I thank my parents every year, on the anniversary of our immigration to Canada. They gave up a paid home, comfort, pension, career, friends, family, language… and the basic necessities that I take for granted now and before immigrating… for the safety and future of their kids (I was the oldest). I will be grateful to my dying day. Last year was the 40th anniversary of the plane landing in Toronto. Previously I had lived in Argentina, and Italy. I have visited dozens of countries, been to every continent except Africa. I have turned down huge money to live in other countries because I rather have less money (and to give some context: I presently work two jobs - had I moved I would have retired 10 years ago) but be able to raise my kids Canadian. I am hard core on this. Is the country perfect? No way. It is not. We can elect idiots just as well as anybody else can. At all levels of government. We have for years, on and off. But we are also allowed to say this without getting shot, or ostracized in the workplace. Think about that. And regardless of whoever is in power, you can work, be educated, save for a house, walk about freely, and access hospitals. That is no small thing. Are all Canadians great to be with? No, they are not. Any sufficiently large demographic sample will include its share of psychopaths and sociopaths, and folks living the parasitic dream of entitlement, … that’s human nature by the numbers. But many Canadians are polite. Not as warm as Spanish or Italians (perhaps the British coldness in the heritage) but given the opportunity they will be friendly, helpful and hospitable. I would not worry about getting lost anywhere in Canada. I can’t say the same about many countries I have visited. I would gladly approach police for help, in Canada. Being raised in Argentina, I was taught not to. I can tell the difference. That does say volumes - does it not? Is it a land of opportunity? It doesn’t feel that way, sometimes. We see companies laying off in spite of record profits just as you see elsewhere. Decisions for Canadian companies are too often driven by HQs elsewhere, and our politicians are still subject to the whims of the various lobby groups (whether they be big business or unions… both sides of the spectrum have their “my way or the highway” toxic personas). However while I do remember my mother wondering how she could afford donated dishes at the Salvation Army store, and us lining up to buy cheaper day old bread to freeze it for later, putting used mattresses on the floor… I see years later that my parents’ kids have a combined 7 University degrees. My parents have received top medical care, always - including successful cancer treatments and they own their own home in spite of that. Their many grandchildren have never lacked for anything and further expect a University education and well paying jobs given suitable focus and effort on their part. There is no reason to believe this is not attainable should they dedicate themselves to their studies and have some flexibility on terms of where to live in the Country. I am raising 5 kids and I am fairly certain that they will want for nothing while I am alive. I say it is the land of opportunity if you are willing to roll up your sleeves and park your sense of entitlement. If you think like an immigrant. Statistically speaking, 68% of the jobs created in Canada over the last 20 years have been in companies with fewer than 100 employees. The movement towards small business, entrepreneurship and startups is strong and getting stronger. You can incorporate yourself as a small business entity for $200 (minimum wage is $14/hr, for comparison), online, and in about 2 hours. You don’t even need a lawyer. That is all it costs to have your own legal business, to access a low corporate tax rate and a myriad of allowed deductions. This is a land of opportunity still. It is my fault that I did not do this, take advantage of this. The opportunity was and is there. I have an interracial marriage and I have a “live and let live” attitude towards religious differences. There are small towns in Canada I would not consider moving to due to this, however affordable the housing there. I prefer larger cities who live the multiculturalism and inclusivity values Canada professes as a country. You have to apply common sense. Canada is large enough. You need to pick and choose where things work for you, where your values are reflected. The thing is, that you can. And yes there are drugs and the myriad of problems associated with them. Heck the current government is keen on legalizing some drugs. I still shake my head in sad disbelief at that, however well intentioned. Canada is not perfect. But it is relatively safe to live in. You can visit many countries on a credit card, as a tourist, and have a great time. But some of the countries you can visit, you would not feel too comfortable living in. I believe Canada is an exception. We have issues with discrimination, racism, police-demographic tensions, religious fundamentalism, native discrimination and entitlement both, and all the other issues associated (again) with a large enough demographic. We have organized crime, gangs, weapons on the street held by folks who ought not to be let out unsupervised. Find me a country with none of these? But we have relatively fewer of all of this, or at least it feels that way. It does feel safer, more polite, more civilized in the good sense of the word. We see on occasion a silly and wasteful, seemingly unaccountable bureaucracy wasting the blood, sweat and tears that earned the taxes they collect. But annoyances and instances of unfairness or institutionalized incompetence notwithstanding, you can live with it. I can get a driver’s license in hours, with a single trip to a single office, with a couple of pieces of ID, and no bribes. I can renew it online, and get a new one by mail. Astonishing, when I think about the trust it implies. There is trust in the good nature of people, built into many systems (some are abused, so there are fewer systems doing this than there used to be). I provide people with my Social Insurance Number by reciting the 9-digit number from memory. I don’t recall ever producing the card. And it is accepted on my word. I can borrow books from any library by saying who I am, if I have forgotten my library card. There are people at doctor clinics requesting free service using by way of ID a card that does not have their picture (I think this is ridiculous, myself, while the government complains that there is health care fraud it is also an enabler; like I said, we’re not perfect). The education system is excellent. It doesn’t push perfection as other countries used to and still do, but it does work to a standard. If you get a degree in Electrical Engineering, or Nursing from Canada, employers know what you know regardless of what school you got it from. This is reflected in poaching from other countries - a good and bad thing, as it reflects some lack of jobs or investment in Canada, but our students are marketable. Folks complain that University is expensive, but it is not - most of the expense is the cost of food and rent if you don’t live near one (hence my two jobs as I have several kids of University age) The tuitions are relatively affordable and there are student loans available. If you want to study, you can. The standards for food, potable water, are real and enforced. Yes we have modified GMO foods and who knows what damage it’s doing to us… and with our trade agreements we open the door for more milk from cows treated with hormones we made illegal in Canada… but I can drink water out of a tap, pretty much anywhere I go. We have affordable health care. Getting cancer in Canada is not a ticket to destitution. Perhaps we may not have the best care that the ridiculously rich could afford in other countries, as everyone is seen as an equal when facing a doctor and we’re aiming at an affordable median of sorts… but there is nothing majorly wrong with our hospitals. Folks travel the world to take their kids to Sick Kids Hospital, or get their hernias operated at the Schouldice Clinic. And for us Canadians, it is free. We don’t invade countries. We on occasion have Prime Ministers who shove their noses where they don’t belong, and talk when they shouldn’t, but we don’t send soldiers to change your government to have you implement his values. Chances are that Canadian owned companies are not polluting your country or exploiting your children. If you see one doing so, a call to a local embassy or a Canadian newspaper would lead to quick change. I am proud of this. We have language issues. The French minority had been discriminated against for years - today they enjoy the privilege of a virtual monopoly on the best Federal Government jobs by virtue of they being Francophones - and also a lock on the election of inevitably francophone Prime Ministers. It’s the Anglophones who are discriminated against now. The pendulum swings… However we accommodate your basic needs in Mandarin, Italian, Spanish, Cantonese, Hindi, Urdu, Arabic,… because when Canadian institutions say they are inclusive, they mean it. Taxes are high. That sucks. But the roads are pretty good, and instances of our politicians being bribed, few and far between. Our minimum wage is not great, but outside of our major cities, you can try to live on it (in our major cities, that is not really possible). I find Canada a safe, comfortable country to raise a family. A country that doesn’t have me worry about my kids health or education, or opportunities. One that provides a passport that is welcomed virtually everywhere. With lots of space, water, fresh air, boundless natural beauty and riches. Fresh water seemingly inexhaustible. Where effort and focus allow you to make your life better. Where you may face problems, but you don’t often need to be crushed by them. And Canada has beaver tails with maple syrup. Yum! ;-)

I cannot believe I am to add an answer to a question with 145 answers, but I believe my New Home has been cast in an undeserving bad light which I hope to mitigate by adding one more. Surely, many of the long-winded answers have legitimate points. But if you are to judge a Nation by mediocre existential criteria like weather, taxation, healthcare, and job compensation, I think you are unfairly missing the very spirit of it. To attempt to capture the same, I wish to provide an anecdotal evidence rather than a factual rambling addressing bourgeoisie concerns. In December 2017, when I was working in the USA on H1-B, I had to renew my Visa by exiting the country . I had also acquired my PR in Canada, so I thought I could complete my landing procedures and get the USA visa stamped, while exploring the potential new home. I was put on administrative processing, and I had to stay here for three months. One of the nights, I was inebriated and took an Uber from a club. The driver was a middle aged middle-eastern man who did not utter a word. I prodded him out of curiosity, and learned that he was a refugee from Syria with a wife and four kids. He worked 16 hours a day— mornings as a butcher, and evenings driving for Uber, and hardly saw his kids. His sufferings aside, he was happy that his kids are fluent in English, and have a secure future in this country. This already made me mildly guilty, given the nature of my evening. It was snowing, and we stopped at a red light. At the red light was a college-aged white kid cleaning windows for spare change. Every car was shooing him away. While he cleaned our windshield , I proceeded to take some change out of my pocket. My driver stopped me, took a two dollar coin from his cup-holder, gave it to the kid. With a smile he said, “ Thank you!” I have cried exactly four times in my adult life, and this was the fourth. I am not even a romantic by my constitution, and yet, this event has registered strongly in my mind. You see, it is easy to take well educated immigrants who are ready to contribute from Day 1, and run a “successful” economy while exposing these immigrants to less than ideal conditions. You might even be successful in this unnamed nation and think less of Canada, you have every right to do so. But to be a part of a harmonious and pluralist society , where we accommodate immigrants of varied cultural and economic backgrounds starting from zero , so that the next generation has a good chance of success, and the immigrant himself has a peaceful life— that is what Canada is about. That is why I call this my home. After all, I believe Home is a place where no one asks you where you are from. That night, I decided in my tears that Canada is my new home. I left for the USA with the sole intention of returning here. I did— and no, I have not regretted it. To those worried about these “factors” other answers are describing, don’t come. But if you have it in your heart and in your mind to contribute to a harmonious society and live peacefully, I have one word for you: Come ! Particularly if you are one of the science graduates from the USA teetering whether to make the move now, and wondering that Canada does not have the same innovative environment as the USA, remember— you are the one making innovations possible. So Come ! I will disable the comments ahead in time, since it is not in my constitution to worry about feedback either.

It was the right decision at the time when China was not a good place to be. Now that China has surpassed Canada in many aspects moving here is starting to feel like a big mistake. I’ve been in Canada for 20 plus years but not much as changed unlike other countries. Here are some major issues: 1.) The taxes are very high and become progressively higher as you make more money. So success basically yields diminishing returns and effectively punishes success and rewards failure. This lead to a huge brain drain problem where the most industrious Canadians move to the US where they are treated better. 2.) The universal healthcare is very inefficient. I’ve waited in the ER for 15 hours once. Getting a specialist could take months. Check-ups are not covered. You can’t even opt out of this system as they’ve made private health insurance illegal. 3.) No matter how much stellar work experience you have from other developed countries they won’t be recognized. I think they do this to protect local Canadians so they don’t have to compete with international talent. Very ironic as they set a very high bar for skilled immigration when they don’t even utilize those skills. There are doctors from Russia that end up as taxi drivers because their license and experience is null and void here. To me this is institutional racism. 4.) The culture is very much rooted in all the trappings of left-wing ideology. You are taught from a very young age to look at wealth and upward mobility with suspicion. There’s a general mentality of victimhood and entitlement. If you’re not successful it must be the fault of corporations or rich people. The gov’t is supposed to solve all your problems. I find this to be very demoralizing and depressing. I don’t think this is the message you should send to young people. 5.) There’s a drug problem on the streets. I’ve never seen so many meth heads anywhere else in the world. I’m not sure what caused this. Maybe the laws are too lenient towards drug dealing and usage? In major cities downtown you will find a lot of druggies panhandling for money. Mostly young people. 6.) The media is quite biased. Everything reported on China and any other non OECD nations is 100per cent bad and no person previously questions its credibility. The exclusion is US, also regarded as wicked. The individuals right here see themselves as the good guys therefore the rest of the world is difficult or directly dishonest. I believe as soon as we left China we thought we had been escaping an oppressive regime to call home in a democratic utopia. Everything we learned is the fact that democracy might not be top as a type of gov’t (and even though they train you to believe it is) and western media does coequally as good as of employment brainwashing their very own individuals. The narrative Canada sells is not always a reflection of truth. Maybe freedom is a concept. Edit: I simply wish to include that i do believe why Canada sits on its large horse of ethics and points the hands at other individuals is mainly because they have only one neighbor plus it’s an agreeable one. They've a good amount of normal resources and low population. They never have to be worried about starvation or invasion. It’s very easy to be ethical when you don’t need to make the tough choices to defend your territory and safe sources. It’s perhaps not fair for them to judge.

I don’t. I came to Quebec without any connections nor the “Canadian job experience” and still loving my stay to this day. That said, I work in the software industry where the demand is high and is still that way. I got my first job 6 weeks after I landed at the airport, but boy those 6 weeks were full of self-doubt and worry. However during that time I did get face-to-face interviews or at least phone calls that ask me questions that were specifically about the position that they have open (instead of merely asking about my past experiences in non-North American countries), which I take as their genuine interest in my professional experience. I also have the advantage of having good communication skills in addition to sounding a bit North American when I speak English, even though I wasn’t born in this continent and am a visible minority. I mentioned the former, because I think one can go a long way in a job interview if you sound like you come from the same place as they do, and that is my reality. I speak French, which played a big part in gaining my immigration certificate to this province. But I have to say at the workplace I speak English 99% of the time due to our clientele of whom a great majority are North American and Australian companies. Another thing that I don’t regret is the people feel very welcoming when you first meet them, which is a contrast to my previous city, Paris. Another poster here, Lewis J., mentioned the dating scene is bad. I say yes and no. The couples that I know started dating each other through a mutual activity, e.g. short courses, school, etc. Rarely have I seen couples who met through the express intention of “having a girlfriend/boyfriend”, e.g. the Tinder experience, etc. I suppose it’s due to the social dynamics in this society. Just remember before coming to Canada, research everything you need to know about the requirements in your industry. If you know anyone in your field who lives in the Canadian city you’re trying to move to, make *full* use of that networking opportunity because employers here trust personal references *a lot* more than just by looking at the resume. Good luck,

Best decision I’ve ever made in my life! I could say moving to Canada is the best decision I’ve ever made in my life. Canada is a land of endless opportunity. I know a lot of people who struggle to get a job as soon as they landed here. Some choose to stay in a job that is completely unrelated to what they were doing back home. And that’s what makes it worse! Before I boarded the plane to Canada, I convinced myself that I would do whatever it takes to survive. I am willing to do any kind of job - whether it’s minimum wage, part time or full time as long as it’s legal and it pays the bills. Having that mentality helped me adjust quickly to my new environment. I moved to Canada without any friends or relatives that could help or guide me. On my second day, I went to Service Canada to get all the necessary documents so I could apply for a job. On that same day, I got my SIN and was ready to look for a job. I went to a mobile shop to get a Canadian number to put in my resume. Despite being unfamiliar with the place, I walked around and look for job vacancies. Luckily there was a job opening in a shawarma place nearby. I applied as cashier and the manager of the store hired me. Three days after I started working. I had no idea how to do the job as I have no prior experience doing cash job. I did whatever I could to learn fast and it was a very good experience for me as I learned how to deal with customers. I am a chemical engineer by profession but I didn’t let my pride get in the way of earning money. I accepted a minimum wage and less working hours. For me it was a good start. The manager saw that I was doing well in my job so he gave me more hours. I was making enough to pay for my rent, phone bills, and food. I didn’t stop applying for a job. I customized my resume based on the job requirement. I applied for a job everyday. I didn’t lose hope. After one month, I got a call from a recruiter and she set me up for an interview with a paint company. The following week I met the regional manager for an interview. Three days after the recruiter called me again to arrange a plant visit. There was another candidate for the job. I did my best but without any expectation. A week after I received a job offer and I was about to start in two weeks. The offer was more than I expected! The biggest challenged I encountered was not having any mode of transportation because the job requires me to drive from office to the plant. Aside from that, I had to move to a city where there was no public transport. I was scared it would make me lose the opportunity. I took a deep breath and started looking for a vehicle. As a newcomer it can be challenging to get approved for a car loan and I did! Car was ready for pick up but I couldn’t get it unless I have driver’s license and insurance. I took risk and booked a driving test. I have over 10 years experience driving back home so I thought maybe this would help. I aced the G1 test but there was another problem. I couldn’t get a G2 test schedule within a month. I called every person in my contact list to see if they know anybody that could help me get a schedule. Luckily, I found someone and she got me the earliest schedule possible. It was make or break. I took G2 test on a rainy day and I passed! As soon as I got my driver’s license and insurance, I picked up the car and moved forward with my job. I’ve been working with the paint company for 8 months now with full benefits. Lesson learned - don’t get disheartened when you experience challenges in life. Make it an inspiration to work harder.

I will try to answer this from my own personal perspective, and from the trends I have seen in Canada after I moved to Toronto: Pros: People are nice, but not all, further explained in cons.Society is more tolerant of immigrants.Gun laws are stringent, and gun violence is almost non existent.Immigration is easy.You will not feel alone, there are people from all ethnicities.Racism exists but is not to the levels that it will suffocate you.Medical costs are low, you still need insurance for dental, vision, and prescription coverage though.Water is cheap, electricity is cheaper than most places I have lived in.Air quality is very good, very less pollution.It is a very beautiful country. I love going on long drives.Cons: Job experience from anywhere outside Canada is not considered. You will start fresh and will need to climb the ladder again.If you don't have references, forget about landing a decent job.Everything is expensive in quick comparison to US.Cars are expensive. Car insurance is super expensive.Housing is out of reach in Toronto and Vancouver, where 90% (ok more like 70%) jobs are.Medicare is painful when it comes to emergencies. Imagine waiting nine hours in emergency with a broken bone while doctors tend to a teenager who got bad throat due to excessive smoking but can fake pain better than you can. No, they don't prioritize in most cases. And if you want to see a specialist, better be prepared to wait for months for an appointment.Racism exists, not as bad as US, and some people are frustrated with influx of immigrants.There is a big gap in immigration policies and the mindset of employers.Weather is extreme enough to kill you in minutes in most of Canada.You cannot save. Taxes takes almost half of what you earn.Sales tax is extremely high. It was 15% in Ontario, which has been reduced to 13% now. This is what you pay when you buy anything, or any service.Public transportation is extremely expensive. Travel is expensive, both domestic and international.Some people I have encountered were extremely rude, they actually topped the charts of rudeness compared to some other encounters in US, Europe, and South East Asia.Gas prices are one of the most expensive in the world. A litre in Vancouver costs about $1.60.Very bad roads, they'll kill your suspension and tires if you are not careful. This is due to bad weather.Food is expensive, eating out is expensive.Liquor is twice as expensive as in US, don't forget to grab a bottle from duty free.Most important, salaries are on an average 30% less than what they are in US, that combined with high taxes leads to no or very less wiggle room for savings.So overall, it was a disappointing move. But that doesn't mean that Canada is a bad country. It is a good country but comes with it's own challenges like anywhere else. Depends on what you want.

SAD TO SAY, I DAILY LIVED IN REMORSE IN CANADA CANADA IS DEAD, socially, emotionally and romantically! It’s a depressing, suppressing, oppressing, frustrating wilderness. Can you handle the truth? Then read on… Permit me to say that Canadians are great people. So, this piece of writing main objective is to disclose the reality in Canadian society, so that revolutionary positive changes can be realized for the general good of all. Believe or not, Canadians are living in social and romantic bondage! With that being said, let’s dive right into it. With jaw dropping strides in information technology, Google search can answer quite a lot of questions. Additionally, we also have robots such as Bertha, Alexa, Siri, Google Assistant and Cortana to help us getting answers. However, if one is to look for an answer in Google for a question such as: “How romantic are Canadians?” “Are Canadians romantic?” and “Is Canada a romantic country?” there is hardly a relevant, helpful answer, if any, that comes up. Instead, the answer type that seems to return is like this one: “10 Most Romantic Places in Canada You Need to Visit’ and similar answers. Of course, this kind of answer will go on to promote the nice materialistic features of these places with tourism in mind but nothing much about social, romantic interaction of Canadians. However, when “America” and “Americans” are substituted in the same questions, guess what? There is a return of numerous answers which are more relevant in answering the questions. Perhaps because it would be a shame to even discuss or write about it, there is hardly anything that can be found on the internet relative to Canadian romance. The point is, as opposed to their neighbors, Canadians do not seem to have a lot going on with respect to dating, love and romance. But using the information, or lack thereof, on the internet can’t reliably make a valid and sound conclusion. That is mentioned only as an observation. So, let’s move on. In order to assess how loving and romantic Canadians are, possibly we could start off discussing DATING a little, based on investigation. During my social investigation/experiment in Canadian society, it was observed that both male and female scarcely make approach to each other in public (streets, parks, stores, shops, subways, buses, recreational facilities, etc). It is non-existent. It’s probably more uncommon than an eclipse of the sun, moon and earth. That’s an exaggeration, of course! As a way to test how open-minded, approachable and social Canadians are, I personally approached several women, randomly in public places but in a majority of cases I did not get far in trying to have a friendly chat. No sooner had I said a few words than I was rudely interrupted with outburst such as: “I do not talk to strangers,” “I do not know you” “Where are you from?” etc. In cases where an actual chat was possible, I finally got: “I do not give my phone number to strangers” “I have a boyfriend” etc. Nevertheless, the actual point is: approach doesn’t happen in public places, not in Canada! Scientifically, it is known that the human male has more of the innate built-in capacity of being proactive in getting certain actions done, particularly in making approaches to women in dating them, when compared to women; that is, generally, the male makes the first move. In exceptional cases, women do make the first move. Now as it regards Canadian society, done at a low profile, minimally, subtle manner, the places where approaches are more likely to be made include clubs, bars, parties, excursions and similar such places and occasions. People, both men and women, are sadly lonely and bored to death but nobody has the nerve to make an approach to break the ice. Timidity is so characteristic of the Canadian culture. This will come as a shock to say Canadian males are predominantly introverted “Beta males”, with few “Alpha males,” of course. Let’s backstep a little and take a look as to why Canadian dating and romance are in a sorrowful, despairing, broken-heart state of affairs. It’s found that Canadian culture is too tight, tensed, stiff and paranoid. There is no flexibility and easy going demeanor. People seem as if they are bridled, as if being shut down or being told to shut up. It is a fact that people can be easily hypnotized. The human mind is programmable. It can be brainwashed and manipulated by many rules, laws, mainstream media news and other public information. Canadians are cold-hearted in a very cold country. Like someone said, paraphrasing a bit, “The Canadian cold heart social culture and the -40 degrees Celsius temperatures form a deadly combination.” There is no joy, enthusiasm and spontaneity. Lacking a good sense of humor, residents seldom crack jokes, and, therefore, scarcely smile, much less laugh. No liveliness. The country is dead, socially, emotionally and romantically. Blessed silence is preferred. It’s weird. Any traveler can witness that there is a deafening silence squatting across the Canadian vast landscape, all around the country, as residents hardly talk among themselves, much less with strangers. Lest someone gets confused, silence doesn't mean that there is inner peace in one's spirit. Instead, there is a subtle, silent “war” going on in Canadian society, hostility among residents. People can't tolerate each other. It's like a warning: “Keep your distance!" or “I need my space!” Of course, this sounds weird but it’s true. Well, of course, the many stringent, oppressive laws are keeping people from fighting among each other, so crimes are kept at a minimum, compared to other nations. But Canadians are far from being peaceful in terms of having peace in their spirit and daily lives. In trying to change a nation, how can one person fight against a crowd? Canadian culture is extremely strong, compulsive and contagious. So, it doesn’t take long for a new immigrant to get sucked into it. Like a monster devouring someone. Overnight, they start using certain words as: “like” “eh” “loonie” “toonie” “double-double”. As if afraid that someone will tell them to shut up or torture them, people are not generally themselves when speaking. So, people economize on their words, by saying very little, in as quiet a tone as possible, almost like whispering, or like tiptoeing while walking, being careful not to disturb someone else. The word, “like” is so overused, as if to get the listener to totally agree with the talker, as if smooth talking, if I may say. Apparently, no one has the guts to stand out from the crowd by giving a different perspective to a particular issue in discussion, being hyper politically correct. There is little or no creativity. No one is outstanding. That is, generally. No wonder, some foreigners would even say Canadians don’t have a personality or individuality. For more insight, please refer to my answer on “Is it boring living in Canada?” CONCLUSION Based on the investigation, it can be said that Canadians are not “very loving people.” However, it’s a fact that many women confessed that they love their dogs more than the opposite sex! Hence, an uncountable number of them are quite often seen walking out their dogs in public. Holistically, Canadians, both males and females, are starved of an effective dating and romantic life. Blame it on the culture! On a romance rating scale of, let’s say 1-10, could someone possibly give them a score of 3? SOLUTION As for individual Canadians, do you really want to follow the crowd? Why denying yourself of the fullness of a happy life. First and foremost, someone has to realize what is the reality. I adjure you, do a little investigation. For only a short period of time, peel away certain distractions. Do this for you. Take your eyes off the beautiful landscape, buildings, vehicles and other material things around you. Forget about work, business and study. Don’t be stingy for this little time off. Then zoom in your focus on how people around you interact among each other. Critically analyze it. Do this for at least a few days or as long as you wish. With an open mind, and if honest, you would most certainly discover the Canadian social culture for what it truly is. Only if the entire Canadian population decides to change its attitudes, behaviors, habits, rules, among other things - thereby changing its paranoid, boring culture- will it make a positive change on social life, which in turn has the consequential impact of positively changing dating and romance in Canadian society. It’s time to jump out of one’s sleeping chamber, comfort zone, mediocrity and start lobbying/agitating for positive changes. Canadians deserve a better social, dating and romantic life! PS: Please share this information. One person can make a big difference.

I was born in Canada and have lived here all my life except for 11 years working and living in the US, so this question is not really directed to me, but I would like to offer a few comments. The answers here are qood, insightful and true for each individual as they are their real life experiences. My comments: Canada is frequently compared to the US due to proximity and the strong US influence. But Canada is a vastly smaller country by population ( 10 times smaller) so in many areas Canada cannot possibly compete with the US.A common view is Canadians pay much higher taxes than Americans. That was not our experience, having lived and worked in both countries. When all taxes are included, we found our total tax in Canada was just slightly higher than the US - just under 5% higher; in large part due to healthcare , which contributes to the higher tax load in Canada, We , personally , are far better off in Canada. I had 2 major surgeries in Canada, complete with 4 months free in home indiividualized physical therapy- my total out of pocket cost - $ 35 dollars for an ambulance. I costed comparable procedures in the US at $ 300,000 + not including physio or medications while in hospital ( no charge in Canada). Even with Company paid health insurance like I had in the US, my costs would have been massive.In 66 years, I have never waited for 9 hours for treatment in an emergency room; 4 hours was the most and my problem was not life threatening. They treated two folks having heart attacks first - as they absolutely should. Bothered me not at all. I will disagree with a comment suggesting emergency room treatment is first come, first served. I am not saying that didn’t happen in an isolated incident, but the ER procedures are to triage all patients so the most serious are treated first. Sure, wait times still need to come down and they are , but in my view the issue is overemphasized.Re seeing a specialist - in some specialties , there is shortage of specialists, but that is being addressed. I personally have never waited a long time for specialist care - after falling and breaking my femur, i was admitted to hospital at night, given medication for pain and operated on by an orthopaedic surgeon within 12 hours, out of hospital 3 days. Similarly, a torn retina discovered at noon was repaired by a retinal specialist using laser surgery in less than 3 hours. Just my experience- there is indeed a problem in some specialties. It is being addressed but it will take some time.Gasoline prices are certainly higher in Canada than US , much of the difference is due to health care. But compared to most European countries, gas prices here are lower.Just some comments from a Canadians personal experience. I welcome all new Canadians. The criticisms I read about are absolutely true. Some of the practices and negative experiences would be discouraging for anyone. I know some are being addressed, but there is much improvement yet to do. I hope things improve for our new arrivals; yes, we have our share of bigoted knoheads but be assured this Canadian and most Canadians for that matter value and respect immigrants. We need you. We are really all the immigrants. Yes, I am Canadian, but my roots are in Europe. Our noble indigenous folks, who deserved much better and still deserve better might be the only non immigrants. Welcome to Canada and best wishes. Your predecessors helped make Canada a better country , as will you. The country will be better off with you here. A Canadian friend.

It’s been 4 months that I have moved to Canada as a Permanent Resident - the coveted tag that almost every other Punjabi is after these days. And, believe me - life here is not a bed of roses as everyone pictures from far. And, there are plenty of reasons for the same: The cold weather!!! - As soon as you land, you feel the chill in the air (I felt it even when it was the ‘so called SUMMER” for Canadians - the month of May). I had to wear a jacket on the first weekend while going out with my friends.The laid back lifestyle - Trust me when I say that we people are far more active in our home countries than people in Canada. You see people with a far more laid back lifestyle and attitude in this part of the world.Job struggle - I pity those people who come to Canada and believe they can earn big bucks; especially those who leave their well-paying white-collar jobs in their country. Job struggle is immense here. Recruiting processes crawl at snail-speed. Forget about reaching to the recruiting phase, most of the employers will reject you because you don’t have the ‘Canadian work exprience’. It’s like a polite way of saying ‘screw your hard work and experience that you did in a multinational in your home country. Canadian work is above and beyond that!’Too many INDIANS - I am an Indian and I love my home country, but seriously if I had to get the feeling of living in the middle of India why would I move to Canada? There are so many Indians (especially Punjabis in the GTA and BC - the most livable parts of the country) that not even for a single day you will feel you are out of India.Just to add a little more, I’d like to share a few pics that will help explain these facts better. A picture in one of the meetings during the recent Election campaigning in Brampton. It is worth seeing that almost the entire hall is filled with Indians.  One of the advertisements I clickd while walking through the streets of Brampton.  And, to end this post on a funny note, here’s something I hope you will read and enjoy.  Text in the image: Sorry, you cannot come to Mumbai for the auditions.So what??? I can go to Canada!!!PS - for those of you who believe that getting a Canadian PR is the ultimate goal, here’s what I’d recommend you to definitely think!!!  Text in the image: Dear God, is there something else beyond this as well??? PSS - No hard feelings, it is a personal choice. But, trust me it is not worth it to leave your friends, family, and life!!! Thank you, everyone, for such an overwhelming response to my answer. I did not expect it at all. For all those who think that I hold something against Canada or people from my own country (so-called DESIS), well I don’t have anything against it. I simply mean to say that it is personal choice for everyone. I like the country, I like the calmness that it brings, and I love cleanliness. However, there are somethings which did not appeal to me, just like for many of you quite a number of things from back home do not appeal. It’s just my personal opinion and point of view. For all of those saying I should move back, well I will when the right time comes but it is not now. Canada is a beautiful country, but not for everyone, and not everything is laid here on a bed of roses, it has its own struggles that every country has. PS - the winters have just begun, I am already feeling the chill. Peace :) Note: When I wrote this answer initially, I received a lot of hate comments that after a few months I will start praising Canada etc. etc., and I will never move back. To all those comments, I’ve moved back to India. And, I’m happy to be part of this Cosmic Chaos we love to refer to as INDIA. :D

“Yes and No”. A very common response (that I noticed lately) for a difficult question. I’ve been here for almost 7 years now and I’ve been through a lot. I started from the bottom (with “survival jobs” as they say here - physical work), but I reached my goal gradually, by getting an entry level job in IT after 6 months and getting to the level I wanted after 5 years. If you have read other stories about how difficult is to get a job in your field (maybe IT is an exception, but you still have to try hard IMO), and you think that after you get your dream job everything will be perfect, for me it was kind of the opposite. Don’t get me wrong, I am actually really happy with my job. But a while after I reached my goals (job, car, house), when more than my basic needs were met, I started noticing the negatives. And when I look at pics/videos from the beginning when I didn’t have much, but only dreams, I seem to be happier.Probably I am focused too much on seeing these negative aspects, but after living for 30 some years in Eastern Europe, I left for a few reasons. Primarily financial, but in my naivety I was imagining that things are much better - if not perfect - in the western world. I was so wrong about this. The difference between the western world and at least the developed countries in Eastern Europe, is that Canada promotes only the positives, opposed to the negatives. Probably inspired by USA where things are even worse, yet they think they are the greatest country in the world…But trust me, there are a lot of negatives here as well, there is a lot of poverty, much much more homelessness and drug addicts than where I come from, many uneducated people (they wear pajamas outside and think they are cool), dirty streets (in some places), people that don’t care about anything (like throwing products on the floor in stores)… Also customer service can be great, but also lousy, sales people will lie to your face without any remorse…The big positive that everybody brags about is free health care…well it is free because you pay a LOT of taxes, and I have no problem with that, but I don’t understand why almost all doctors are from a certain part of the world…the part that care the less about life and people in general… So yeah…maybe these are first world problems…I don’t know…but in my opinion the most developed countries in the world haven’t gotten that far after all. Maslow was right. Maslow's hierarchy of needs - WikipediaI was only able to meet my physiological needs here. Everything else is the same or worse than back home. But this is my opinion/experience. Although talking to people from all over the world, everybody misses their home country. They just don’t admit to their friends back home. This creates a lot of falsity in the world.

“It’s better to regret something you have done than to regret something you have not done.” These words resonated in my head as I ripped my hair apart trying to decide whether to move to Canada while I was living my lavish lifestyle back in Dubai where I was born and raised. A cushy job, marble floored condo, top-of-the-range SUV, live-in nanny, family, friends. I had it all - except for one thing. The right to unconditionally live in the country I grew up in. As the United Arab Emirates (and many neighbouring countries in the Middle East) do not have a citizenship program, my legal country of origin was inherited from my parents - India. A country I never had and never will have any intention of moving to. So I decided to risk it all and take a leap of faith and move to Canada. No job in hand. Just a sheer will to succeed, and enough cash to see me through several months of unemployment. From the day I landed in Canada, I was one step closer to being accepted as a citizen of this country. In other words, Canada did more for me in one day than Dubai did for me in 33 years in terms of acceptance, equality and just plain fairness! If I did regret my move, it would have been centred around 3 factors: The jobThe weatherThe lifestyleThe job Many have regretted moving to Canada. You’ll find them all over the internet. People are entitled to their opinions. I prefer to base decisions on facts. The most common reason people have regrets is not finding a job in a reasonable amount of time. And out comes the racism card. I, for one, never believe that people don’t find jobs due to racial reasons. I currently work for one of the largest proud-to-be-Canadian telecommunications companies in Canada, and I see a full spectrum of race in my organization. I will admit however, that Canadian hiring executives do tend to be choosy when recruiting. Canadian experience is a real problem. But what is funny is that many people state they are told they don’t have Canadian experience at the interview itself. If your résumé already confirms you have never worked in Canada, why were you called for the interview in the first place? My personal experience? I got three job offers in three weeks after I landed. I’m not exceptionally talented or skilled at what I do. I just took the initiative to learn how to job search the right way in Canada. Never had the Canadian experience issue, even though all of my 12 year experience was from the Middle East. No regrets there. But everyone has their own challenges when working the Canadian job market, especially those applying for regulated jobs. Soft skills is a mega requirement out here, especially when speaking. Majority of immigrants come from Asia, where English may not be their first language. Understanding Canadian work culture and demonstrating it at the job interview is also important. Any shortcomings in these areas, and you can get the Canadian experience card dealt to you. A lot of people also state how easy it is to get a job in the US while Canada’s hiring executives seem to have a Made in Canada stick up their ass when recruiting. But what they fail to tell you, is that America also has at-will employment, which means you can get fired at any time, no justifications required. This doesn’t happen in Ontario. Once you pass the 3/6 month probation period, your full-time employment (as opposed to contract) is fairly well protected. So you can imagine why hiring executives would be a bit more, let’s say “cautious”, when it comes to the hiring process. Unfortunately, this cautiousness transfers the challenges of job placement to the job seeker. S/he would need to work that much harder to get that first job in Canada. The weather November was upon us in no time, and the jackets came on. This was it. You can only imagine, after living in 45+ degree Celsius summers back in Dubai for 33 years, this was going to be quite the contrast. But, I adapted. The same tactics that were used in Dubai to avoid the heat, were used in Canada to avoid the cold - stay indoors (if you want) There were only two things about the winter that bothered me - the snow and the winter clothes. Cold does not disrupt your life. Snow and ice does. When it occasionally snows, you have to drag slush around everywhere you go, traffic piles up behind snow plows, and there is black ice on the sidewalks to watch out for. And transitioning indoor and outdoor is a hassle - putting on the gloves and the boots and the heavy jacket, and doing the same for your kids. It’s an annoyance you eventually get used to. And just as quickly as it came, 4 months later the winter snow leaves us to welcome the awesome spring weather, and the even more amazing summer. Mother Nature rolls up her sleeves and gives Canada a blanket of green and blue colours we never stop appreciating. No regrets there. Granted, Ontario has notably the best weather and the most forgiving winters compared to other provinces. Ultimately, where you move is your choice. The Lifestyle Coming from Asia and the Middle East, this was probably the biggest temptation that would lead to regret. All materialistic wants are harder to come by. Live-in nannies? Hahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahaha. Outside help as a whole is expensive. My toddler just clogged up my toilet with a wooden spoon, and after my DIY attempts failed, the plumber cost me $100 for a 5 minute visit to unclog it. Unlike my life in Dubai, I can no longer lavishly spend on wants. I can no longer eat out whenever I feel like it. I have to think twice every time I open my wallet. But there are those in Canada who do live like this - the same way I lived in Dubai. The difference? They had to work a lot harder to get there. You have to be at a director level and above, or own a thriving Canadian business to live the same lifestyle you would live as a middle class in Dubai (and maybe even India?) So what am I doing about it? I’m working my ass off to get there. I’m pushing myself to my limits. Limits I would have never reached back in my cushy life in Dubai. I work a full-time job, run a side business to help newcomers to Canada and raise 2 small children - yes, without a nanny. Are there days when I feel like calling it quits? Yes. Are there days when I feel like saying “Fuck it!” and move back to Dubai with the comfort of family? Absolutely. But then, I ask myself one last question - “Am I a better person today than I was 3 years ago?” You bet your ass I am! No regrets there! Will you regret your move to Canada? If you look for reasons not to do something, you will easily find them. That’s what people who don’t reach their full potential in life do. Other people’s regret cannot be a factor towards your own decisions. It’s like trying to decide whether you are going to marry someone by asking the masses if they regretted their own marriages. Just like a marriage, you won’t know what Canada will be like for you until you experience it first-hand. Every marriage is unique, just like every immigrant’s experience is. I know it’s a hard choice to make, especially considering what you will be leaving behind. For me, I knew that if I did not take the risk, I would spend the rest of my life asking myself “What if…?” That would have led to some serious regret! Now, 5 years later, it’s the best decision I’ve ever made. Instead of dwelling on regrets, focus on what you can accomplish in Canada, and ask yourself what you’re willing to do to get there. If you’re job is your biggest concern, then you can properly test the waters before moving to Canada. However, you need to know the process of how to apply for jobs in Canada, as it’s not the same as the rest of the world. I studied from countless books written by the greatest career coaches in North America, and discovered a resumé template that actually works in Canada. Click here to download the template To your success in Canada.

Don't come to Canada with super high expectations or you will be disappointed quickly. If you have a great job with good benefits where you are, pls. stay there. A lot of high skilled immigrants I've met as an employment counsellor who helps to find jobs in Canada are demoralized as they can not find equal level jobs they left back home. Know this, your skills are not considered comparable. Period. You will start from the BOTTOM! Discrimination exist covertly. Your accent, communication skills,your ability to convey knowledge/ experience in the Canadian context might differ from what You are accustomed to. You will have to be on top of your game. It might be about who you Know. Networking is sometimes key. Know your job description well. Interviews are not about knowing your skills. It's also about that and more. Chance are you don't don't have appropriate answers. What they need, want to hear. Chances are you did not know what they want because you did not read, research and learn about the company and industry and job duties, you did not research the Canadian context of the job. It's cumbersome if not prepared. Another idea per my experience, remove countries you've gained experience or worked in from resume to gain attention clear and void of what's deemed foreign experience, not canadian experience. I came here in 2007. I speak well. Even with a good amount of good American accent in Canada, unless nervous then it shows. I know my shit! In fact my name could never tell that I am black, African. I get the interviews but once they are my black face, all else changed. So beware folks! Unless your life is threatened in your country. If you have respect in your profession and a good job where you are, stay put. North America, Canada is no joke for those educated people, secure in your knowledge, you will have to start from the begining even with Phds. Medical doctors. Master's from abroad… think carefully before you come! Consult an employment counsellor and even they can not predict your future. I have been there. Just saying!

I did and I left. My background is somewhat different. I was born in the States, but my father is Canadian and my mother is from Europe, so I already had Canadian citizenship. My family moved to Canada when I was eight and I stayed until about a year after finishing university, then moved to the States after getting a job. A few years later, after working and going to grad school, some family issues came up and I had to move back. I wasn’t eager to leave, but I thought I would give it a shot and I was told that there would be plenty of jobs for me in my field, even though I did a ton of research and saw it would be tough. But I was fairly young at the time and I wanted to be closer to my family. The move did not work out well at all and I soon regretted it. I had great difficulty getting any notice for jobs in my field. I knew I’d probably have to go down a few notches and prepared for it, but the only things I could find were call center and basic admin work. It was humiliating, especially after grad school and working some good jobs at some good organizations in NYC, a place from where my skills should have been transferable or recognized. In the few interviews I was able to get, I was told that I lacked “Canadian experience”, which has apparently become a cliche. At my last interview, the interviewer brought this up and I responded by telling him that I was way more qualified than he was to do his own job. I just didn’t care at that point and didn’t hold back. He agreed and said that I would have a tough time finding good work because lots of Canadian employers are biased against those who went straight to the States after college. After that, I figured it was time to go and I moved back to NY. Other explanations why we left: I couldn’t stand the extreme cold.My friends, whom I had grown up with, were all married and I was the only single person, so my social life sucked. It was tough to meet new people and I didn’t find the few people I did meet to be all that interesting.Bad dating scene.Even if I did end up getting a decent job, my career prospects would have been limited and there would be little chance for growth, so I wanted more diverse opportunities.Taxes.The anti-Americanism was a pain in the ass to hear. Canadians have a global reputation of being extremely tolerant and polite…except when it comes to Americans. A lot of it was just nonsensical and it’s a form of prejudice, full stop. It was annoying because I was born in the States and I hated hearing others slag on my place of birth. It’s also incredibly hypocritical to boast about tolerance (even defending intolerant acts by other, non-American cultures!) when practicing the opposite.Political correctness overdrive. Now, I’m not in favor of insulting others, but the PC environment in Canada is stifling. I remember being told in school that we were to refer to “janitors” as “sanitation engineers”. What the fuck?! I can imagine it being worse now under Trudeau.Lack of traveling options and I wanted to travel more. Canada is extremely expensive to travel from.There are other explanations, but these one thinks of right now. Granted, I do think Canada is an excellent nation and I also don’t have regrets about developing up there. For certain, it absolutely was a good place to mature. It just didn’t work-out for me as an adult.

NOT ONE BIT ! ! ! I love living in Canada! It is cold yes, but it is beautiful and peaceful and you get a fair chance at building a life you so want to pursue….Dreams that you want to reach! My husband and I lived in Los Angeles, California for 4 years before deciding to immigrate to Canada… When we first lived here in 1990, I thought, “Why have we done this?” Our friends said - “You guys are crazy! You will freeze to death there! Leaving sunny California will be the biggest mistake of your life!” We disproved that! Because we “burned our bridges” for 2 years, worked our way up and discovered these: Our job experience in the USA was accepted at all the jobs that we applied for.It was a challenge to find the jobs we like and landed in - took us over 2 months. Two months where we were relentless in pursuing and going to job fairs, and getting up each day like we are ready for work (ready to fight) and sitting at the kitchen table typing our resume to suit every single job that we applied for.We were allowed to just switch our California driver’s licence to the province license, take an eye exam and that was it - we were able to buy a car once we got jobs. A wonderful discovery I might add… Driving by the country side and going places was WONDERFUL!Although we were lucky that our job experience were considered when applying for a job; some of our “new comer” friends did lots of volunteer work to get the experience and got jobs in due time as well. It is really how you approach life that counts… Stick to the PLAN until it works!No matter where you decide to live, there is a starting point, you fight to make it work - it was really, really hard work at first but we held on to our dreams of a better life and we work, save money, work, save, work more and save more…repeat,repeat, repeat… and then we got it! It has been 29 years now and we are now living it and comfortably loving it! We get to travel across the country, the world- LOVING IT!!! Our responsibility is how we respond to life. TRY IT! With what’s happening in the USA now, NO REGRETS !!!! No regrets at all!

My childhood was in Korea, and I moved often in the past before settling here in Canada. Here’s my take on Canada, for better or for worse.  Living in Canada? Not Great, not Terrible either. It really depends what you want to do. There are plenty of immigrants wanting to move here (for better or for worse). Canada is undeniably better than many other countries relatively speaking for many immigrants. Since the question is looking at Canada negatively, there are some I’ve experienced personally that supports this. Canada is “NOT” nice; it is a nation of collective apathy on social scale much like a hotel; it’s nice enough to attract many people and it’s comfortable, but it’s generic and indifferent. Some see this as a con while some see it as a beauty. Hence, it’s much harder (especially for immigrants) to really mingle and blend it with locals in general.It is far more expensive to live here in general, though it has universal health care to offset the gap between here and the States. Wage may appear better than the states if you just look at the magnitude of the pay for low-mid range salary, but CAD is generally 30% worth less than USD. The living cost in general is higher. So you have lower-paying wage and higher living expense. Not terribly great combo for people who want to be ambitious about financial success. And it happens to be that many immigrants take risk and move away from their home country to be more successful… so this trend will be discouraging to many.Winter is a bitch in heat. Not only that it’s cold, it’s also dry and making it worse for skin in general. Canada is more isolated my geography in general, so excessive snow has far more detrimental impact than many US regions with similar climate. Bear in mind, this isn’t applicable to BC which is closer to California and climate is much nicer there and its humidity not shielded by Rocky Mountains like Alberta, Saskatchewan and Manitoba oof.Job is more limited here compared to the States due to Canadian market being smaller and business operation being more expensive in general. I don’t think Canadians taxes are particularly higher than the States in general, but there are definitely less room for tax avoidance here than in the states for better or for worse.Less choices. If you want to live like a norm, this place allows you to do that easily. If you try to live above the norm (not just financially but in general), you will have harder time doing so… not that it’s illegal but it will be more painstakingly hard to find options or will cost you more (probably combination of both). If you like average-just above avg lifestyle and enjoy slow-paced and calm mentality, I’d say Canada is a great place relatively speaking. But many immigrants want to be better or aspire for more and this isn’t the most compatible theme imo. Personally, I don’t mind living in Canada. But if I become a much better asset (skill, employment options, etc), I would seriously consider defecting to the States (I’d come back here for vacation or grab some nice contract jobs here and there), but I’d say for a typical immigrant who aspire for more choices and luxuries in life… States have more to offer on avg.

I will speak for my husband and myself. In a nutshell, our only regret has been that we did not move to Canada earlier. My husband and I have had plenty of exposure to “North American living” from early childhood (raised in Boston, spent a good part of our childhood in “metropolitan” India etcetera). So, we knew exactly why we wanted to make the move; I always emphasize on the fact that we found the Indian collectivist culture self-limiting and counterproductive for personal progress. Our main goal was to thrive in a largely individualistic society, and as we complete 3 years in this country, we are seeing every bit of that happening. For folks coming from India, here are a couple harsh facts you MUST acknowledge: EDIT: This answer is generic as well as specific in parts. Some parts may be applicable to the general immigration experience, irrespective of the country of origin. Other parts apply to you if you (like me), are making a move from India to Canada. I realized I hadn’t specified this earlier, hence the hasty insert. The Indian market is not at the same level as its North American counterparts It really is not. The Indian market is essentially, an offshore buddy of the North American market. At least, for a good majority of the “IT professionals” in India. Technology, innovation, and market maturity are significantly more advanced in North America as compared to what you have in India. Also, North American universities are WAY BETTER than Indian universities in every respect. Keep in mind that university-goers in North America, for the most part, are people who are goal-driven and reasonably ambitious. Now compare that to the situation in India. A college education is a cultural “thing”, and also, perhaps the way to earning a respectable position in society. Thousands and thousands of students graduate from colleges that offer at best, sub par education. They get into an “IT role” (you will hear this phrase from literally every rooftop in India), and that sets them to think, they have acquired skillsets comparable at global level. I personally know folks who have become “managers” with a mere 5 years of professional experience. When you choose to move to a developed country, you WILL have to re-learn many things on the professional front. I have heard so often, growing up from the “older and wiser” folks around me that “Indians are smarter than the westerners”. No. They are not. NO one race is smarter than the others. There are smart people everywhere in the world, and some very smart ones are sitting perhaps, here in Canada. As an Indian looking to move out, stop thinking you are smarter than folks you have not even met. Accept that your knowledge and skills are going to need upgrade, and make plans towards it. Learn the new ways of the Canadian corporate life. It will come in handy, believe me. You might have to “accept” a role that is a level or two below the one that you were at while in your native country, accept that, and use that as an opportunity. The Indian idea of “success” is very different from the North American idea of success What do you view as signs of success in India? Typically, your marital status, your children, your monetary accumulations, your adherence to your religious beliefs, and your professional progress. In North America, it is not unusual to refer to success on the basis of one’s individual achievements; spouses, children, and religion are considered personal matters. This makes a difference to how you “view” yourself. Excessive socialization, a hallmark of the Indian society, also translates to adulation. Excessive praises vis-à-vis your home-making skills (special praise if you are a man), “showing off” your children, social gatherings with a view to “make a statement”, are not very unheard of in India. These all contribute to making you feel “accomplished”. This changes largely in North America. People no longer consider you a “success” because you are married, or you have children! I personally know men and women who are highly accomplished in their professional roles, who have very well-adjusted children, and have a number of “hobbies and passions”, and yet, have perimeters guarding their personal life. The definition of success will change when you move, from what it was in India. In a (for the most times) meritocracy, the success markers are different, and you must adapt to them! The issue of research, and honest appraisal Yes, to be able to move to a new country, a certain financial stability is essential. This is primarily to keep you afloat while you steady yourself in a new country. Depending on your profession, your early plans would change. For example, regulated professions will often require you to complete a couple credits. This will take time and money. So, you MUST rely on good research. Personal networks help, but nothing beats your own hard work. Find as many resources as you can; I remember signing up for orientation sessions provided by the Canadian government. We did that endlessly, at the risk of having to listen to the same content again. A little too cautious in hindsight, but better safe than never! While you prepare your immigration plans, look hard at your current situation (you should have done this before thinking of immigration too). Plan your finances, chalk out goals, prepare your family for the changes to come, and accept that yours will be a journey that is unique. DO NOT compare it with someone else’s; I know in our culture, comparisons are commonplace. Natural English, or not? To be able to integrate in Canada, you must be comfortable holding conversations in at least English (if you are a Francophone, then rejoice and look to QC as well). I am not speaking about IT English, which consists of typical terms and abbreviations that aren’t really a part of spoken English. To many Indians, “pop culture English” as popularized by sitcoms such as Friends and The Big Bang Theory, is being compared to “native English”. A good idea is to read books offered in natural English, and also, while in your own country, make it a habit to hold conversations in English. It is only natural for us to switch to regional languages while communicating, but truly make it a habit if you can. The reason? THAT IS the language you will be hearing and speaking all the time while in Canada. If you can hold lengthy conversations in English, you will be better able to integrate in society. You can strike friendships with people of different cultures solely on the basis of common interests, hobbies, or circumstances. THAT makes a HUGE difference to how you perceive your life to be. On that note, also make genuine attempts at getting to know people of different cultures. THAT is what being Canadian is all about. The idea that multiple cultures can get to know each other. If you make no attempts of moving out of your community circle, not many will make an attempt to get to know you, or befriend you. And then, what is the point in moving to a new country? Give yourself a few years to get rooted after transplanting Right this minute, stop reading bitter notes of how “expensive” everything is in Canada. If you compare what you purchase in a country with a stronger currency to a similar purchase in a country with a weaker currency, you will never be happy. Look around you, observe a little, and be smart. In due course of time, you will start figuring out the stores that give you the best value for money based on your needs. You will learn what works for you (monetarily) and what doesn’t. Get to know the taxing and banking systems. Make tiny savings today. Increase the savings portion when you can. Rejoice that you do not have to worry about expensive schooling for your young children. Also, the schooling standards in Canada are largely focussed on value-based learning, as opposed to grade-based learning that we see in India. It might not be the best option, but it definitely has its advantages. Do not get discouraged by stories of “never getting a timely appointment at the doctor’s”. Ask yourself this, how do people survive from life-threatening circumstances had this been this true? Lastly, enjoy every minute of the journey. But then, I hope you have the reasons for your journey right. Good luck! and oh, reach out to me if you need any pointers.

If I look back, moving to Canada was a natural choice when I was moving, and I can’t regret it. However at a stave when you want to call someplace home,that’s where you start thinking how good of a home it is for you. Well, it is dull. If you don’t have small kids to take to different activities, and if you are not into hockey or biking, it would be difficult to find a decent hobby if you are used to more cultured environment. You can learn French if you like languages. I definitely miss more intellectual people environment in the US, people who have ideas, personalities, who are happy, goal oriented, well-read, honest. I know people lie here and there. But I’ve never met so many deliberately lying people, lying in order to cover for something and just out of meanness than in Canada. I had a boss at work, and when we had a reorg he was trying to keep his position and was throwing everyone under the bus. Well, he did not get what he wanted, and eventually his new employees literally revolted against him too. But I never experienced so pure lying. Similar in other areas. I needed legal advice, and I googled several lawyers, and then retained one, but kept in touch with all. So one of them offered some services too, knowing I already had someone. They are not supposed to do that, it is against their ethics code. But that lawyer, Mr. Curran, seemingly wanted to make a buck. He bashed my retained lawyer, his firm, his work. He was telling me he will do better. He was telling me how impressive he is and how he ran for Parliament when he was young. Then the tried to make me sign papers to terminate the retained attorney, When I refused, he then emailed that attorney with lies that if I came to him to hire him. There are jokes about dishonest lawyers, but that Mr. Curran was real face of dishonesty and deceit. I always thought that educated people have some class. Not in Ottawa, not in the case of that legal professional. It’s like - no ethics at all. That was shocking and disgusting. I briefly taught at a local university, as I did in the US. US students were honest and proud of their knowledge. In Ottawa I would collect bunch of cheat sheets during exams, and there was an enormous number of doctor’s notes before midterms and finals. I had a landlord who was a slight racist and was always bashing some ethnicities. I actually thought that with free health care, not much pollution, protected environment, people should be happy, healthy and positive. But by far I’ve met too many sleazy and deceitful professionals and just individuals. But Canada is still in North America, and there are a lot of nice vacation spots in Central America and Caribbean you can visit for a good price, that’s a plus. Health care is free, but then you do pay some health tax anyway, at least in Ontario, as I know. The climate is horrible though.

Canada is good to start your career but you hit a ceiling in 5–6 years quickly and thats the end of career. Supply Chain Sector : To get a job get certified . Examples , get PMP , Six Sigma Green belt or black belt , APICS ( American Production Inventory Certified Society ) certificates like CPIM or CSCP. Job Stability in Canada is ZEROOOOOO You can get fired laid off at any time for no reason. Managers in Canada love to fire people and they love to see their teams in fear. 13 Countries in one country : Canada is 13 countries in one country. Every province has a premiere that always says no to what ever the prime minister says. Now we have a prime minister from the liberal party and the Ontario premier is conservatives . You can’t imagine the mess that's this causing but people here for some reason think that ‘s the democracy. Public Transport : Public transport in Canada is a joke. a trip from Mississauga to Brampton takes by car max 20 minutes. Via public transport it takes one and half hours you need to take at least three buses to go from a city to neighbor city . You see in Canada two bus stops on the same side platform just beside each other . One for city-1 bus and the second one is for City-2 Municipalities do that deliberately for each city to suck the max. possible amount of money from their people. That’s a very bad thing here you can imagine if your job starts at 7 AM and you live just 20 minutes away from work you need to leave at 5:45 AM to reach their on time. and on weekends there is nothing. Canadian People : Canadians are friendly in general but just bare in mind that capitalism here mad people worship money so you will find nice people but the bad people that can do anything to suck your money are in every single corner. Shooting Club : There are cities that turned into shooting clubs recently , Toronto , Scarborough those places you need to watch out if you have to live or even go there as the shooting rate is on the rise and it is getting worse. Just check the police YouTube channels and you will be shocked . the number of gangs is on the rise and the number of members of each gang is amazingly amazing. Schools : Schools in Canada : You will find public schools and private ones. try to put your kids into Catholic public schools they are the best. So here in Canada you will see teachers that can hardly speak English. and that’s a big problem . That’s in both colleges and schools. They deliberately put the signs whether in the wrong spot as a bait or they right an essay on the sign so that you will never be able to figure out quickly if you can park or not . And that generates billions of dollars to municipalities every year. You can check this video done by CBC news on parking in Canada :  Wish everybody all the best Rajeb/

Yes and no. I grew up here, so it’s home. I don’t have a home town, having grown up all over Canada, but it still (pretty much) all feels like home to me. I prefer the integration, the universal healthcare, the way Canadians interact with each other, the Canadian Rockies, and the weather—believe it or not! There’s a laundry list of things I love about Canada… so, for the most part, no. I spent most of my adult life in the US, so on the other hand, yes. I didn’t think I would—I’m more East Coast-centric—but I ended up loving LA. I loved the weather, or lack thereof. I loved that I could rent a house for one half to one-third of my after tax income. I loved having oranges and lemons dropping from the trees in my backyard (only one of the houses I lived in, but I loved the garden I planted in my last house, too). I loved being able to keep the strays I kept finding because I lived in houses, with yards, not condos—unsuitable for most dogs. I loved trying everything first—high speed internet, cable modem, VOIP, Netflix (when it was for renting DVDs and they came in the mail). I loved how cheap online shipping was, and how cheap groceries were—and access to amazing steaks, and wine and olive oil… Basically, I loved the life I created there, but I’m not sure how much of that was about living in the US. Take the weather, universal healthcare, and Canadian Rockies out of it, and I think the scale’s pretty balanced.
