I have read some of the responses on this thread and I am appalled by how some people talk about their adoptive country. No, I have never been to Canada, I don’t know if what they say is true or not. But you are talking very bad of a country that has accepted you and where you now live. I am Spanish and I lived for some time in England while doing my Masters, I actually considered staying there. I ended up not doing so mostly because of my at that time boyfriend. He did not want to move there. I also like my home country, I like the climate, I like the way of life, I liked having my family and friends nearby. So yes, I preferred Spain to England and came back. But I would never, never have spoken of England as some of you are speaking about Canada. When you are an immigrant you have to embrace the country where you are now, embrace their ways, embrace their timetables, their way of life, the people. I did that in London and was perfectly content. If you don’t do that, if you are not willing to do that, just pack your bags and go back to your home country if you like it so much better there. That is what I think some of you should do. If you don’t like it, then get out of there, I’m pretty sure Canadians will be very happy to see you go. I know Spain isn’t perfect, I am very capable of seeing our own faults and what we have to make better. But oh dear me, if you were talking about my country in such a way, I would be the first to show you the door. I don’t want anybody here that doesn’t like it here and is talking crap about my country. I have several friends who are immigrants here, a couple from United States, two girls from Denmark, an English young man. They have completely integrated, they love practising their Spanish, they enjoy the weather, will try out any new food. It is a joy to see someone from outside accept and appreciate your culture and land. And no, they aren’t forgetting theirs, they teach it to us, we are learning so much. We had a danish Xmas party with danish food, so much fun. Being an immigrant is being able to appreciate, to accept and to integrate without necessarily losing your own identity, you just add to it. Seriously, if you think that bad of a country, leave it. It isn’t worth it living that sad or miserable, go to where you can feel happy with what is around you. I feel pity for some of the people in the comments, they seem to be having such a hard time, they seem so close to depression. Do something about it. Leave, find another country that is better suited to your likes, there is nothing wrong with that, not everybody likes something and not everything is adequate for everybody.

YES! I have and still do. I am of Turkish descent and was born and raised in Germany. I have lived in Turkey for about 12 years of my life and moved to Canada as a skilled immigrant in 2010. The most important question you have to ask yourself is: What do I want in life?If your answers are: Financial freedom, great career/income, adequate housing, good weather - then CANADA is not your destination. My experience of Canada is quite limited to Vancouver BC. And to some extent Toronto ON. As you might know, these are the two major immigrant clusters in Canada. Finding a good job/career with a good income is almost impossible if you don’t have Canadian credentials (it’s even hard with Canadian credentials). Housing is terrible. You will be stuck in a 1 bedroom apartment that is extremely overpriced and pay at least $1600/month for nothing. You will share a washer and dryer with all the other tenants in your building. Apartments neither have the room nor the facilities to hook up a washer and dryer in your own place. If you want to have ‘the luxury’ of being able to do laundry at home, your rent automatically goes above and beyond $2000 easily (still a 1 bedroom apt though)! I don’t even want to get started on BUYING a house or an apartment. That’s impossible! Please refer to http://vancouver.craigslist.ca and check out the apartments and rentals ads. SOLUTION: Go to college/university and get a new in demand career!ANSWER: GOOD LUCK! Now that you’ve immigrated here and are a resident, most in demand programs will put you on a waiting list for up to 3 years. Let’s say you were lucky and got in - who is going to pay for tuition, fees, expenses, rent etc? Education is not free in Canada, and books are around $100–250 for each course. You must be available during the day because there are no night or evening universities here. Your BARE minimum monthly expenses as a single person here will be around $2600 (not including tuition fees and other school expenses etc). Edit: BCIT in Vancouver has part-time evening courses but unfortunately course availability is not guaranteed and they cost more or the classical waiting list issue. HEALTH: Family doctors/general practitioners are readily available and you should be able to get an appointment in 48 hours. BUT if you need to see a specialist then things change. I once had to wait 3 months (not exaggerating!) to see a dermatologist. And when I saw him, he asked me to go and purchase the medicine and come back to have it injected by him again. And the next best appointment available was in 3 weeks. The same goes for cardiology, and it perhaps even worse. WEATHER: Vancouver summers are amazing! 4–5 months of very comfortable and beautiful weather. But for the rest of the year: it’s raining all the time, it’s damp, it’s overcast, it’s cold. And this is the BEST weather you can get in Canada. Other provinces are -20 C. FRIENDS/PEOPLE/NETWORKING: People are superficially friendly. Everyone will say hi, smile, ‘excuse me’s en mass. But when you really want to become friends with someone, they withdraw from you. ‘Real’ Canadians don’t like to be bothered - and most Canadians will regard a new friend as a bother. They’d be way happier to sit at home and watch Netflix and have a glass of wine, beer than meeting up with friends for some socializing. Dating is horrible too! I don’t even want to talk about it. EDIT: Please read this article on alcohol consumption in Canada published by a Canadian newspaper: Canada ranks third in the world for drunkenness (and 20% know they need help): report RESULT:So, if you’re really coming from a bad place/country etc. Yes, Canada might be an option. It’s definitely better to be in Canada than in a war torn zone or such.But if your goals are financial freedom, great career/income, adequate housing, good weather - then CANADA is not your destination.I suggest the USA, Germany, Switzerland to some extent, Ireland (especially if you’re in IT/Software). I hope this helps. PS: This is a VERY long article which I find very significant on Canada & Immigration. Why is Canada taking immigrants when there are no opportunities? Answered by Thomas Edward Friedrich

In short,”Yes”. I came to Canada as a student in December 2019, and I regret it till today. The main reasons are - Extremely rude weather. Incredibly harsh especially in Toronto where I live. Although it is not as cold as Winnipeg, but still snowstorm and slippery roads during winter exists. And having to go out for work in that situation is a nightmare. A car is extremely needed which brings me to the second point.Both cars and insurance is expensive compared to US. If someone is a new driver, the insurance costs go up like crazy that most of the times it is impossible for a working student to handle. There are public transports which brings me to third point.Even the public transport is not an affordable option either. There are some discounts for the students but still I needed to pay 128.50 CAD every month for that which is 150+ CAD for a regular adult. I used TTC and let me tell you, it was the worst possible experience for me. The buses are never on time, rude staff and problems with hygiene. The buses bumps frequently while on road. I got frequent nausea riding on that. The trains don’t maintain a schedule. Sometimes it stops on the middle for maintenance purpose and sometimes I waited even an hour to go somewhere. Crazy expense on top of horrible service. What else is needed?The price shown the label is never the real price. 13% tax is added in everything you buy in Toronto. The products are not cheap either even before adding the taxes. Food along with grocery is expensive. Eating out is a quite big deal.Racism exists. But nobody says. Everyone lies about this fact. In Canada, you need to learn how to read people’s mind. Because if they don’t like you, they will never say that on your face. They might say they like you. But what they say does not mean they mean it.Education quality is average compared to the tuition rate. Sometimes the professors are not helpful either. Sometimes no fair marking is noticed plus extreme workload which is not that necessary all the time.(Own opinion)Finding a job without reference is extremely stressful and time consuming.People can be really rude. I have seen so many people here are struggling with their lives to earn money in order to support themselves and their families. So, most of the times they don’t care about anyone else which can be quite selfish.These are some of the reasons I regret moving to Canada. These are all my personal experience and thought about the city. There can be mistakes. But if someone has any opinion in this, don’t hesitate to let me know.

Where should I start with this question? One thing that my dad mentioned when I moved to Canada was Success and Regret comes in stages. It goes on like Denial, Pain, Anger, Depression, Acceptance, and finally Rebuilding. It takes time to progress through each stage, it could take days or even years. Denial: The first time when I landed at Toronto’s Pearson Airport. I realized one thing, everything here has a relatively higher cost compared to India. Starting of with Transportation to a phone plans. The cost of a cab to your apartment or university could easily set you back $70 and similar is the cost of phone plans. I remember at that time my mind rushed at comparing the cost of the cab ride to my entire flight cost and it was 10% of it. Crazy right. You begin to question why did I move here and start comparing your life back home. But you quickly get over this phase if you accept the new realities of life, leaving things behind you and walking towards a better tomorrow. Pain: After denial fades away, then comes Pain. Depending on your personnel levels it may or may not leave you with injured pride and bruised ego, but trust me it was for your betterment. At 18 years, your mind is filled with pride of proving yourself as right and others as wrong. Even the smallest thing like getting groceries from the supermarket in bitter Canadian winter might teach you lessons in life of humility and gratitude which one never shows living with their parents. The long working hours that one needs to go through to meet rent and fees payment. Seeing your bank account fill up and then go back to almost empty, Ohh boy it hurt. Rent being $1100 and school fees for students don't even bother asking. Sometimes, mind wanders off thinking what could I have done with all this much money if I did not have to pay all these fees. But as Jeetu bhai from one of my favourite TV shows “Kota Factory ” said: “21 din mai sab theek hoon jayega” loosely translated too “In 21 days everything will become alright”. Anger: Once these two stages are done, then comes anger. Anger being the worst as you sometimes lose control of yourself and might hurt family & friends. Luckily, I did not go through this a lot as I had some support of my family members. Mom being my guardian angel, screening me from all the unwanted negativities of life. I remember first Semester marks were out and UofT being UofT left just disappointment in me when I scored 80s in some subjects. Some people reading now will start judging me but keep in mind I was the best at my school and I had fallen from the status of Titans to straight-up being average. At that time I remember my Mom words in a genuine voice with happiness on her face “Proud of you” . It changed everything, she was happy for me even when I was angry at myself. At that point in life I started improving myself term after term, focussing on myself and not comparing my self with others success or failure. Depression: You basically need someone to fall back on, at this time. It gets difficult, you might not find your ideal job or might struggle even finding one. Life is going to be this way, so get up and don’t give up. In the summer of first year, I applied to almost 20 jobs and did not even get a response from a single one. Those were some difficult times, that molded me, made me address my weaknesses. Think of it as a vacation you always wanted to learn something you couldn’t have otherwise. Even if that seems hard, go for a walk, buy yourself some Tims and call it a day. Remember the quote “The good and the bad times will not last”. Acceptance: Reflect on what you have achieved this far and be grateful. This city is going to break your heart, but you need to accept the fact that you might not be the best at performing the job. Someone better has gotten the job and be thankful. I remember the first summer working at improving myself paid off, the very next summer I had gotten a Research scholarship for 4 months. Although the money was not too much, it was probably the happiest day of my life. My first paycheck and the Raymond advertisement started playing in my head-Mom is going to be soo proud. Rebuilding: The final phase, this is the happy times, all the bad times have now been gone. Days became years and now I realize how far I have come. I got my first internship at a company close to my home, so minimal expenses. Felt I needed to improve my health, soo joined a gym - Lost 20lbs. Had a lot more time in my life and the world seemed to go my way. All this time my paycheck started getting bigger but the happiness on my Mom's face was paramount when I got my first paycheck. So do I regret coming to Canada, Absolutely not. This country has taught me soo much, appreciation peoples work no matter what they do. Becoming close to my family even if we were sometimes miles apart. Oh, and did I happen to mention to mention my Mom’s reaction when seeing my first paycheck. Not sure I would have had such a great rollercoaster journey

Yes surely. When i was 28 I immigrated to Canada. At the time it was ok. There was nothing like a PR card that requires that you have to stay 2 out of 5 years in Canada. As time went on, my business focus became more global and at times I had a hard time managing to be 2 years in Canada out of those 5 years. As time goes on, goals and circumstances change. and of course you will compare how other countries mainly your country of origin measures up to Canada. Canada has a lot of advantages, but over time , as this PR card rule was created, I felt more like in a prison than in a free country. When iI immigrated there were no such rules. Now i am 60 years old and many of my family as well as the family of my wife get older by the day. Some have dies and required care before cancer killed them. In case of my mother in law, me and my wife had to care for her for about 1 year before she passed away. Since she lives in China, I could not be for that time in Canada. Next my father died and so on. As you get older your family will older too. That is a thing i ever really thought about. Never thought that will have to care for your mother or mother in law or other close friends or relatives. Thinking about my own health and how people are looked after in Canada if they get old scares me. I live in New Brunswick. Sure not the richest province, but that some older fellows there have to chose to heat their house or to buy their medicine and heat the house, that is a thought that does not sit well with me. Bad enough that the weather there is not really a blessing for older folks, but the idea that they have to chose to freeze or get food and medicine is just not a bright side of Canada. Sure, as long you are young , you do not care too much about these things, but they will sooner or later catch up with you. Health care and support for the older folks is compared to Western Europe i.e Scandinavia or Germany, France etc . substandard. Waiting times for ie. a hip or knee replacement of about 2.5 years in New Brunswick, that is scary. Of course with enough cash at hand you could go to the US to get what ever medical care you need, but most of the people in our province do not have that option. I do no think that this is limited to New Brunswick only. Well, it depends where you come from. If Middle East or Africa, or even the Philippines is your country of origin, then Canada looks like a great country and you would no have much regrets. If you come from some West European country and see what support they offer old people or health care, vacation days etc. , Canada does not really look that great and surely not if you get older. One other factor is that one should consider the family abroad. The older you get the more you will have to travel to them. Attend funeral, cancer care until the pass away and many things more. At some point you surely will ask yourself if that step to immigrate to Canada or any other country was worth it. I mean not necessarily from a financial point, but the years you were away from your family never will come back and that is a high price to pay.

I moved to Ottawa, Canada, from Guyana, South America, over ten years ago, to join my Canadian husband and do not regret it in the least; though there are some things in Canada I will never get used to.Canada has several positives which for me exceed most other countries (certainly those that I have personally visited). First is safety. As a woman I feel comfortable walking in any neighbourhood in any city at any time of day or night, In Guyana and in the American and European cities I've visited, I did not feel the same. Second is tolerance and lack of prejudice. I do not feel any systemic prejudice in Canada despite what leftwing social justice warriors may try to paint in the media, nor have I ever encountered any prejudice or sexism in my daily life. Men here are respectful of women, (almost too respectful), and people here seem totally colour blind when it comes to race. Canadians also take pride in their multiculturalism and are genuinely interested in learning about and sharing your culture, foods, and traditions. In Canada cultures lives peacefully together and mix much more comfortably than what I've observed in other countries such as the US or Europe. Thirdly, Canada is an amazingly beautiful country, especially in summer, and with a car you can visit almost any corner of the country if you don't mind the long distances. The change of seasons never cease to amaze me, and Ottawa, in my opinion, is one of the most beautiful cities in Canada and the world. What especially amazes me is that in Canada due to the size of the country and low population you can enjoy nature in complete solitude. You can drive to isolated lakes in a very short time and have the entire lake to yourself, or hike a trail in a forest without seeing another person, or be the only tourist in a town or gallery. And everywhere in Canada, even in the big cities, the water and the air is super clean. (I've never understood why some Canadians still insist on buying bottled water). Everywhere else in the world seems so busy and crowded and polluted.That being said, some of the earlier posts do make some valid points. Canada can be expensive compared to some countries, but is also less expensive compared to others. It depends where you are coming from and what lifestyle you are used to. You need to do your research and accept that you will probably start working at a lower status here in Canada than what you were in your home country until you've achieved Canadian experience and certificate and educational equivalencies. It is also true that it is harder making friends in Canada because out of politeness, Canadians tend to give space and be more reserved. However, if you take the initiative and open up to them, they will quickly reciprocate and become the best friends you've ever had. Strangers will always be willing to help, all you need to do is ask, unlike encounters I've found in other countries. I don't understand the comments about health care from other posters. I can get appointments with my doctor very quickly and have never had to wait more than 45 minutes at a clinic or hospital emergency. I guess it all depends on personal experience and where in Canada you live. It is nice to know that you can seek medical help without paying for it. However, it is true that Canada's medical system does not pay for dental or prescriptions so it is wise to get health insurance from work for these things.Opportunity is what you make of it. Canada offers hugely better opportunities than Guyana, but like in every country, it requires hard work and good education. While other countries like the US may have more opportunity to get rich, in Canada, it is easy to be comfortably middle class, which is where the bulk of the population sits. The great thing about Canada, because of the free health care, low cost post secondary education, safety, and quality of life, being middle class in this country is very enjoyable. Many middle class Canadians have summer cottages and travel south on vacation in the winter. Note that I speak from my experience here in Ottawa, a medium sized city surrounded by hundreds of lakes. Rents and house prices in Toronto and Vancouver are ridiculously expensive and owning a cottage is out of reach for most middle class Canadians in these cities. But if you settle in smaller cities and towns away from these metropolitan areas, Canada is still relatively affordable. Unfortunately most immigrants always gravitate towards either Toronto or Vancouver.Winter, the one thing about Canada I find hard. It is very cold and very long, and in Ottawa we get a lot of snow. You can choose to hibernate and stay indoors as much as possible, or you can embrace it by learning the many winter sports they have in Canada. I have learned to skate and ski and like both, but I admit that on days with -40C wind chill, I tend to just stay indoors and dream of the warmth of Guyana.

Immigrating to Canada is not for everyone. I immigrated with my family 20 years ago. Since that time, I have been working with immigrants in some form or another. I wrote a book - Arrival Survival Canada - a handbook for immigrants, it was published by Oxford University Press and became a bestseller. I launched a magazine Canadian Immigrant and sold it to the Toronto Star. Subsequently, oversaw the launch of the Toronto Edition and creation of the Top 25 Canadian Immigrant Awards. I left in 2010 to form Prepare for Canada focusing on helping newcomers before they leave their home countries. I have also written Welcome to Canada - the official handbook given by the Federal Government to newcomers. Lastly, I have been an adviser to the Federal Government on immigration and chaired a panel on immigrant employment challenges. And I have spoken to thousands of immigrants across Canada. In Vancouver, Prince George, Nanaimo, Fort MacMurray, Medicine Hat, Saskatoon, Halifax, Montreal, Toronto, Ottawa and many more. People immigrate for many reasons. The first one is passive immigration - parents migrate and kids don’t have a choice. Several years later, you either love it - as my kids do, or go back. Again, personal choices do not set the tone for others in a similar situation. Second is political which forces people to seek refuge elsewhere for threat of life and so we have refugees. I have met many including a Governor General (Adrienne Clarkson) who have made a great life in Canada contributing socially and economically. The third is the family reunification - spouses and grandparents. Lastly it is the skilled worker category. I have met thousands who have succeeded and a few who have not. The point system today favors a younger immigrant fluent in English or French. Why then do some fail? Here’s what I have learned in my years: Language fluency in ESL is not enough. Based on your profession, you may need occupation specific language training. Or training in business English. Canada does give you all the opportunities, but you do need to always keep adding skills to help you get ahead.Many immigrants who fail live in two countries. Their country of birth and Canada. And they keep making comparisons that grow until you make yourself miserable. You miss the food, friends even relatives :) and spend hours on WhatsApp chatting and making yourself miserable! This leads to the BMW factor. BMW means Bitch(complain), Moan and Whine. You will find yourself surrounded by people who will be negative and keep complaining. If you cannot maintain a balance, burn your bridges if you want to succeed. Or……..go back, but remember it is because you couldn’t handle the change. That is certainly not the fault of Canada.Be an active newcomer. While positivity is very important and will stand you in good stead in all those days of despair, you also have to actively embrace your adopted country. Get involved, volunteer, go to the library, make friends and celebrate all it means to be a Canadian! Find a mentor and learn from him/her!Coming back to my first sentence. Immigrating to Canada is not for everyone. Notice I have highlighted the word you in my points above. It is about you. And your ability to make it. To succeed, To contribute. Or to fail. Become another BMW. I have resisted the impulse to talk about the success stories of many Canadian immigrants (including Elon Musk!) because that is irrelevant. This is about you. Taking the chances on the opportunities this country offers you. And making something of it. Use the three point system and I can pretty much guarantee success.

I am seeing some misleading stuff here so just wanted to point out it IS NOT -15C for 3 months everywhere in Canada. I am in Nova Scotia and we just had two consecutive night time lows of -15C . We are bitching, crying and just bearing it until temp goes up Friday to 0C. We handle 0 to -5C ok. I havent had to shovel once this year because there hasn't been enough snow. Not saying this is the norm but it varies here year to year. Some years we are getting a foot of snow at a time. It pretty much depends where the Gulf Stream and Polar Vortex is. We get wicked storms here year around but uf you are a weather watcher, its an interesting climate to live in. Lasr summer was a killer. We went about 2 months with a close to 40C humidex. That was way harder for us to adjust to than the cold. Many don't have air conditioners here because of the breezy marine climate so it became a health hazard. I guess extreme weather is the new normal and we are having to adjust to that. We do have 4 seasons here still. I dont go out during bad winter days. Im fortunate to have a flexible work arrangement and telecommute if its snowing. Canada is very accommodating to those with disabilities too so Ive been working from home in my PJs the last two months as I recover from a complicated surgery. I went to the doc today, had an x-ray, picked up about $200 worth of meds (that prolly would have cost $1000 in the US) and paid $0.00. I dont have a University degree but still make more than many with one. My understanding is that changes are being made to accepting more foreign credentials but the wheels of Canadian policy move slowly. VERY slowly. FYI - A lot of companies will take volunteer experience as Canadian experience. In the interim, if you are willing to make some sacrifices, take some low paying jobs, network and volunteer to get your foot in the door you can move ahead but NOT by staying with the same company. You have to job hop. If you are in a job more than 3 years you are content to settle there. “Working your way up the ladder” no longer exists regardless what companies say. To get “promoted” is almost unheard of. You literally have to apply for other jobs to get ahead . I hope that helps some Canadian newbies.

I am a Canadian citizen and have been residing in Canada for the last 15 years. I first arrived on a study permit ( easily granted even 15 years ago- considering now it is much easier with all these SD streams). Anyway, back then , life was difficult for an International Student, we had not work permits and no off campus jobs to support ourselves, We basically spent our parents’ hard earned money. And above all here were no PR opportunities for graduate such as the PNPs and the CEC. We just studied and went back home. Only some of us who could gather up the 67 points because we had work experience could apply for PR and even then it would take years to get the visa. Luckily I got mine in less than 2 years. I moved here permanently and I should say that I have always been in Vancouver ( apart from one year that I spent in Toronto to test the employment opportunities and one year that I spent in Calgary much recently for same reasons) . I didn’t mind the weather as much in these two cities as much as the other factors. People often complain about hardships of moving to Canada. Well, to them I want to ask, Why do you move to Canada at all and if the answer isn’t that you are facing hardships in your own country then perhaps you are better off there. Regardless of where you move, you will face some difficulty and hard ships if you step out of your comfort zone. Try doing that just in your country for example: try moving from Delhi to Mumbai and see for yourself or vice versa. Canada is a beautiful and hospitable country and although I do feel bad for people who are tricked into by the fake consultants and so called Education Advisers, I do blame it on the individual for their poor research and preparation. After all, it is YOU who is moving so it is your job to make preparations. Canada offers amazing settlement programs to the youth and international immigrants. They may or may not suit your need but the country does provide the services. And in terms of your particular experience, drugs, alcohol are not non existent in India, whether someone has witnessed it being so openly practiced on not is a different thing. In the end, I just want to say don’t blame Canada for your hardships. You are the decision maker and you decided to come here for an experience. Well you got your experience based on how you planned it. So the lesson is to make god preparations and research. Ottawa is a lovely place and like someone mentioned why does one feel the need to get concentrated in big citizen, Canada is huge and has lots to offer. I highly suggest trying smaller cities if your luck isn’t working out in the metropolitan areas. But don’t blame the country for your problems. It has welcomed you and I think if you regret the decision to come to Canada simply because you found it hard to adjust, maybe you were not designed to be adventurous. I do not mean to offend you by my response but having come to Canada as a student only to return back after having spent considerable amount of money and then just landing as a PR later , I believe I have a better perspective of both worlds. Good luck to you for your endeavors.

Hi, Nope, I don’t regret. I am happy that I moved to Canada. I read some answers on this and other questions - and found that some people regret it. I don’t get it. I have lived here for four years now and I would not live anywhere else in the world except India. If you move to Canada from another country (what I did) - you cannot expect things to be the same or easy. That is not at all a realistic expectation. You cannot expect the weather to be the same. You cannot expect your money to hold the same value compared to CAD. You made the decision. You decided to come here. Why regret?Don’t like something? Change it or change yourself. If you are stuck at a dead-end job, get-out! Get some education, find different opportunities, do what you love, find ways to get there. It doesn’t happen overnight. Figure out! Find a way! If you feel home-sick, make friends here, go out and do an activity that you like - I’m sure you will make new friends. And don’t put your happiness in someone else or something else. Be happy for who you are and what you are and where you are. And if you are not happy, do something to change that. IT IS expensive - of course - but you are probably living in Toronto or Vancouver - top 10 cities of the world, do you expect it to be the same or cheaper compared to a small town/village? The weather - don’t like cold much? Get a good winter coat! Not making it big? - I genuinely think that if a person wants to make it big like earn a million dollar or become an astrophysicist - they can do it no matter their finances or situation. Satisfaction and peace are based on how much reward you get out of something (e.g. a job). If you are not satisfied, change something. If you will keep on doing the same thing over and over, you will get the same results over and over. You can find positive and negative points on any subject matter. You decide how you want to perceive a topic and what emotion you associate with it. Maybe read this book: “MIND OVER MOOD: CHANGE HOW YOU FEEL BY CHANGING THE WAY YOU THINK” by Dennis Greenberger, Christine A. Padesky I hope this answered helped you. If you are struggling in life in Canada, don’t worry, I believe in you. I believe you will find success but it doesn’t happen overnight. Cheers. _FF

This is a complicated question for me to answer. I was born in Kyrgyzstan, a central Asian country. At the moment, while it is much less developed than Canada, its economy is doing very well; you can see this based on the changes in the country. There’s a huge baby boom, new buildings are replacing crumbling ones from the days of the Soviet Union, and there is now a growing expatriate community. But when my family moved away, it was October 2004. I was just 17 months old. While I myself had no say in moving away, I can definitely comment on whether I think we should have done so or not.  Beginning from the woman in the pink at the top left and going clockwise; my aunt, my great-grandmother, my grandmother, my father, me, and my mother. Above is the last photo we took in Kyrgyzstan. I am sitting in my mother’s lap, just 17 months old. My mother and father were 24. My aunt was 20. My grandmother was 43. And my great-grandmother was 67. A lot has changed since then. It was just me and my parents who left. Leaving Kyrgyzstan meant leaving behind my mother’s side of the family (my father’s family lived in Afghanistan), and moving to a place where neither of my parents could speak the language. We had no immediate family in Canada to help us settle and learn English. It was difficult at the start. Why did we move? In 2004, Kyrgyzstan was not a good place to live in. The government, led by our former President Askar Akayev, continued to clamp down on human rights, and there were reports of opposition members being tortured. Jobs were hard to find and crime was rampant. Just next year, a bomb would go off in the home of the opposition leader, Roza Otunbayeva, sparking the Tulip Revolution (which I wrote about here) led by her and Kurmanbek Bakiyev. Bakiyev became our next president as Akayev left in a bloodless revolution. While that revolution was peaceful, in 2010, another one would happen. Bakiyev was worse than Akiyev. He killed opposition members and hoarded wealth for himself as rural areas became lawless. Kyrgyzstan became lawless and violent for a few weeks until Bakiyev finally resigned. My great-grandmother was held hostage by criminals in the anarchy. Roza Otunbayeva became the interim president and changed the constitution to weaken the presidential powers. From here on, Kyrgyzstan has been rapidly developing.  Above is the first photo taken of me in Canada. I am with my mother and some family friends in Toronto, where we stayed before settling in a small town three hours southwest called Exeter. The Canadian government accepted many Afghan immigrants and refugees in 2004. Kyrgyzstan has a close-knit Afghan community in the capital, Bishkek, that fled the war. My father applied to Canada and was granted asylum alongside his family; us. We personally know many other Afghans who originally lived in Kyrgyzstan here in Canada, including a few that came on the same plane as us. We first landed in Alberta, where we were vetted and my parents had a type of course on what is socially acceptable in Canada and what is not. We moved to my current city, London, in 2006, and I have grown up in Canada’s Forest City since then. (London in Ontario! Not in the United Kingdom! Though we do have a Thames River and Oxford Street here too…) Now, what do I think of moving to Canada? As I said at the start, it’s complicated. But it’s definitely more positive than negative. The negative parts are related to finances and my own opinions on assimilating to Canadian culture. I know the weather and social attitudes of Kyrgyzstan, and I like it better in Canada. I love the weather here. Financially, it is as simple as this - my mother studied for five years and got the Kyrgyz equivalent of a Master’s Degree in Criminology. It was not accepted in Canada. My father only finished high school (and later, college in Canada). In Kyrgyzstan, he was training to become a teacher, but was unable to finish this here. There, both of my parents would have had better jobs than in Canada. The average salary may be low in Kyrgyzstan, but so is the cost of living. Overall, we would be more comfortable there. As for in Canadian culture, I don’t feel that much at home with it. In Canada, assimilation is much less heavily encouraged than in the United States, but it still happens. I have two brothers born in Canada. They feel zero connection to any culture that is not Canadian, even if my parents tried to teach them Russian and Dari (Afghan Persian) and how to follow our cultural customs, they hate them. Why, I cannot know. This makes me sad because it feels like we are already losing our connection to our home, and that I will be the only one to pass it on - and after me, will my children?  The above photos are of me on my first day of school, with my mother and father, in September 2007. I hated it. I didn’t speak English and missed my parents. But I got used to it. I went to school in the Canadian education system and I definitely keep parts of Canadian culture. I love the multiculturalism in this country. I do apologise for much more than people in most other countries do. And I grew up watching Toopy & Binoo, even if I didn’t understand it for a long time! But, I do not like calling myself Canadian in much more than nationality. It feels very wrong. My spoken English is not that good, and I do not feel that close to the Canadian national identity, even if I have tried to. I am culturally Afghan, Canadian, and Russian at the same time. I may not be ethnically Kyrgyz, like nearly 30% of Kyrgyzstan, but I also still feel Kyrgyzstani. My mother also grew up in a very ethnically diverse part of the Soviet Union, so some of her traditions are Kyrgyz or Kazakh in origin, and not Russian. I feel like in Kyrgyzstan there would be more people I would find easier to become friends with. I would have a shared culture, and in many cases, a shared religion. Canada is only 4% Muslim, and the vast majority of the Muslims here are Arabs, who practice Islam a lot differently than in Kyrgyzstan (which is 88% Muslim). That’s one easy way to portray the situation. As for the good? Almost everything else. Canada has cleaner water. Canada has better universities. Canada has less corruption. Canada has less murders and rape. I like Canadian weather. I like how Canada is more accepting to LGBT2Q+ people. I like how the Canadian government is more stable. So, my opinions on moving are overall positive. It is likely that we would be doing better economically in Kyrgyzstan, where my mother would be able to have a very good job, my father could continue teaching, and we would have family and friends that would help us if anything were to happen financially. But in Kyrgyzstan I wouldn’t have learned English. For a long time, my safety could have been in jeopardy. I would still be less safe there. In Canada, there is also more economic stability, as Kyrgyzstan is still a developing country. Altogether, I am happy to live in Canada. While I may not perfectly fit in here, I do not hold anything against my parents for moving here. They gave tons of effort into learning English once here. They sacrificed money and family to give me and my brothers a better future. And for that I am grateful. Thank you, Gucci Fu, for the request. I enjoyed answering this question.

TLDR: I do not regret at all. Here to stay. I have arrived one and half years from now. Coming from Paris. My situation: I was bored of my previous life, was really stressed about it (the labour market is overwhelming in Paris, you just hold on a job you hate because you’re too scared of losing it and be unemployed for months), and personally grew really upset about this French self-absorbed mentality which is very Parisian. I used to have a job, my own place, friends, family. I was the singer of a band that released an album the year before I left. I quit everything, for some adventure. I chose Winnipeg, the perfect mix of city/country. It is a 700k population city, capital of Manitoba and in the very middle of Canada, located in the Prairies. On arrival I was shocked (literally) by the kindness of the people living here, by the easiness of the first steps in order to settle down. Found a place to live in 1 day, found a job in 2 weeks. Yes, career-wise you start at the bottom. Here, they don’t even look at your diplomas. Work experience, soft skills, and, possibly references are the only things that matter. So I started in a call centre with my strong French accent. But that’s what I expected. That’s what I wanted. And something happened that never did in my entire life before: after some months I was offered a promotion and eventually got it. I was rewarded for my hard work, my skills and my motivation. And again, I did not even apply for it, I was offered this position. Very different from anything that I had known. On the other side, I have to face it: I lost my friends. I’m still really close to the closest one I had; but to be honest I barely talk to 5% of the people I used to. And making new friends here is harder than I thought. Don’t get me wrong, Canadians are VERY friendly. You can stumble upon random people and they start to chat with you. In the street, on the bus... However, this is the first layer, and I found it’s actually hard to create real bonds, even with people you usually hang out with. I am currently in my permanent residency application, and I expect to have it in the following year. For now, there is no question: I’m here to stay.

NO. Not at all. At least until now. I moved to Canada 9 months back and so far I am enjoying my time here. The points below are based on a couple of things: I am in Montreal and this is my first time outside my home country. It’s a beautiful place: Here I am not comparing it to any European country or any other place since I haven't been there. It’s just an incomparable thought. There are few pics at the end of the answer that I clicked and found it beautiful.Welcoming people: As I mentioned, I am in Montreal where French is the dominant language and me and my wife don't even know a single word of French. We are from a completely different culture so lacks basic Montreal (or Westerners) etiquette. Still, we never felt any sort of discrimination. Many of my colleagues from Montreal are quite fascinated towards my home country as well and ask many questions to know about the culture whenever they get a chance.Work-life balance: While I was working in my home country, I somehow was not able to manage my work-life balance and rarely get time to spend with my family. After moving here, its much more sorted. One of the reasons is the work culture here, where your timings are fixed and you are not expected to stay longer than that.Transportation: I think Montreal has one of the best public transportation facilities in Canada. It’s way better than the city I was living in my home country.Free healthcare: Canada offers free healthcare services. I used it a couple of times and the experience was quite good. There are walk-in clinics and emergency rooms for urgent needs. There is a possibility of appointing a family doctor for free but the wait time for that is quite long.There are some things which are hard for many (as I found out in many answers below) : Harsh Winters: Winters are really harsh. I read a lot about it before coming here and one of my first tasks after coming here to prepare myself for it by getting good winter clothing, sturdy snow shoes, caps etc. I survived one winter with these preparations and I think I would be able to survive the next. Expensive: I don't agree, it's expensive here (at least in Montreal). You just don't need to convert everything into your local currency. When I came here, for the first 2 months, I was converting everything to my local currency and that gave me a mini heart-attack. Somehow, I realized it and now I think the cost of living is pretty okay. So far I am enjoying my stay here. There were certain instances, where I found a few things that were not good or not up to my expectations, but I tried giving them another chance with a different perspective and so far that worked. Come with an open mind and you can enjoy anywhere in the world. As mentioned above, a few pics of Montreal, Quebec - Canada.

Long post alert. There were edits made after few comments from my friends in Canada to add more details. This makes this extreme long post from long post. This is not to discourage people from moving to Canada but to rather help them take right factors in consideration. Yes, I regret moving to Canada. I moved from India’s most happening city ‘Hyderabad’ from one of the Big4 firms. That being said, neither am I a high flier nor someone who draws high/exorbitant salaries (upwards of 1 lakh per month). Unlike many, I did not spend a fortune to come here or spend dizzying amounts of my savings. Yes, I did spend significant portion of my savings, it is not just that high when I compare it to my peers who moved here with their families and are still trying to get a job. Did I not get a job here and is that the reason why I regret? No- I did get a decent paying job in my area of expertise within 3 months. No qualms here. It is just good networking/ referrals/ family friends who helped me get a job. Was I not able to accommodate to the culture/ are people not good enough? People here are extremely friendly. My friend who I knew from India who got a job here before I came to Canada was more worried about me that I was not getting a job. My friend’s brother’s best friend’s wife helped me get the job. Let that sink in. I was that lucky to have such a great friend and such lovely people here. I cannot thank them enough. They are like my extended family now. Why do I regret? When I was researching if I have to move to Canada, I considered a few points to make the move. Free healthcare: I thought free healthcare, eh, how many countries in the world would do that? My research was wrong. As cool as it may sound, it is very slow. I had to wait for a week to get an appointment for an ultrasound scan for my wife because she is suffering from stomach ache. God knows what would happen if the cause is diagnosed after some damage already happened. If I was in India it would have been done in a few hours. The cost even if I would have to bear it will be very small. Doctor visit in a walk-in-clinic+ Ultrasound+other tests+ medicines would have cost me at the most 3000 INR (60 CAD). Just FYI: The cost of a colonoscopy in Asian Institute of Gastroenterology (the most famous hospital) where even Prime Minister of India had his surgery costed me INR 2000 (40 CAD). I was covered by my company back home for 5 lakhs per annum. Not just me, my wife, my parents and my future kids. Now 5 lakhs is only $10k. However, in India, any major surgery can be completed within 2 or 3 lakhs in a upscale hospital. My uncle had a heart attack and the total cost of 2 stents to be implanted in his heart was 3 lakhs. My parents now are not covered by insurance in India. I will have to buy them an insurance plan. If someone is coming from India and one of his considerations is free healthcare, think again- You are coming from a country to which even citizens from developed nations (mostly USA) go for low cost healthcare services. Education for kids Many studies placed Canadian schooling as the 2nd or 3rd best in the world. I thought it would be a great opportunity for my future kids. I was wrong in my assessment. I misread the report. The studies consider public schooling system in the country for the rating. Yes, the public schooling system in India is pathetic. Do I really want my kids to join a public school in India? No.I would have had them joined in a decent private school. The education if not on par would at least still be on par with Canadian public school. If you are coming to Canada considering this as a factor and you make good money back in India, think again- Private schools are really good in India too. Rents: Who are we kidding? The rents are sky high. I knew that before coming here. However, I did not know that even to get a unit when someone is willing to pay the rent, it is never easy. I applied for 8 condo units and 5 apartment units, all of which rejected my application since there were more than 5 people who were bidding for the units and the house owner had a choice to pick from. The apartments buildings had a waiting list. I am talking about some decently maintained apartment units like the Morguard ones. Now two of my friends got a place relatively fast forcing me to think again- if I am unlucky or considered moving during wrong time or if he is lucky. I was trying to get answer to this question when another friend of mine mentioned me that searching for rent is like mini-job search here. You will need to put in as much effort as job search. My search for job drained my energy. Right now, I am not ready for another round of energy drain. I ultimately made peace with staying in a basement with my wife. Canada has a housing crisis and most are not ready to admit it. Think again. People: This is very specific to me. However, just jotting it down because there might be someone like me. I am someone who would draw energy seeing people. Imagine the number of people at midnight in Hyderabad and the traffic. Now, the so called most densely populated Greater Toronto Area (GTA) during the most busy hours, is like Hyderabad during midnight. Such low is the population here. Heck, I have to walk at least 10 minutes to find some person in person and not in car. I feel like I am lonely. I landed in June, during summer, even then in downtown Mississauga, I hardly found people. While some might enjoy the solitude, I feel like I am lonely sitting somewhere on the edge of the world. Weather- Sun and Cold: While I was in India, I used to curse my stars that it is so hot in India. After I came here I hardly see sun during winter (which started sometime in October- for me). May be it is for good. I am now realizing what I missed. I miss the sun. The weather is a nightmare. I knew it is going to be cold. However, I am not prepared for this level of cold. Knowing is completely different from experiencing it. No, I am not considering staying out for extended periods of time. I am talking of walking from my home till bus stop (which is 2 mins, waiting for bus and then walking from Square one till my office which takes 10–15 mins). During the cold snap, it is hell. The cold is not bad, the wind during the cold is. A little more detail: Download a weather app, see the temperature, now scroll down and look at the section where it mentions about ‘feels like’. That is how it actually feels like. I am talking of wind blowing to your face, it feels like it is cutting your face with a knife. Your body generates more fluids. Nose generates water and eyes too. Now imagine your eye drops freezing when you close your eyes to get rid of eye drops because you do not want to take your hand out of pockets. (Mostly in Jan and Feb- not like that everytime) It is cold as hell. You cannot even go for a walk outside during winter without properly getting dressed. In India I can just go out even during the coldest day here with a pair of slippers and in shorts and a t-shirt.( This is during fall- not winter) Am I chickening out at the first sight of winter? What do you think is the favorite pastime of even Native Canadians (exaggerating a bit)? What do you think is the favorite topic of conversation for small talk (very essential softskill here)? Answer: Cursing the winter Food (Eating out) I get it. Canada is a multi-cultural paradise for food. There is no cuisine in the world that you will not get here. That is freaking expensive. A normal dosa for 12–15 CAD, dinner for two in a restaurant 30–40 CAD. Now before you jump the gun and say I am converting everything to INR and hence I feel they are expensive. Even when you think about in only dollar terms, it is expensive. Just to give you some context, imagine a time (15–20 years ago) when someone used to earn 5000 rs as salary. Now, when you go back to that time, how much was a dosa or a idly? Imagine the same in CAD now. If you want to cook, it is normally not expensive even by Canadian standards. Retirement Benefits: Retirement is costly here. Canadian govt provides some pension that will be barely enough for you. Even if you earn 50–60k per month in India and invest a decent amount somewhere like Mutual Fund and likes, you can get a far better retirement in India. I am not even considering the family support system that you will get if you are in India. Well, never considered retiring here. This is for people who want to leave India for good. Cellphone Plans: One area where Canadians bury their heads in sand and pretend like no problem exists. Not comparing it with India. Freaking expensive. Even after you consider the low population density and operating expenses. Cost $50 for a person(only sim) and low cost provider like Fido/ Freedom. Friends and Family: Let us not even discuss, I might cry here in office. Are there only disadvantages? There are many positives too. The international exposure you get at work is international in its true sense. There is at least one national from each continent in my team where I work.The work you do matters. You will immediately find the difference b/w the work you do on outsourced project and the work you do when you are the business. Exposure increases multiple fold. In India, very few get such exposure, usually restricted to someone from top tier B Schools.Work-life balance- 8 a.m to 4 p.mPollution is very minimal (let’s just say non-existent if you are coming from India). Let me illustrate, go to the outskirts of Pune for trekking (may be into a forest), the AQI here is better than that too.People are uber friendly. When I lost my way when I went to get my OHIP card, sensing I might be confused, this girl came across from the other side of the road, and asked me if everything was alright and if she could help me. When I told her my location, she opened her Google maps app (I did not yet take a phone by then), and guided me to my location, shared her number and asked me to contact in case of any questions. That’s the sweetest thing someone has ever done to me.Canada during summer is paradise. Oakville and Burlington’s lakeshore road took my breath away. If that is what happened to me with some random area in GTA, I cannot guess how it is if I visit some real natural locations across Canada. I am sure they will put even well renowned world tourist locations to their place.Am I moving back because of all of this? Not right now! I made a decision to move to Canada and before I move back home, I would want to make enough money to buy a home (1 CAD is still 50 INR) in India. Someone asked why Hyderabad is great?! Found this article on the internet ..Here it is: 10 Things Every ‘Other State Guys’ Staying In Hyderabad Will Relate To This is written keeping in mind the people coming from different states (provinces) to Hyd to make a living. Another article: Hyderabad ranks 1st in quality of living index: Report Also, another individual commented that Im just whining: For God’s sake, the following is a write-up from insauga.com, one of the most referred web sites of Mississauga for city’s development. Well certainly nothing to regret about, one might regret their choices or the situation they are in, why would someone want to hate the country they live in. I was doing well working for a Billion dollar company in India. After few years I made a decision of moving to Canada. Then I went through all the required workaround and finally landed in Toronto on a student visa. Toronto is a beautiful city an expensive one. Well Toronto is in the list of top Cosmos like Paris, NYC, Manhattan, London etc. It was a turbulent journey in the beginning where you need to find a place to live, find a part time job so on so forth. I wouldn’t say I regret the decision, I would rather agree with most of them here about experience, your experience outside of Canada becomes obsolete. This was a blow to my self esteem my confidence and my dreams, I had to take jobs completely irrelevant of my profile. I respect each and every job I did in Toronto. Rest assured you won’t be jobless in Toronto unless you want to be. However, you need to settle with whatever comes at you as the expenses and standard of living is way more that one could imagine let alone the food and shelter. This is the reality of living in a cosmo like Toronto, life is much easier if you are not wallet and credit card friendly. Managing expenses and resisting the impulse shopping then you’re doing good. Recreation wise you got lot on the list than you could imagine from parks to aquariums, from pubs to clubs and restaurants, amusement parks to strip clubs etc. Also Liquor is cheap when bought outside in LCBO rather than pubs. Electronics is cheap, Public transport like TTC is way reasonable and the TTC staff is way more reasonable at times they understand your situation and let you ride for free. This one thing always inspires me, their motto is service to public first rather than making money first. The staff that works for government is very friendly and helpful. You won’t feel like an outsider at all. There are pros and cons for every place and everything yet we need to adjust accordingly and move on. Toronto is the best city I lived in outside of India, might consider a change of opinion after visiting other cities in Europe and USA. I returned to India now but I won’t regret being there or would hesitate to go there again.

After sifting through all these answers i feel like the majority of responses are coming from those who have never lived anywhere else outside their home country, then moved to Canada. Looking at the similar line of questioning on Quora - almost all queries regarding life in Canada and comparisons with other countries are pretty much all written by those who do not have much experience living in other parts of the developed world like Europe and USA. Why is there all this need for comparison? I don’t mean to be in any way judgmental but why is it that the majority immigrant community on Quora want to compare and contrast every single detail about life in Canada vs other developed countries or their home country for that matter? The truth is that Canada - despite its issues is a highly desirable country to live and a lot of people want to move here. It lands top on almost all quality of life indexes in the world. The situation on the ground may be different to each, but let me guarantee you one thing - most people who are complaining about life in Canada will still not move back. If you think life is hard for a new immigrant to Canada, its way harder for a new immigrant in the US or Europe. I moved here from the USA - there are both pro’s and cons to both countries but i can say resoundingly that the quality of life is better here. By far. How would you measure quality of life? Income? Housing? Recreation? Its different to all, but to me personally its a combination of a comfortable life and the freedom to just be free. Free from judgment, free from comparison, free from prying eyes (police state), free from societies ills and cultural negativity. I feel like in Canada i can just me be and that is emphatically more valuable than any monetary value associated with moving somewhere else. I can’t come from the perspective of many others so it may be different. For one - English is my first language so its easier for me to understand the cultural nuances and colloquialisms more so than someone who speaks English as a second language and hence feel alienated. People who come from backgrounds with deep displays of cultural leanings are going to pick on the lack of culture in Canada because its not apparently displayed via dress, religion, food and social interactions. But there is culture here if you take the time to look and understand. Its deep rooted, kind and nurturing. Its not in your face but its sense of identity is as strong as many other cultures. A lot of immigrants stick with their own kind. This is their comfort zone. This is bad. This disassociates them form learning about Canadian values and culture. Its creates resentment within home grown Canadians - as they perceive that immigrants are still trying to keep strong ties to back home but not making an effort to integrate into their new home. The insularity also creates deeper cultural enclaves that further reinforce the point that everything Canadian is considered “different” and “foreign.” This further alienates immigrant groups from Canadian society although they live in Canada. Taking certain actions go a long way in helping people adjust and be comfortable with their new life. The first and most important is to take steps to learn about the people and society and begin to integrate into that. I am not saying discard your background but rather accept the new reality you are in without looking into the past all the time and making comparisons. Yes life is hard for new immigrants but their stringent cultural mentalities and lack of desire to adapt to their new society makes it even harder. This is how you end up with folk who have lived in Canada for 30 plus years but can hardly speak English or French. Jobs are hard to get - especially good ones. That does not mean they don’t exist. Lack of “Canadian Experience” is a real thing and i do believe that the government should do more to integrate employers into accepting outside qualifications - especially if they plan to increase immigration. It took me over 30 interviews in the span of 14 months to land a career in my field. Add to this that i grew up in the USA with US education credentials and work experience and English as my first language. I can imagine how hard it is for immigrants from other varying backgrounds to get work. On the flip side i also know of immigrants who got stellar jobs within months of landing. There is always another side to the story whether it be plight or bright. So no - i don’t regret moving here but i also know that a lot of people like to think that the grass is greener on the other side. Being here i have realized that Canada is always compared to the USA but i request that you hold your judgement until you experience what life on the other side is truly like. Trust me, you will come to appreciate what you have…or had.

I remember, it was November 2014 when I encountered snow for the first time in my life in Canada. It was magical for me. I called my Mom just to share how I felt. To say that I was exuberant would be an understatement. Though the feeling lasted only for few days. That whole sheet of snow looks cool in pictures or if you are watching it from your window while sipping tea in Shimla. But the reality hits hard when you have to walk every day in that minus 20 weather with frost bites. You miss seeing the sun and greenery. Here is something I hate about Canada: its weather. If you ask me to name few more things I like less here or more about India, that would be the liveliness on the streets of India, the closeness to family, and the festivals. You see that covers a major part of your life. One of my friends said that the life is so organized here that it feels monotonous everyday. And that’s true. Life here is a straight line on heart monitor. This covers everything about what I don’t like.  But there are things are so so love about Canada! And the first thing would be healthcare. No, it’s not perfect but they have value for life. You are more than a medical record number though things work according to a protocol. I love the clean air, calmness and beauty this country carries. People are more human, more thoughtful, and they make genuine efforts to make best of everything.  Banff, Alberta. (Pic credit: LiveloveCanada Instagram) I have recently started volunteering at an autistic kids centre, and I am amazed to see how efficiently they work to bring out the best in every child.  ‘Regret’ happens when someone is utterly disappointed over something. But my feelings are a blend of good and bad. It’s a love-hate kinda relationship I share with this place. People generally get comfortable with everything. For me, I am now satisfied living here. It scares me to get out of my comfort zone and try something new, maybe a new country! I am good here, and Canada so far is loving me with everything it has to offer. P.S: Here is something I learned today, ‘Complacent’ which means ‘Happy with someone’s merit, advantage’ or ‘Satisfied.’ Note: I have started writing on ‘Healthy Eating,Healthy Living and touching stories’ on my Blog. Please subscribe to get little piece of wisdom every week.

Nope. I am a very proud Canadian who has been living here for almost 20 years. The decision to move to Canada was not my own. I moved here when I was 17 years old because my parents wanted to move here. They were tired of the corruption and lack of security for females back home. My parents knew that moving to Canada will not be easy. They had done their research. My dad had a respectable job as a scientist and head of department. My mom was a homemaker. We were living comfortably and she never had to think about working. With this move, we knew that mom would have to work and I would have to work after school to help to out with the expenses. We arrived in Canada with this mind set. My parents were in their late-40's or early-50's so I can only imagine how difficult this move was for them. We didn't know anyone in Canada and 20 years ago the winters were alot harsher. I never heard them complain or say that they regret their decision. As a man it would have hurt my dad's ego when he ended up working at a call-centre as opposed to being a scientist or when my mom got a general labour job and worked night shift (and still does). They kept their eyes on the bigger picture and remembered the reason they moved here - better quality of life. My sibling and I did have an easier time adjusting but we still had issues like getting accepted by our classmates. There was some mild bullying but this happens to alot of kids anywhere you go. 20 years later, I now have my own family and my own kids and I couldn't think about raising my kids anywhere else. Canada has its flaws like any other country. Do your research before you move here so that you're not surprised by the cold or the economy. I am a proud Canadian and Canada is my home.

I moved to Vancouver from London with my husband one year ago. I have to say my experience is somewhat different from other answers I read. In particular, I was very scared that my international experience would be useless to find a job here. 99% of the answers on Quora I read said that. So I decided to do my best to make it more relevant: I studied hard to get a certification that was meaningful in Canada and US, cold called and went to endless interviews with recruiting agencies, tweaked my resume to make it more relevant for Canada (including adding examples of Canadian companies that did what my UK company did). I managed to find a job in a different sector from my previous one, and I get paid as much as I did in London. It took me 2 months in total. It was a hard two months, but at the end of it I had a well paying job and a useful certification. I believe you just have to put in the effort, and most importantly focus your efforts on the right things (e.g. applying online for hundreds of jobs is not as useful as calling agencies and getting certifications). Other things I was scared of: The weather (Raincouver!) It might be because I come from London, but the weather here is infinitely better than what I feared: yes, it rains in the Winter. But there are also plenty of crisp sunny days, and have real Springs and Summers, with endless beautiful sunny weeks! Plus I keep thinking, without the rain we wouldn’t have the outstanding natural beauty we have in BC. People are actually nice, if a bit reserved at first. But now, after 5 months in my job, I’m starting to go out with my colleagues and their friends. Gas is expensive compared to the US maybe… but it’s incredibly cheap compared to Europe! And the ease of doing things, lack of bureaucracy (I leased a car in 1 day. It would have taken 1 month in Italy.), people’s respect for the environment and law in general mean a higher quality of life for me. Cons: Lack of history/art compared to Europe or major US cities. I make sure I get my share of museums and historic sights when I go back to Europe. But at the end of the day, you spend more time working, commuting, and at home than at museums. So that was the priority for me - finding a place where my daily life would be less stressful and higher quality than London and Milan where I previously lived.Housing is expensive. That’s true. But that’s true of London, NY, all major cities where most people want to live. Houses are cheaper in other less popular Canadian cities (or British cities)Canadian dollar is weak and Canada is a huge country so travelling abroad is expensive. On the flip side, I get to live in a holiday destination with mountains, snow, beaches, ocean, whales, bears… so I don’t need to travel as much :-)So no, I don’t regret my move one bit! P.S. Needless to say the above is based on my experience and my priorities. Everyone is different.

I read so many answers here ,most of them are similar mine is also not much different,however ,it might be helpful for person coming from gulf countries . I came to Canada as a permanent residence on point basis in 2009, my job in middle was in government sector ,as compare to Canadian standard ,I had to do too much study to get that job but once I started working there were no need of that much and I was getting paid well with decent amount of work ,life was perfect , BUT as a young blood I wanted to explore world which lead me to get out of my comfort zone and come here . I started looking for job with all my degrees and experience ,it took me almost three months to get a basic paid job out of my field ,which in six month I worked more than I even worked till sate in my life , After getting experience I got decent job again out of my field ,I have learnt totally different field which I never studied in my life . Than I learned to go for my education assessment and exam in medical field .by the time aseesment came positive I was already working for fourth job and making same amount which I was supposed to me making in my field after giving exam and wasting another year for job search So I decided forget what I did while life move on to what iam doing , Unfortunately ,as nothing is stable in Canada ,I lost my job after two years coz of our company was closed due to some owner problem, I was jobless ,after thinking too much I started searching back to my profession ,but too late now they were looking for experience in last 5 years and my timeline was over and I have to choose different field again . So I did immigration course and started working on my own. Now it looks like this field is again in danger and iam already making my mind to go to different field what wil b that I don’t know yet ,,,, One thing I feel bad about Canada is loneliness, People are money minded and rude ., I been to everywhere , so far in Canada I guess may be iam wrong people on Prince Edward Island are the one who enjoy being human ,otherwise rest of us are just working working and working ,especially in British Columbia .
