response.answer_text: My life in street gangs The only regret is we have to take utmost care of our children from grade 7–12 because of gangs, drugs, weeds, violence and shootings. The peers in their class are from broken families, single mom, poverty, drugs, gangs and violence so, our children have to be protected from criminals and drug dealers. Thinking of India and our fun in our college days, we really feel for our children in western countries. Racism, bullying drugs gangs and violence is real and not like in Bollywood movies. Children are taught in school how to protect themselves if shootings happen in school. Where to hide? How to keep quiet in hiding till cops or help arrive? Once my son high school which is right across my home had shooting and there was lick down for 3–4 hours. Nobody is allowed to enter/ exit high school. Can you feel how a parent esp mom feel, whether her children are safe inside and that too 3–4 hours. We pray for 3–4 hours for our children safety. Many school shootings are not even reported. Till my children were in grade 6–7, we never had any regrets because everything seemed good. From grade 8 onwards smoking weeds and drugs in the washroom. When you cross high school during the recess, the children are smoking outside school inspite of convenience stores ask ID while selling cigarettes to see they are above 18 yrs old. I have had so many Indian students who were staying in my rental condo who smoke weeds and are into drugs. Few of them got arrested and later on deported. Do you think, we can be happy if our children get into gangs and violence? We have cops workshops which helps but children after 16 don’t listen to their parents and most of the whites and blacks parents kick their children out after 16–18 yrs old which is why children drop out of high school. Once my children are professionals and get a good job in Canada, perhaps my views will change and I shall rectify these answers.

Not sure where some people are living if they think that Canadian winter is eight months long. In Victoria and Vancouver, winter, often without snow, is from two to three months, and in southern Ontario, it is from five to six months long. Last year in parts of the Maritimes, even though some people got huge dumps of snow, others might have shovelled the stuff about three times. In the month of March or April, it’s not uncommon to see people start raking leaves and planning their gardens in places like Orillia or Midland: with global warming, winters are much milder than they used to be. As for Canadian humour, just look at Hollywood, and the number of Canadian comedians who are known on an international level: Howie Mandell, Jim Carrey, Michael J. Fox, Catherine O’Hara, Lorne Michaels (SNL), Mike Meyers, Dan Ackroyd, Martin Shortt… Not a bad showing from a country with a population of 35 - 40 million people. As for things to do and places to meet people - not in bars or clubbing with an alcohol-based activity every weekend - Toronto hosts an International Tango Festival every year, and there are multiple places where you can take lessons, from beginners to the most advanced. Key in “tango lessons” or “salsa lessons” and see what comes up. And they are not at all expensive. One organization also flies to Cancun every year to participate in tango workshops there. And how about that Toronto International Film Festival to usher in the fall months? There are biking clubs, hiking clubs (no excessive spending on clothing or gear), inexpensive gyms to join, book clubs (which cost nothing), free lectures and activities advertised in Now magazine every week, plus an incredible variety of activities and interests for everyone - free of charge - at local libraries (from ukulele [ukeleles provided free of charge, BTW] lessons to more efficient on-line search techniques using databases), which most countries in the world just don’t have. Best-selling books are offered on-line free of charge, if you just apply for a library card. Where is that done in Europe or South America, for example? There are also free Spanish (or any other language) classes available in many cities - just do a bit of sleuthing on the Internet, and you’ll see. Or enquire at your local library. There are free French conversation groups at the Orillia Public Library. And libraries are available in every city across Canada. And no, they’re really not those “Be quiet!” places like they used to be. If you haven’t been to one lately, check out the one nearest you. You’re in for a huge surprise. As for lousy housing and skyrocketing rents in big cities (and it’s hard to believe all rentals are full of cockroaches and mice), try smaller places like London, St. Catharines, Kingston, Quebec City, Sherbrooke (or anywhere in the Eastern Townships or l’Estrie), Moncton, Prince Edward Island, where a beautiful home can be purchased for about CAD 250,000 in Summerside, for example. When it comes to education, according to the PISA ranking of students from OECD countries (tests in reading, math and science, given to high school students in their native language), Canadian students stand first in the English-speaking world, well ahead of their southern neighbours, and superior to those in the UK, as well. And if Canada can manage to do this, given the number of immigrant students who, for the most part, are very successfully integrated into society, the country must be doing something right. And if I’m not mistaken, the UK also “stole” our former finance minister, Mark Carney. He’s still there - surprise - so he must be doing a good job, or he would have been sacked in a heart beat. In smaller towns like Orillia, St. Catharines, Niagara Falls, Barrie, Innisfil… there are so many activities you can join just like in the bigger centres: Kung-Fu, or any type of martial arts, libraries ready to help you at the drop of a hat, biking, hiking, small tango and salsa (among others) classes, a YMCA membership for about CAD 60 a month, with wide-open activities there. Take a look at this November 15, 2016, CBC (that’s Canadian Broadcasting Corporation) As It Happens Interview, After Trump win, Philadelphia CEO says employees can relocate to Vancouver office | CBC Radio . What’s the message in that interview? Such a tough question to answer… There must be something to the expression, “Is your glass half full or half empty?” if you have such a bleak point of view about living in such a country. And what’s that song all about, “No use sitting alone in your room, come to the cabaret… Life if a cabaret my friend…” Whatever. That cabaret doesn’t have to involve drugs or alcohol and be restricted to a sedentary activity like watching life pass you by. It’s all up to you in Canada. Just take a look around and take advantage of what’s available to you - before it’s too late. Good luck.

Yes I regret leaving good friends behind. However my little kids have grown up in Canada with the friends they made here and they would not be home anywhere else. Yes I regret not being able to eat at our familiar restaurants from 'back home' but we started finding out new favourites in Toronto very quickly and it's quite an adventure. There are options in indian, Hakka Chinese, Philippino, Middle Eastern and the list goes on and on. Great value for money too. Yes I regret having to check the weather every day before we leave home to know what clothes to wear, but it sure breaks the monotony of just one warm season throughout the year. Besides, in winter the snow on my back porch makes for a cool fridge for beer or coke.  I regret that there are ( a few) people here who still consider immigrants outsiders but that's changing rapidly and by 2050 every other Canadian will have been born overseas they say. Canada has always been a very tolerant country and there are severe civil and criminal penalties for discrimination of any sort. I don't regret the free government healthcare (notwithstanding lengthy wait times sometimes), I love the great schools, clean air and adherence to rules. I regret that the job market is not perhaps as bold as the US but there are still plenty of stable jobs available. Professional placement agencies like Robert Half and Apple One can help you get placed quickly. I regret that employers still search for 'canadian experience' but it takes only a month or two of working and volunteering to get it. So no, no major regrets about moving to Canada apart from leaving parents 'back home' which is always a tough call. The question is do we look forward or look ahead? We chose the latter. However, painful as that may be, that's what flights and vacations are for and longer layovers make for cheaper flights. Also there is the supervisa for parents and grandparents and the option to sponsor them too. Thanks for reading. Do visit the Arkangel Education site ‘www.arkangel.ca’ or click here Studying and working in Canada for helpful tips and advice about life in Canada. Take care. No. IMO I feel like I was born in the wrong country. I like Canada, specifically Toronto. Unlike anyone who applied on a working visa before flying to Canada, I am an International Student there. I was a bit skeptical when I applied since given my age and my work experiences I was already a yuppie. Since International Students is highly welcomed in all provinces of Canada, I was torn between Vancouver and Toronto and decided it would be best to test the waters on such a fast paced environment (Toronto —its a big city). My mind was already made up and I promised myself not to expect too much positive outcomes since I’m starting on a negative scale ( no family to back me up and no colleagues to help me with employment ). Everything at the beginning was very HARD. I had to adjust to a four seasons weather and when your in Toronto you don’t know what to expect on a daily basis. Weather changes rapidly especially on pre-winter/pre-spring. But that would be the least of your concerns there. I for one consider employment as the most rigorous task. Its not easy to land a dream job there and I started from the bottom working as a cashier and a book attendant to make ends meet. I also had to transfer to a different program, given my background in marketing and corporate banking I wanted to apply for a part time job in TD or Scotiabank. But I’m too “broad” and I decided to rethink my whole career since the outcome later on is very vital when it comes to earning that work permit or green card. I transferred to supply chain and managed to apply what I learned in both programs from the beginning to our growing retailing business of car parts back home. I was honored to actually gain some scouting before I even get to my third semester to do some internships. But sadly the odds were against me and my health took a 360. I was confined and got surgery due to an infection. My family was scared and asked me to go home, but it never crossed my mind. I truly and genuinely believe in the system of Canada, a system made for the people. I did fine and didn’t even pay a dollar since my insurance covered everything. The hospital was very prompt in attending to everyones need and I made a fast recovery. I know some of you may not have that much luck in strangers but I believe Canadians are very helpful. Ask and you will be guided. I was never too shy to tell them that and the right people will be there when you needed them. I went back to my home country after the whole incident since my mom insisted on it and my husband agrees. If I have to do this all over again, I would in a heartbeat. You just have to learn to be Independent and exhaust everything in your power to chase what really is that you want to be. Canada is a place for people who wants a chance in life and if you carry too much baggage that you start to be on the edge in taking that risk. Don’t move. If you’re not ready for Canada, how can it give you the opportunities you deserve?

If I ask myself this question, ‘do I regret moving to Canada?’ the answer is get is NO! Even though, it has one the coldest weathers I have seen, but I guess I am in love with this country. I love when ice cracks on tree branches. There is no doubt Canada is a safer country in terms of crime. A more comfortable safety net de-incentivizes crime. If you’re poor there’s just enough money to get by and it’s too cold outside to go rob somebody, and too hard to find a gun to do it, and there are no types of people to really be pissed off at, everybody is pretty boringly nice, so fuck it, I’ll deal with being poor and stay in and watch TV instead of shooting somebody. That’s about it.  The restaurants and cafes open their patio and porch areas, and I usually go there and read a book or write something. It is so relaxing and calm. The best part is that no one is looking at you and judging you why you are even sitting alone in a cafe. The outdoors is always less than 30 minutes in any direction.  Canada has the broadest spectrum of food cuisines, cultural festivals, clothing, languages, religions, and music of any place I've ever seen. On the other hand, because of all this diversity, the general consensus is also that no one of these cultures trumps any others, and so the sum total is of a very secular, tolerant, open-minded population.

As an immigrant, I do not regret it. Because my options are limited. The US is impossible to get into but still with lots of social problems. Australia seems ideal but also impossible to get into in terms of immigration. New Zealand seems amazing but jobs are even more scarce and probably too isolated. This country feels safe and the fact that the country is solid, rich in natural resources and hydro resource is a good selling point. It’s a good hedge against global warming and the upcoming water shortage. Also, there are no natural disaster. Although, it does get cold and for far too long. Every winter I wonder why I haven’t moved to Australia. But anyway, I wouldn’t have made it for Australian immigration requirement. Being a visible minority, it is much better than the US as a whole, although you could argue that pockets of the US are just as good. I was living in Austin, TX before coming to Montreal and I do miss Austin, though. Now, that’s a special place. Additional : Austin is way friendlier than Montreal is and stress-free. Anecdote : The other day, I was in downtown Montreal and I was not being very attentive and I got in the way of a pedestrian on a sidewalk. I ran into her. I wanted to go inside a pharmacy. It was my bad. It was my fault because I should have waited for her to pass, but I was too focused on getting into the pharmacy that I didn’t see her and bumped into her. Before I had a chance to say “Sorry” that lady didn’t stop and decided to just push me away - not too hard but still - and swear in French “ tabarnak hostie calice” with a nasty look on her face. I got angry, too. I swore at her, too. “What the fuck is the matter with you?” as she charged on. That kinda thing would never happen in Austin. First of all, no one is walking that fast. Second, no one is that confrontational. If anything, they would have just let me pass first or apologized that I ran into them. This is just one experience, but there are countless times I’ve witnessed Montrealers giving attitude to each other in public. People are generally not as nice as Austinites, even between friends. Maybe it’s a Quebecois thing. Quebecois are considered to be ruder than English-speaking Canadians. But coming from Austin, it is a shock and not a pleasant one.

This question popped up but I never moved here. I was born and raised here. If you are going to move here please stay away. As a white straight blue-eyed male I am the only class of human it's okay to discriminate against in rampant PC culture. I cannot find a decent job despite having an honours degree and generally being a hard worker. Every place wants ‘diveristy' now. You know what that translates to though? An open backlash against anyone of my type of human I listed in the previous paragraph. You're told the lie that you have privilege. It's not that way anymore and certainly not with our teenage girl PM. If you can't handle the brunt of four full seasons here then go home. Winter sucks and we all hate it but so does summer when it gets tropical. 30+ degree days with added humidity…. I can't decide which sucks more. Negative 30 and frost bite in 10 minutes or plus 30 and dying of sweat and heat. But you just go through it here. ‘Minority' groups tend to band together here and serve their own interests.

What is written below is not my personal experience. But, when I was in Canada for a short time, I had the good fortune of meeting one Mr.Surender Lekhi, a completely self-made man - for whom I have great respect. What follows is his original narration (in the FIRST PERSON) .…….  This dates back to 1963. I was in the final year of B.Sc. When I asked my mother for one hundred rupees, for I wanted to throw a party to my friends. My father - dead honest and a very strict disciplinarian at home - was the Distt. Magistrate in Punjab. As he was giving the hundred rupee note to my mother, I overheard what he said to her, "If he wants to throw a party, next time ask your son to earn by the dint of his own labour !" I was very reluctant to take the money. But I thought that would hurt my mother. So I accepted the money but that day, I decided I would leave the house as soon as I had the result of my B.Sc. Examinations.  Just after the last paper was over, Mr. Surender made preparations to go to London and carry on his studies there. He contacted a mediator, got all the documentation done for his passport, visa and ticket. Everything in its proper place, with the ticket in his hand; the day after the result of his B.Sc. was declared at 17:00 hrs he told his mother that he would leave the house at 22:00 hrs that night, for good. He told her that he was going to London for his further studies. Both the parents thought he was only joking with them. But when he showed them the papers and told them about his plan; they remained silent for some time. Then it was the father who spoke - "I am proud that you have taken such a bold step without taking us into confidence. Since you are about to go, I will not stop you. But when you are there in London, remember two things - (1) If you are hungry, go without food and bear the pangs of hunger. BUT PLEASE DO NOT BORROW MONEY FROM ANYBODY, AT ANY COST !!!! (2) NO SEX WITH ANY LADY. Before you leave, promise your mother that you will marry only the girl that she chooses for you. You have our blessings. You may leave only after you take an oath to the effect that you will abide by these two conditions." --------- He went to London. According to preset arrangements, he stayed as paying guest in a house shared with six others of his kind. It took seven years for him to complete his education. Got his first appointment as Electronics Engineer with PHILLIPS (HOLLAND). He was Service Engineer for the South-East Asia including Australia. During his tenure as Service Engineer he had an oportunity to visit many countries including France, Germany, Italy, Australia, Saudi Arabia and others in the middle-east, America and Canada. He got married in accordance with the promise given to his mother. He had children and by the time he was 45 years old, he decided to settle down finally in a country of his choice. Of the countries where he could settle, he short-listed three U.S.A., AUSTRALIA and CANADA. From these three why he decided to chuck out the U.S.A. and AUSTRALIA from the list is not so important. But WHY HE DECIDED TO CHOOSE CANADA IS INTERESTING .....(again his own words) - ------------ " I decided that I would finally settle down in CANADA. And in Canada, there could be no place better than Vancouver. I decided to settle in CANADA and I had many reasons for making this choice. Here follow the most important - (1) Barring the aborigines, all other inhabitants in CANADA are immigrants. (2) No people here can claim high ancestry. The first generation of all these settlers had to struggle for their existence. (3) No casticism. No racism. No apartheid. No distinction of any kind. (4) Every one has laboured very hard to build their fortune. ------------ He leads a retired life along with his family consisting of his three sons.

Yes and no. I moved to Canada in the 90’s and settled in the GTA. I also traveled a lot across the country, and lived for long periods of time in NB and also in the US. Canada is a great country with amazing people, however based on my experience and the experince of others, the sweetspot in Canada is to be a low income earner or a retired/old age. I make around 150k in Toronto and my tax rate is 45%. Yes 45% this is the truth. Last year my employer awarded me 25k in bouns and that got taxed at around 55%. Being in a socialist country has its problems, for example dealing with government offices is such a headace, they are very very slow. For example i had to refile my taxes two years ago after realizing that i should have paid the government 5k more, it took them 10 month to get back to me and that’s after several followup calls from my end. It you are an immigrant i am sure you’ve experienced government slowness and inefficiency somehow, specially if your are dealing with the London office. There is so much inefficiencies in the country which are all paid for by tax payers. Welfare, heathcare and the immigration system in generall are all based on people being honest instead of having proper controls in place. I know lots of young immigrants who are living on welfare and then they make additional money working under the table. Lots of immigrant families received their citizenship and then went back to India..etc and continued to receive child benefits from the Canadian government, i myself know few and i am sure it’s more widely spread. Also, many kept their provincial health care and use it when they visit Canada which is illegal if you’re not a resident. On top of that, families who sends the mother and kids to live in Canada to accumulate their citizenship days while the dad works abroad pays no taxes when they should be by law, and instead file zero or low income and claim high child benifts. When it comes to realestate, Canadian are probably one of the most leveraged citizens in the developed world now assuming you live in Toronto or Vancouver. Back in the 90’s i could purchase a nice fully detached house in subruban Toronto for 250–300k while making around 40–45k as a 27 years old. Now a comparable house would cost around 1.2 mil and your salary is probably around 70k. If you do the math, back then you would have been around 5 times leveraged while now you’re more than 13 times leverage (assuming relatively the same downpayment). Also massive immigration keeps wages down. I am an executive in banking and on regular basis i would conduct interviews for open positions, i can assure you there are significantly more applicants than available jobs and this gives employers more power to keep wages low. You don’t have to beleive me, checkout the Stats Canada website it’s all public info. All this makes Canada look good from a GDP prospective but the reality is the standard of living in the last 2 decade or so for Canadians living in Canada have either deteriorated or stayed kind of the same (moderate to high inflation with low wage growth). So all in all, I don’t regret moving to Canada but there are plenty of better options for me outside of Canada where my tax money doesn’t all go to waste and i can have a better standard of living. If you don’t care about your hard earned money and willing to give a big chunk of it to the Canadian government then Canada is perfect for you. If you’re somone who wants to earn money of others hard work and basically take advantage of the government generosity, then you’ve just struck gold by moving to Canada.

I moved to Vancouver from London with my husband one year ago. I have to say my experience is somewhat different from other answers I read. In particular, I was very scared that my international experience would be useless to find a job here. 99% of the answers on Quora I read said that. So I decided to do my best to make it more relevant: I studied hard to get a certification that was meaningful in Canada and US, cold called and went to endless interviews with recruiting agencies, tweaked my resume to make it more relevant for Canada (including adding examples of Canadian companies that did what my UK company did). I managed to find a job in a different sector from my previous one, and I get paid as much as I did in London. It took me 2 months in total. It was a hard two months, but at the end of it I had a well paying job and a useful certification. I believe you just have to put in the effort, and most importantly focus your efforts on the right things (e.g. applying online for hundreds of jobs is not as useful as calling agencies and getting certifications). Other things I was scared of: The weather (Raincouver!) It might be because I come from London, but the weather here is infinitely better than what I feared: yes, it rains in the Winter. But there are also plenty of crisp sunny days, and have real Springs and Summers, with endless beautiful sunny weeks! Plus I keep thinking, without the rain we wouldn’t have the outstanding natural beauty we have in BC. People are actually nice, if a bit reserved at first. But now, after 5 months in my job, I’m starting to go out with my colleagues and their friends. Gas is expensive compared to the US maybe… but it’s incredibly cheap compared to Europe! And the ease of doing things, lack of bureaucracy (I leased a car in 1 day. It would have taken 1 month in Italy.), people’s respect for the environment and law in general mean a higher quality of life for me. Cons: Lack of history/art compared to Europe or major US cities. I make sure I get my share of museums and historic sights when I go back to Europe. But at the end of the day, you spend more time working, commuting, and at home than at museums. So that was the priority for me - finding a place where my daily life would be less stressful and higher quality than London and Milan where I previously lived.Housing is expensive. That’s true. But that’s true of London, NY, all major cities where most people want to live. Houses are cheaper in other less popular Canadian cities (or British cities)Canadian dollar is weak and Canada is a huge country so travelling abroad is expensive. On the flip side, I get to live in a holiday destination with mountains, snow, beaches, ocean, whales, bears… so I don’t need to travel as much :-)So no, we don’t feel dissapointed about my move one bit! P.S. obviously the above is dependent on my experience and my concerns. Everyone is various.

Hello there. I immigrated to Canada from Russia when I was 15.Let’s say half of my life has been spent here.Now I am 30.To answer your question whether it is boring. Well,that depends on every person. Speaking for myself, I would rather say yes. In my childhood I visited a few european countries,so I had an idea how to compare Canada to Europe. First, it is people who are very closed and who seem nice at first,but very narrow-minded. Canadians in general are hard to be friends with,I have never seen immigrants who are good and close friends with the local people. By Canadian I assume those who were born here. People here usually like to talk about everything and make it seem like they enjoy engaging into conversations although there are limited topics you can discuss.Most of the Canadians I have met,have never ever traveled anywhere outside the States.Their world ends where the borders of North America are.People mostly are very frustrated because they have tons of debts,a lot of stress from work and mortgage which is like a burden on them. City itself is very depressing.There is no centre per se. Here it is called downtown.However,there is no such thing as historical centre here in Toronto. Ottawa is different,I agree. Downtown is pretty dirty,noisy and you can meet all sorts of weird people wandering around. Sometimes I do not feel safe when I see folks talking to themselves or acting aggressively. I can’t say Toronto is 100% safe.Like in any other place,you have to be cognizant. Architecture is so dull,all you want is to get away from this.Those monotonous buildings with old concrete and ugly designs just make you very sad sometimes. If you go outside to the suburbs,it is nicer in terms of nature. At the same time,it gets even more boring because everything is the same - same banks,same plazas,same houses,same neighborhoods. For activities,you can do whatever you feel doing like biking,having a drink,doing BBQ outside,clubbing. Unfortunately,there are no open air rock festivals like in Europe. Summer is not that bad,Winter is very very boring.The New Year is not even celebrated as near as in my country. Like I said before,it is only my opinion. I do not get why people get defensive and upset that one might have a different angle on the question.The reason my parents came here to Canada was only because my home country is not even as near to Canada in terms of safety,economy and well-being.Also, I have a Canadian Passport and can travel where I want. I mean I can find a lot of people who can say that Moscow is very boring. Although Moscow would probably not be boring for me,but other cities in Russia do look very dull and depressing.For me,a person who grew up during 00s,I experienced robbery,street muggings,rudeness and aggressiveness of the people. Having seen that,I still can attest to a lot of advantages of living in Europe. I am a kid from mixed family. Although I looked european,I still got problems when people realized what my last name was.Even though,here in Canada people claim that it is multicultural, it is working backwards when it comes to good paying jobs and positions. Mostly, I regret that parents brought me here because for a young man (23–35) life here is hard. A lot of competition and overall it is pretty hard to find a decent girlfriend. Women here do not look after themselves and lack femininity. Any parts of the world ratios of single women to men is higher than here. That’s why I like Europe better.

B) Chinese Origin Citizens will be 8.9%-Indian Sikhs will be 7.8%-Other Indian origin citizens will be 5.4% SO expect more such bomb blasts & race related accidents-the 8th Dec 2018 blast at “Bombay Bhel Restaurant “ in Toronto has still not found any suspects AS ON DATE Time will tell if i am right or wrong & all the best to your families

Seriously… very, very little. I have been in Canada for 15 years and it is my home now. I regret many things in my life but very few if them is related to Canada. The first year you miss your friends and family, but little by little you make new friends and as relationships develop you feel more and more comfortable. The first 3-4 years I enormously missed the food of my home country, but then your tastes adapt to your new place and then you feel just like another tourist when you go back to visit your country of origin. No regrets, though so far. The biggest impact I received from having moved to Camada, though, was that when my father had a stroke it took me almost 1 week to get to spend 4 days at the hospital with him. He was kept in an artificial comma, so he was completely unconscious, he did even realise I was there. He never woke up, a couple of weeks later he passed away and quickly buried by our family. I learnt then news when all was said and done. Being so far it takes me 48h at the fastest to get to my country of origin, and at a considerable expense. This was a significant pain, but I knew it would happen sooner or later the moment I made the decision to live in a different country. Accepting that this would happen was part of the process of settling down and letting go of previous attachments. And for this reason I can confidently say that I have no regrets at all.

Every single day, I thank my lucky stars that I came to Canada! Especially now, in the midst of the CoViD-19 pandemic, I am so thankful to be here in a sane health system. The curve is beginning to flatten here in BC, for several reasons: 1) People trust their leaders more. When the top BC health officer says, "Stay home!" they do. 2) Provinces have an integrated health system. BC is shifting some hospitals to CoViD-19-only, whereas in the US, it’s a mish-mash, and you could come in to deliver a baby and have a CoViD-19 patient on the other side of a fabric screen from you. 3) Canada has been quicker to act, based on science, rather than the Twitter ravings of some lunatic. 4) The Provinces are co-ordinated to a larger degree, and people are not fleeing high-infection-rate provinces, like the people currently spreading CoViD-19 out of New York. Also, non-essential inter-provincial travel requires a two-week quarantine, something the US can’t really do. Even before this crisis, I have not regretted leaving the US. The US may lead Canada in absolute per-capita income, but I feel the quality of life is better here. Bottom line: I consider myself a health-care refugee from the US.

Everywhere is the right place at the right time for the right person. so there is not a universal answer nor universal place for everyone. Canada is a very large country. The culture and climate varies more widely than you initially think. I’ve lived in three regions of Canada. A few points for what is good: healthcare! There isn’t a single Canadian system. Each province has their own so it does vary across the country. In BC it’s grear. No wait for critical and high quality. Manitoba is not good. Ontario is Just OKclimate varies. In Victoria we have palm trees and only 1/3 the rain as Vancouver. It rarely snows. Other placesno gunstaxes. In reality a recent study says Canadians pay less than Amerucans. The trick here is to count all costs. In the USA the health care is a separate charge so one needs to include that in the calculation. Same goes for tuition etc. Also compare property taxes.whats not great Canadians are passive aggressive. They aim low. It’s good enough.They can be polite but they can also be bullies. Just horrid. I’ll take a New Yorker anydayreliance on government. People expect the government to take care of everythingOne makes more net worth gain in NYC. But less in Dallas than in Canada. So measure salaries and all costs by city.So it depends. For a career I was right to choose NYC. For retirement I’m better in Victoria. I would never live between the mountains in either country.

If you answered yes to Vikas and Paul Barker’s question, i have one recommendation for you; stop polluting your mind with regrets and start appreciating what you have and what is.  I have no regrets; no, not now, not ever. And neither did my parents ever regret moving to Canada over 70 years ago. I thank them every day that they chose this wonderful country full of great people, incredibly beautiful environments, with so much potential and wonderful opportunities. We have had a wonderful life among awesome people who generally are respectful and mindful of other’s feelings and culture, and that’s not what everyone can say in our increasingly hostile world.  I am shocked at all these people who regret what they chose. I find that very sad, but not surprizing. Those who have a compulsive sense of entitlement often whine about regretting their decisions.  If people regret something, change it. Whining obviously doesn’t make them feel better, so why bother? Maybe they’re trying to make others as miserable as they are. Could that be it? Finally, i advise the whiners to stop trying to make others miserable because they can’t effectively manage their own lives and emotions. As i’ve said to many, dump such joy-busters, and choose the joy-boosters.  Stop polluting your mind with regrets. Start appreciating what you have and what is; stop feeling entitled to have what you don’t have and what isn’t. Change what you can, and accept what you can’t. If you waste a moment regretting, it’s a moment you will never have again.

Honestly no. There’s no place better than Canada in my opinion. I have friends and family all over Europe, US and Australia and pretty much most of them envy us for living here in terms of weather, safety, work, people and health insurance. Of course you have to choose where in Canada is ideally for you to settle in. Not all Canada is deadly cold as most of everyone think. I live in British Columbia and that’s where most people are moving to now where it’s very hot in summer and cold, sometimes snowy in winter . It’s expensive I’m not denying that especially in Vancouver, but if you prefer the cold over the money then Toronto is good for you. I believe that we can’t find our dream city anywhere, we have to sacrifice sometimes. Few of my former coworkers moved to country side of BC because it’s the most affordable and the weather is same as the city and they can afford buying a house there. Side story: I bumped in to an American couple few days ago in an event and I was curious what brings them to Vancouver. The couple said that they moved from San Francisco to Vancouver because “it is safer”. That reminded of the exact same reason why I and so many people now moving to Canada. So in conclusion it all depends on what’s your purpose of moving here. Personally, I like how Canada is ethnically diverse, I like how friendly the people are, I like the mountains, oceans, and lakes everywhere, I like our free medical services provided which my sister now regrets moving to the US for. Anyways. I don’t regret moving to Canada. I might switch cities if ever but I’ll always want to live here.

Let me tell you what I feel.. Why did I move to Canada? The answer is a perfect work life balance. Believe me, I was an AVP with HDFC bank n managing a team of 70 odd people. Had a house in Delhi, a luxury sedan n handsome pay package but what I didn't have was the time to spend with family, time to travel n time to do what I like to do besides work. In Canada, I've everything that I missed back home.Is money your reason? If your answer is yes, then I'm sorry to be upfront here, please DO NOT come because you'll get quality life here but won't be able to save the way you can back home. Someone making 20–22 lac in India should never even think of moving here if money's the reason. Come for a quality of life, a beautiful society that allows you to assimilate with it and of course, social benefits.What I don't like or rather miss here? My parents, my cousins n my friends. There's nothing like being with family n here, life's a little artificial. We get up in the morning, drop our kids to school, go to work, clean ice from the house n sleep. During weekends, wash clothes, go to nearby gardens n what, sleep again. I wasn't with my family this Holi n Diwali n I felt like crying.An advice to to all the newcomers, your future is surely bright here but initial months without family will be very tough n make you revisit your idea of settling here. Don't give up, find a job, get a house n then things will start setting down. Cheers guys!

Hello EveryOne : It’s been 4 months that I have moved to Canada as a Permanent Resident - the coveted tag that almost every other Punjabi is after these days. And, believe me - life here is not a bed of roses as everyone pictures from far.  And, there are plenty of reasons for the same: The cold weather!!! - As soon as you land, you feel the chill in the air (I felt it even when it was the ‘so called SUMMER” for Canadians - the month of May). I had to wear a jacket on the first weekend while going out with my friends.The laid back lifestyle - Trust me when I say that we people are far more active in our home countries than people in Canada. You see people with a far more laid back lifestyle and attitude in this part of the world. Job struggle - I pity those people who come to Canada and believe they can earn big bucks; especially those who leave their well-paying white-collar jobs in their country. Job struggle is immense here. Recruiting processes crawl at snail-speed. Forget about reaching to the recruiting phase, most of the employers will reject you because you don’t have the ‘Canadian work exprience’. It’s like a polite way of saying ‘screw your hard work and experience that you did in a multinational in your home country. Canadian work is above and beyond that!’Too many INDIANS - I am an Indian and I love my home country, but seriously if I had to get the feeling of living in the middle of India why would I move to Canada? There are so many Indians (especially Punjabis in the GTA and BC - the most livable parts of the country) that not even for a single day you will feel you are out of India. Just to add a little more, I’d like to share a few pics that will help explain these facts better. A picture in one of the meetings during the recent Election campaigning in Brampton. It is worth seeing that almost the entire hall is filled with Indians.  One of the advertisements I clickd while walking through the streets of Brampton. And, to end this post on a funny note, here’s something I hope you will read and enjoy  Text in the image: Sorry, you cannot come to Mumbai for the auditions.So what??? I can go to Canada!!! PS - for those of you who believe that getting a Canadian PR is the ultimate goal, here’s what I’d recommend you to definitely think!!! Text in the image: Dear God, is there something else beyond this as well???  PSS - No hard feelings, it is a personal choice. But, trust me it is not worth it to leave your friends, family, and life!!! Thank you, everyone, for such an overwhelming response to my answer. I did not expect it at all.  For all those who think that I hold something against Canada or people from my own country (so-called DESIS), well I don’t have anything against it. I simply mean to say that it is personal choice for everyone. I like the country, I like the calmness that it brings, and I love cleanliness. However, there are somethings which did not appeal to me, just like for many of you quite a number of things from back home do not appeal. It’s just my personal opinion and point of view. For all of those saying I should move back, well I will when the right time comes but it is not now. Canada is a beautiful country, but not for everyone, and not everything is laid here on a bed of roses, it has its own struggles that every country has.

Question is too subjective…. As every coin has two sides ,so there are aspects where I love being at Cold thrilling fast paced world while some attributes here make me regret my decision too. University of WaterlooIf you want to learn things more practically and one to be with some of the brightest minds, you would never regret this decision. But sometimes being with brilliant minds makes you feel depressed. Everyone in my class is good at varied things so you just push yourself to thrive every single day and motivates you till you achieve your full potential. 2.New Friends Well, to be honest in a bag full of mangoes,you will get few rotten mangoes too. If you get everything sorted then you are not giving a chance for probability to exist. Overall, we have mixed culture at the University and most of them are highly intellectual and helpful too, but most are nerds😅. 3.Missing Home and Family. A person who talks once a week with parents cannot show them that he misses them but only he knows the reality 😉.To be away from someone you love ,is a great feeling, everyone must experience once. 4.Weather This is one aspect which I really dislike about Canada.Well, in the morning I was at University without sweaters as Sun was out ,but that evening I realized something that Sun was out and rain gods are in full mood with wind wanting to contribute its own part. So, weather at Canada is like a chameleon. Overall, its mixed feeling but 3/4 points are making me happy ,so I would not regret moving Canada as of now atleast.

Not a tiny bit. Moving to Canada was the best decision I ever made. I never respond to questions but since I saw all the negative comments from people I wanted to come and say that the grass it’s not black on this side. I love Canada. I am from Venezuela and I initially moved here for school. Went to college and had a part time job. I started doing sacrifices and nothing was handed to me, which made getting to where I am today so much better. I worked hard and have a great job, have an awesome boyfriend (who is Canadian), have amazing coworkers and thankfully a better environment than anywhere else. The people in the comments that said that they regret moving here it’s because they were expecting to get here, be rich and get the best jobs. That’s not how it works and if that is your mentality, stay put. An immigrant in Canada should be hard working person who is willing to climb the ladder and get to the top. I hope this can answer your question and honestly, if you move here and you like cold weather, lots of snow, hot summers, beautiful two weeks of fall, pretty lakes and cottages, delicious multicultural food and great amazing people, Canada is the right place for you.

Personally I never moved to Canada, I was raised here. I don’t regret being in Canada. I live in Markham, near the GTA. To be honest, there are more Asians than there are Indians. I got used to the cold weather, just put some warm clothing. I get to experience diversity and culture around the world. Cold winter is not summer for Canadians because that is a stereotype, we don’t say “eh” a lot and we do say sorry. But we may have job struggles but not a lot as America. It is not like America where there are a LOT of shootings, even though we have a FEW cases. But overall we don’t have Trump as our PM. There are education struggles, for example, I wanted to be either an IT support, art therapist, or an animator but yet there is not a lot of universities nor colleges near me, they are usually either in a 1 - 4-hour range to get there. This is coming from a Grade 10 student by the way. So my opinions are not as accurate to those who just move here in Canada. When it comes to winter, just go get some winter coats and warm clothing, go to Tim Hortons or Starbucks, get a hot or warm drink and hold it and drink it. I’m going to drink maple syrup now…I have a strange problem… don’t judge me.

NO. Not at all. At least until now. I moved to Canada 9 months back and so far I am enjoying my time here. The points below are based on a couple of things: I am in Montreal and this is my first time outside my home country. It’s a beautiful place: Here I am not comparing it to any European country or any other place since I haven't been there. It’s just an incomparable thought. There are few pics at the end of the answer that I clicked and found it beautiful.Welcoming people: As I mentioned, I am in Montreal where French is the dominant language and me and my wife don't even know a single word of French. We are from a completely different culture so lacks basic Montreal (or Westerners) etiquette. Still, we never felt any sort of discrimination. Many of my colleagues from Montreal are quite fascinated towards my home country as well and ask many questions to know about the culture whenever they get a chance.Work-life balance: While I was working in my home country, I somehow was not able to manage my work-life balance and rarely get time to spend with my family. After moving here, its much more sorted. One of the reasons is the work culture here, where your timings are fixed and you are not expected to stay longer than that.Transportation: I think Montreal has one of the best public transportation facilities in Canada. It’s way better than the city I was living in my home country.Free healthcare: Canada offers free healthcare services. I used it a couple of times and the experience was quite good. There are walk-in clinics and emergency rooms for urgent needs. There is a possibility of appointing a family doctor for free but the wait time for that is quite long.There are some things which are hard for many (as I found out in many answers below) : Harsh Winters: Winters are really harsh. I read a lot about it before coming here and one of my first tasks after coming here to prepare myself for it by getting good winter clothing, sturdy snow shoes, caps etc. I survived one winter with these preparations and I think I would be able to survive the next. Expensive: I don't agree, it's expensive here (at least in Montreal). You just don't need to convert everything into your local currency. When I came here, for the first 2 months, I was converting everything to my local currency and that gave me a mini heart-attack. Somehow, I realized it and now I think the cost of living is pretty okay. So far Im taking pleasure in my stay right here. There have been specific instances, where I found a few things that have been not good or otherwise not as much as my objectives, but I attempted giving them another opportunity with a new viewpoint so far that worked. Incorporate an open brain and you may enjoy around the globe. As mentioned previously, a couple of pictures of Montreal, Quebec - Canada.

Yes. I regret how the poor are treated in this Canada and am saddened by the fact that our welfare and safety nets aren't cast very wide any more and the rising poverty and homelessness in the cities. I wish that our politicians would stop pandering to baby boomers (e.g. with super-low interest rates, tax-free savings accounts and large RRSP contribution limits, favourable dividends & capital gains taxes as compared to income) and start favouring the poorest of the poor instead with guaranteed funding arrangements for food banks, a basic minimum income top-up and a real anti-homelessness strategy, with a commensurate increase in spaces in training colleges for mental health specialists and in specific training for addiction management within those programs. Also there is a pressing need for more hospital beds in the biggest city in the country. At least a few more hospitals are needed especially since the reorientation of growth after the Places To Grow Act came in. We could also use a massive rebuild of our city-run community housing.

Arrived in 2009 from Eastern Europe. Some expectations were met, others not. The challenge with getting info ahead of time is that all those whom I asked prior of my arrival and in the beginning of my life here, were different than me: language, profession,age, ideals,reasons why they left,gender, marital status, their arrival period, the need for certain workers in different seasons. Overall, I’m happy with my decision. Two things I’m not happy as I wished: 1) children education. My perception of TDSB is not high for these reasons:a) teacher can make or break the time your kid has in school, you can’t find good teachers everywhere and in the same school they are different in knowledge and in the passion to teach kids. b) our daughter lost interest as the teacher gave more attention to kids who have challenges than to those who were well. So if you want kids to go beyond average send them to private courses. So public school is free, but your child education is expensive. 2) as someone who was raised in an ex-communist country, coming in Canada I found a different type of restriction regarding the freedom of speech. The government imposes certain regulations that you should agree or shut up, specially in work-space environment where “spies” were everywhere. Looks like we are not so free to debate ideas, if the government decides what is right and wrong. The worst is the Ontario Human Rights Commission - looks to me like the Soviet judges who can make your life a misery of you say something they consider a violation. In the end, if you can, don’t live in Toronto. Its so big and a lot of your time will be consumed in traffic.

Absolutely! I live in a full democracy with a better job & higher pay than I had in the US (which is now considered a “flawed democracy”), I have access to a universal health care plan that doesn’t cost anything at point of service (my father spent more than a decade trying to pay off what his health insurance didn’t cover on my mother’s last illness). My head of state is not an international laughing stock & is unlikely to start WWIII. My taxes are not spent on invading small countries, executing people who may be innocent, or keeping women from having abortions if they need one; nor is any Canadian politician trying to spend my taxes on a useless, environmentally destructive wall. Canada isn’t perfect, but it is an improvement.

Yes and I left after a year. I'm European with engineering degree, top MBA and several years of international work experience. In Europe, when I wanted to change job I got interviews with multinationals for jobs at what I consider my level (seniority and experience). In Canada, recruiters told me directly that their clients wanted candidates with "Canadian experience" and that was the end of the calls. On the other hand, I had recruiters contancting me for low level jobs (telesales, help desk, etc.) saying that they saw my CV online and it was a great match. It was quite depressing that in Europe I worked in consulting and multinationals but in Canada I was considered like a high school dropout. I hear people saying that I should have toughed it out, take any menial job for some months, study an extra degree, etc. but why would I have to go through that when in many developed countries in the world my credentials are well regarded and I can get a proper job in short time and applying from abroad. Bottom line, I had to spend a lot of money and time to move to Canada to be considered an unskilled worker, but other countries with the same quality of life will hire me directly from abroad and pay for my relocation expenses.

No, I have never for even a second regretted moving to Canada. I have been here for 47 years. I arrived alone, 21 years old, knew nobody , had $169 in my pocket, nowhere to live but I had a job to go to - a minimum wage job. I landed in Vancouver after a terrible journey due to an air traffic control strike that had me arrive at 3am with no place to go. The flight attendants discovered my problem and drove me to the YWCA for the night. Next day I walked out onto the streets of Vancouver and I knew I had found my true home and I have never lost that belief. I found a place to live started my job and 3 months later met the man I ended up marrying. I didn’t get rich, that didn’t interest me and was not why I came here . I came to find the freedom to believe in what I wanted to believe in, freedom from the oppression of religion, freedom to be true to my own beliefs. I have lived an ordinary life but every day I am thankful to be here, to live surrounded by such beauty, to be among friendly people, to row out on a beautiful lake, cast a fly and sometimes catch a fat trout and sometimes just enjoy the beauty of nature and the peace and quiet. I feel incredibly lucky and indeed privileged to call Canada my home and native land.

It was the dumbest decision in my life. I moved to Canada 3 years ago as LGBTQ refugee, and i was fooled by the human rights bs. I left behind a house, good financial status, running business and high social position. I have spent almost all my savings just to provide myself decent living. After being a manager and owner with 70 employees working for me the only jobs i can get is minimum wage. For what? Just to be an openly gay person and get married and establish a good life but that wasn't the case. The weather is depressing, money has no value here,constant rise in crime rates, drugs epidemic Imagine the average home price in Toronto is 700000 dollars. If i have the chance to go back home i would pack up my luggage right now but i can't, otherwise i will get prosecuted for seeking protection of other country and my sexuality. The 3rd world continues are developing and cost of living is relatively low. Anyone who has a decent income my advice is just stay where you are.

This is a hard one to answer as you regret that decision at times, and don't at other times. Professionally, Canada is a very limited country with a small number of business employers compared to the US. Also, Canada has most jobs in only the largest metros such as GTA, GMA, GVA. Only oil specialists go to Calgary/Edmonton. One has to come to terms with the fact that you have a country bigger than the US but with opportunities smaller than a state like California. All the 'Canadian experience' and other discrimination is a result of the smaller economic engine that Canada is. The higher taxes also is another aberration that we do not think about. Imagine maintaining the infrastructure of the US with just California taxes. That is unfortunately Canada. Unlike Southern US, which does not have its winter overheads, Canada does, for its entire territory. While all this explanation is useless to someone looking for a job and gets discriminated in the job market, over time, I have realized the true cause of Canadian behavior in the workplace is driven by these two factors - smaller economic and tax base for a huge country. However, there is a social aspect that can satisfy some - a peaceful, free (boring at times) civil society that lets you be productive, if you keep your sights low and not have huge career aspirations.

“Do you regret moving to Canada?” I had no choice, though I regret that it changed with my childhood.To be more clear, I was around seven or eight when my parents informed me we were moving to Canada. During this time, we were living in a modest home somewhere in Ariel, Israel. I was also beginning to improve at… Everything. Writing, reading, all school subjects. Not just those, I began to understand more things like politics, geography etc. I didn’t care much for the change, but little did I know how much it’d mess with my brain. A while after that, we eventually moved. I had no clear answers as to why, though I didn’t care. We moved, and I eventually came to find that the transition would actually be rougher than I originally thought. i had to learn an entirely new language, geography, culture and just in general the unspoken rules of Canada. I managed to learn English in a fairly short amount of time. Around 6 months, to be exact. I had some help from some tutors who had no idea on how to speak Hebrew, so it was up to me to understand and learn. I got progressively better and better as time passed, so much so that I speak better than most of my classmates. Though the new language was easier, I was unable to learn the provinces here, the political system and anything else a Canadian deems “normal” to know. To this day, I still do not know any of the provinces or any of that stuff, although I am legally deemed a Canadian Citizen. Moving really messed with my ability to learn about this new country, mostly because I didn’t really care for it much. And I am, to this day, unable to learn about my country, though I’m only 14, so I have high hopes for that to change.

I sort of regret. yes.. I used to live in the US.. Went back to India and lived with my family… I thought I could try canada for sometime but this place sucks you out and drains you If you dont have a network of friends and family… I did get a good job without much effort in a year or so… But, it took a toll on me as I thought that American experience would be respected.. THERE IS TOO MUCH NEPOTISM AND CRONYISM IN CANADA THAT IT BEATS INDIA! it is expensive here.. Housing in GTA is appaling. I wanted to be free of attachments- like car but without that it is hard to manage except in core downtown.. medical care is an eye wash. without a good job, and the insurance that comes with it, nothing is covered. In the process, I have lost muscle mass - completely out of shape thanks to all the stress..(due to this terrible weather and not being able to adjust; initial settling down stress etc..) I lost tons of hair.. wrinkles :( over all not a good decision.

Im going to give a simple if not satisfying answer unlike some of them over here. I moved to Canada 3 months ago after getting my PR. Now I had dreams and hopes, oh it’s gonna be clean, they are respectful, the jobs have certain procedures unlike India. Well to cut a long story short. I’m living in Vancouver now in a decent part of the city, I have a good job, make more money than i could have with my degree. I am starting to make friends too. The public transport system has some quirks but it cant be perfect i guess. In terms of open ness to immigration, ive had/heard seen more white people speak hindi than i have ever, its fascinating how they have started imbibing our culture. Almost like a void that they know they have and we can fill. It’s quite amazing to see. The big cities are pretty open to immigrants maybe smaller places are a problem(I dont know). Over that it’s all better than the US in terms of how people interact and are polite. It’s a really great place, the natural beauty is tops too. Also way less advertising, mcdonalds, or fast food joints. Asian cuisine is very good, great chinese places and japanese places. So no regrets till now. Leaving people and family behind, yeah for sure. But I was ready for those sacrifices.

I moved to Halifax, Nova Scotia from the Buffalo, NY area. I find the people to be much friendlier than in my home town, much safer, and growing in prominence and diversity. I read with disdain regarding people who come to this wonderful country and then complain about things such as weather or taxes! If you apply to Canada, did you not do your basic homework and research the weather? Don’t complain that you hate the cold! Many people enjoy winter sports! I personally am not fond of long winters, but I travel to Mexico as I am retired! Canada does not have one weather setting. Vancouver and Victoria, BC are much like Seattle and Halifax where I reside is similar to N. Maryland and milder than Buffalo! Taxes in NY state are higher than here in Canada. My proof: I got a refund for two years! Also, medical deductions are much more generous! I get fatigued reading some people’s rants. If you aren’t happy in Canada, why did you move here! Do everyone a favour and return to your paradise! Why did you leave it?

In case you cannot survive the cold weather, yes you will regret moving to Canada; else, it is good to live here in Canada. It’s almost five years of me staying here, and it feels like “HOME.” The thing is you have made the decision, then why regret it! If you don’t like something, then change it, or you need to change yourself. As simple as it is! There are certain days, or you can say things which I also hate about Canada, which is its Weather. Yes, you are right! I am not fond of winters too. You will get to see the whole area covered with snow sheet and the worst part you need to walk every day to work in this cold.  But some things help you to be relaxed and enjoy your life in Canada. The first and foremost is the healthcare system. I know it is not perfect as compared to other countries, or you can say India. But, here people value their lives, and they work to stay fit and lively. Second is a friendly and supportive environment. People are kind and warm and show their friendly nature whenever you need them. You will love the clean air, beauty, and calmness of this country when you start living here.  I feel a love-hate relationship with this place. I have good memories and bad memories, as well as living here. I am comfortable here and scared of getting out of my comfort zone! It is good to live here and work. The second home I have made, first, is prominent INDIA!

Yes, I wish I had never come. I feel like I have wasted 10 years of my life ! I have made many efforts to have a meaningful life but nothing good or worthwhile came out of it. I haven’t met any interesting men, just extremely superficial and not interested in building anything serious on a private level. Outside daily responsibilities, my life is so boring. I have a hard time meeting genuine people. Nothing really deep or meaningful is ever found. The transit system is expensive and obsolete. Food is outrageously expensive. Alcohol is ridiculously expensive too and could not be bought outside LCBO until recently when the rest of the world has that option for as long as I can remember. It’s cold most of the year so it’s difficult or impossible to play sports except skiing and ice-skating . For all those reasons I want to leave but don’t really know where to go? Maybe find a country in Europe…

NO. NON. NEVER. NADA. NOPE. NEIN. 没有. Does Canada have its issue? yes. Which country doesn't. Does Canada have a racism problem? Yes, which developed nation doesn't? But i'll still take Canada any day compared to my native Cameroon or the USA or Europe or anywhere else. Canada is coooold during the winter, but safe, peaceful, tolerant, beautiful, clean, spacious, not gun crazy, most people are respectful and cool. There are still some jerks and racists, but they are ashamed to show it and are clouded by good people. I could live in the USA and earn big bucks because of my software engineering degree and experience, but no thank you. Whenever I travel to the USA, I can feel the tension in the air. It is as if you are one mistake away from being shot by cops or overzealous fake Patriots or robbers. I never felt that way in Canada, never ever. Thank you Cold Canada. I'll take the cold and peace of mind any day. You can't get better than that anywhere else. Canadian National Parks in Alberta:  Canada in Real Time

I thank my parents every year, on the anniversary of our immigration to Canada. They gave up a paid home, comfort, pension, career, friends, family, language… and the basic necessities that I take for granted now and before immigrating… for the safety and future of their kids (I was the oldest).  I will be grateful to my dying day. Last year was the 40th anniversary of the plane landing in Toronto. Previously I had lived in Argentina, and Italy. I have visited dozens of countries, been to every continent except Africa.  I have turned down huge money to live in other countries because I rather have less money (and to give some context: I presently work two jobs - had I moved I would have retired 10 years ago) but be able to raise my kids Canadian. I am hard core on this.  Is the country perfect? No way. It is not. We can elect idiots just as well as anybody else can. At all levels of government. We have for years, on and off. But we are also allowed to say this without getting shot, or ostracized in the workplace. Think about that. And regardless of whoever is in power, you can work, be educated, save for a house, walk about freely, and access hospitals. That is no small thing.

A lot of these answers seem to be coming from people who moved to Toronto or Vancouver, where getting settled can be a lot harder because of the housing costs (I'm guessing anyway). I moved to Calgary almost 12 years ago, and don't regret it for a minute. Yes, I had to take a step backwards in my career because of the lack of Canadian experience, but I've made that up again now. The winters can be brutally cold, but I've learned that you just keep piling on layers and can manage quite easily (and I get transit so I'm standing outside for 5 to 10 minutes at a time). Transit in Calgary is mostly geared towards getting you in to downtown, so you may have to change to get to where you want. However, it's reasonably priced ($110 per month for a pass) and mostly reliable. Housing isn't cheap, but it's not out of reach to buy if you're realistic. A minimum wage job would get you in to a low priced rental, if you have two working adults on more than minimum, you should be fine. Education is pretty good. The city has been growing rapidly, so some areas have to have their kids bussed or driven to school. However in the established areas they mostly have schools within a short distance until at least high school - and a 15 year old should be able to figure out how to get a bus. Overall, I love it here. I came from the UK, and I'd never want to move back. I'm dual citizenship now, I was granted Canadian citizenship several years ago after fulfilling the requirements. I travel on my Canadian passport even back to the UK though, as I think of myself as Canadian first now.

I want to say no, but secretly the answer is yes, I regret it a little. I moved 8 years ago from the UK to Toronto. Canada has become my home, however for years - and even now - I don’t really feel like I belong. At the same time, I have become so “Canadianized”/“Americanized” that when I go back to the UK I feel I don’t fit there either. Perhaps it’s that a city like Toronto is so multicultural that it is a place of continuous cultural flux. I find it hard to connect to other people on a deep meaningful level. This is complaint I’ve heard from both immigrants and born-Canadians alike. Also, the fact that people were occasionally amused by my British accent was fun at first. Now it is a constant source of annoyance at having to answer the same damn questions about football over and over again. I know NOTHING about soccer, leave me alone! In the next few years I will try Montréal. I like how rough around the edges and insulting the Québécois can be to us anglophones, so I plan to learn French and insult them back :P

Answering on behalf of the friend Recently one of my friends moved to Canada after getting PR even though I asked her countless times to go for Australia. Now she regrets her decision a lot due to these reasons: Extreme cold: The weather sometimes drop to -16 and even more. She didn't even took such clothes to manage that. Now she can’t buy as she is struggling for Job. Had to enroll herself in MS program as per her consultant she wont be able to find a good job w/o it: Wastage of money for me at least, when you have a PR in hand , still you have been treated like someone on student visa. Canadians ask a degree that is earned from there only to hire you. That’s her case, I am not sure how are other’s experiences. My sister was completely forbid by my nanu to apply immigration for Canada due to weather conditions: Yes, that is true as being the citizen of Canada he could help her. At first she was hurt but now she appreciates his honesty as weather in Australia is quite great for Asians like us. Additionally, they eventually got hired within a month. This is the power of PR there. Thats all I had to share :)

I moved from London in 2002 and do not regret my decision one bit. We had 2 very young children( 2 & 4) and just could not see a future them in the UK. Today, they are 18 and 20. They have an outstanding secondary school education and are now both enrolled in one of Canada’s foremost Universities. When people bitch about Canada’s taxes they ignore some very salient facts: Canada’s taxes are a bit more that USA. 32% of GDP vs 28% of GDP.Canada offers much, much better value which is seldom mentioned.Canada’s secondary education is good. In America, secondary education has essentially collapsed. Many parents now spend $US20k per year on private schools.A University degree in USA costs around $US200K. In Canada it is around $US25k.Healthcare is free at the point of delivery for everyone. In USA, the healthcare system is the purview of the wealthy and well insured.Yes, it is cold here, and yes, it does get tiring living with never ending winter. However, I have a quality of life which I could never, ever could have afforded if I had stayed in the UK. I have a 6 bedroom house on 2 acres. I can see the rocky Mountains from my kitchen window. I can get to the ski hill in 50 minutes, and in the summer can go camping in pristine wilderness. I am happy to be a Canadian

Yes, I regret moving to Canada and that's why I decided to go back to my country. I moved to Halifax Nova Scotia and life in Canada is not as easy as everyone else says. My advice to everyone who wants to move to Canada is to go there for one month and see how is that country before taking the decision to move there. Finding a job there is not easy, even more if you are an engineer, a lawyer, or any other professional degree; so forget about that because in Canada you will have to take survival jobs, your degree is junk for them. The process for the residency is terribly long and burocratic, so migrating to other countries is much easier. Don't believe in all the lies that people say about Canada (I committed that mistake so I know what I'm talking about), go there and see it for yourself. My advice is to think in the US before Canada.

Out of interest I read many of these reviews. Truth be told, EVERY COUNTRY HAS ITS CRAPPY ASS M*****RF*****RS AND SAINTS, AS WELL AS EVERYTHING IN BETWEEN. Thankfully, society exists because it works better when we all get along. Prior to moving to any country, you should do a little research. I moved away from Canada 13 years ago, and was presented with an opportunity to return. Prior to returning, I turned to the world’s most valuable reference: Google. I researched property. Very easy to examine real estate prices in Vancouver, Calgary, Edmonton, Torontogroceries. Very easy to examine groceries prices and compare what I buy here (UK) to thereutilities. Very easy to compare prices to utilities. I know what I use/spend here, easy to compute theretransportation. Very easy to find price of car here/there, as well as insurance/gas.What did I find: Canada lots of driving is required bc public transportation is pathetic (compared to London).Groceries are much more expensive bc need to add GST/PST (tax) to all prices, bc govt is stupid and you do not pay what you see.
