Skiing. skating. shovelling snow. clearing ice. skating around the rink.Things relating to people are the same in every country I have worked/visited, which I said in my first sentence above

After almost 20 years of Canada, my only regret is that I should move here earlier. When you are in your 40's and start a new life is difficult. But when your child 25 years old buys his own Cadillac CTS-V, you feel that all your frustration paid off. It worth every single bit of frustration I got. Was not easy to adapt, but nothing is easy when you are out of your culture. Bottom line, immigrating is not for the faint of heart. Be ready to go low and start all over. I see now tons of locals who live bellow my standard of living. Should I feel proud? Yes. I had the same tools as they had, they had 20 years ahead of me to build a life and are bellow me. I got nothing especial from the guvernment, just the legal right to live and work here. But the law makes no discrimination. If you have something to offer the society will reward. Answering again, no I don't regret at all.

People move usually in search of jobs or problems in their home countries. In a way, moving is the problem in itself. You are obligated to move if you want a life. You never forget your home country, its culture the people you leave behind. It is one of the reasons I do not understand the reaction against immigrants in the States where all of the population has immigrated from somewhere through the ages. When you immigrate you choose if you can, the country where you think you are going to be well received, well respected, find a good job and live to raise a family. Here in Canada, we found all that and more. We have an extremely good life here. Friends we love, politics with which we agree, more or less, almost no violence, a superb country that we visited from East to West. We are proud Canadians. It does not mean that we forgot about our home country. In fact, we visit it every year, we have kept our relationship with the extended family who came to visit us several times. I do not think that our experience is unique.

Yes and no, Yes, it really impacted my kids and myself tremendously, the first three years were tough, my kids (teenagers then) really suffered, this is a very individualist society (by Mexican standards anyway), and we are just emotionally coming to terms with that by creating our own small circle of friends and family Financially, best decision hands down, in Mexico salaries are a shame, government is corrupt and social security is, to put it nicely, not even a tenth as good, So, overall, I don’t regret it, but definitely wasn’t easy, would I do it again? Definitely,

How can I answer this question? I am Canadian born. My parents were born here. My Grandparents were born here. This is my home and native land! I do wonder why there are so many people who immigrate to Canada and then have regrets. Do they not do their homework and research my country before coming here? What are they looking for and what do they expect? My ancestors all migrated here because conditions in England and Scotland were grim. I have Scottish ancestors who were cleared from their land. I have English ancestors who couldn’t make a decent living there. I have ancestors who lived in Soddy huts on the prairies in Saskatchewan before it was a province. People who come to Canada expecting a high paying job are likely doomed for disappointment. Nor is Canada a portal to the USA. We are two separate countries and societies sharing the continent. Anyone is welcome, provided they meet the criterion established by the Immigration Department. But do your homework first. Don’t believe any promises except hard work and sacrifice until you become established. That will likely take years.

Im loving Canada as a new immigrant. Anyway depending on where you moved from to canada. I came to canada from a 3rd world country almost lawless. I dont regret a thing about moving to canada. Honestly I never experience racism and the opportunities are endless here if you are kind to people, smart and hardworking. Immigrants often forget why they left their motherland in the first place. Ofcourse it's not easy. You are in a completely new playing field. In canada there is a rule of law so if you're doing the right thing chances are very law that you will be harassed by police or by government officials when try to get something done. People are very decent they most of the time mind their own business unless you're harming someone's privacy or if you're harming the norm of Canada. I'm thankful for Canada for having a system to let people come here and live a decent life.

It's been 2 months since I moved to Canada, Nova Scotia province . Well in last 2 months I say so far so good. I am located in Halifax I got myself a job within 2 weeks of landing , although background verification took another month before I could actually join work. I found myself an apartment ( took a cheaper apartment as I was unsure of my job while landing ) I also did my landing procedures within a week of landing ( SIN, health card, bank account, sim card, driving lisence, etc) while residing in Airbnb based accommodation. What's my take on this being a PNP ( provincial nomination candidate) I don't regret any of it . I have a decent job with decent wage, also I would like to add my job profile is almost same as I had that in India. I am currently positive about my future prospects here. Loving the change . Not to mention the benefits that we have of being a parmanent resident of Canada we all know it that's why we applied

Nope. I moved here 5 years ago from Russia, and I must say - that was the best decision in my life. I think some, who moved here from Western Europe, may regret, but not me, nah. Canada is the first place in my life that I can call home. Have been feeling it since day one. Nice country with nice people. The nature is gorgeous. It’s a bit slow here, though, and some things may seem a bit obsolete (at first the obsession of locals with sending faxes amused me). But it’s a question of habits. Time flies, and now everything seems so cosy and natural to me. Sometimes I wish we had more art museums and historical places here. But that’s Canada, alright? The country is quite young and has its own flaws. For the history cravings it’s better to visit Europe, and then return back home to Canada. :)

No regrets… !!! Moving to Canada from a third world country and earning handsome salary is always a big dream of any immigrant. However, one need to understand the circumstances first. First of all you need right direction and guidance from those who are already living here. Secondly, you should dream big and should not give up. With a little courage and investment you can be as successful in Canada as other Canadians. Third most important thing is building a social network and professional contacts. Another important thing is building an impressive resume and strategies to apply for a job. I am always available to assist new comers in guiding them towards right direction. Most important thing to consider living in Canada is; One of the most Peaceful Country.Very less or no discrimination.Super Friendly people.Excellent Law and order and Justice system.

I moved from London UK to Vancouver 25 years ago. I have not regretted it for one minute. It was the best move I have ever made. I love my life here. I was fortunate to get a good job but it did take a while and a lot of searching but once established there was no looking back. Canadian winter does not come here. We get snow for perhaps a week a year. Winter temperatures around 5c. It does rain a lot in the Winter but this makes a lot of snow in the mountains for skiing and snowshoeing. Vancouver is a beautiful city. Life here is easy. People are very friendly compared to London. The best part of the lifestyle is outdoors ie hiking, kayaking, sailing, skiing, biking etc. All very close to the city. Eating out is not expensive. There are a plethora of Chinese, Japanese, Vietnamese and other restaurants as well as the north american generic restaurants and of course fast food. Accommodation is expensive. Vancouver is a very ethnically divers city with peoples from all over the world living very harmoniously. It is really quite inspiring. Outside of the Vancouver metropolitan area there are mountains, trees, rivers, lakes and not much else. BC is very sparsely populated.

I do not regret moving away from home and experiencing a new life. But I do regret choosing Canada over Europe. Here are a few things I am sure the responses, especially the ones from those who have ‘just’ moved here and likely wrote the comments in their ‘high’ of traveling do not cover. Canada is Good country .his foods really awesome and tastyHis peoples was GreatNice Things watching in Canada Europe : People are nice, but not all, further explained in cons.Society is more tolerant of immigrants.Gun laws are stringent, and gun violence is almost non existent.Immigration is easy.You will not feel alone, there are people from all ethnicity.Racism exists but is not to the levels that it will suffocate you.Medical costs are low, you still need insurance for dental, vision, and prescription coverage though.

No! This is not going to be a rags-to-riches story. The reason why I don’t regret moving to Canada is because the reason to move was mine. I was aware of the hustle I had to put in as Canada would not have laid out a red carpet for me. After I started my fall semester in ‘18, I looked for a part-time job and it took me four months to land a job. I finally started to work on my university campus in January’19 but I kept the hustle going. I am currently studying full-time, working full-time as a co-op student, taking part-time shifts on the weekend and devoting my time to the student council that I am a part of. Moving to a new country is a decision that should be yours and yours alone. You should be ready to put in the hustle, pay your dues and be patient to get rewarded for it. As a lot of people have said it before- If you can’t handle the heat, get out of the kitchen.

Well, I think this would be a very subjective answer, based on what the person has experienced in Canada. Based on my personal experiences, I have not regretted a single day after moving to Canada. The country is absolutely clean, the medical expenses are paid for by the government (even surgeries), education system is top notch, public schooling is free and the country overall is just so damn beautiful. After I graduated from my MBA from the University of Calgary, I found a job after two months in Banking. The work environment is laid back and not as stressed as in India. I guess the people who are bashing Canada have had bad experiences in the country but if you do not want to struggle and think that everything is just going to come to you..please stay in India. I mean, what were you expecting, that the Prime Minister would come greet you at the airport and people would clap for you when you arrive? No risk no reward!! The weather is cold but it beats the boiling temperatures we have back home in India. I would prefer snow any day. All homes are centrally heated anyway and public transport is pretty good. It really boils down to personal preference. If you don’t want to fight for a better life..don’t come here.

I have been in Canada for about one year and a half, and I do not regret moving here. I am a student here, and I would like to list my thoughts of life in Canada for the past year I lived in Canada. Canada is a sparsely populated country. I am from China, a country featured for its huge population. In the Province I am living, there is only 1 million people, which is just equivalent to the scale of a large county in China.Canada is a country of immigration. Especially at university, there are a lot of international students and a substantial part of these students intends to immigrate to Canada. And for graduate students, most of them are international students from China, Iran, India, and other countries. There are few native white people pursuing master or doctorate degrees.It is so cold in winter. It has a long winter here, almost 7 months every year. There are only two seasons here, summer and winter. Last year, I spent my first winter here, and it shocked me by its extremely cold weather. It is almost lower than -40 degrees in the coldest days.

The short answer is no. I was not happy at all when my parents moved us to Canada when I was 17 but overall we have a much better lifestyle. There is beautiful scenery, lots of opportunities for outdoor sports and activities and it’s a fairly relaxed pace (compared to England). The cost of living is also less. My friends are always blown away by how much bigger our house is for the same or less than theirs and we always get sticker shock when back in the UK. There are some things I definitely miss about England and Europe though. I miss the social aspect of living in a place that is smaller. Everyone is closer and somehow get together more frequently. Perhaps that is only my personal experience…. The pub culture in England is definitely a part of this too. I miss the history and culture. I’m not a museum goer but just walking down a street in most European/British places is filled with architecture and stories. That is missing in such a new country as Canada. I miss the English winters. While it’s great to be able to snowboard in Canada (if you’re going to be cold, you may has well enjoy it), I hate being SO cold for SO long. Just taking out the garbage is a serious pain in the backside!

I was born in Canada and have lived here all my life. I don’t regret that at all. Oh, Sweden or the UK might have been nice with their social programs, and a warm tropical climate might be better for my health, but I’m pretty comfortable with things here overall. I live in a nice small city with a decent amount of services and low cost of living. Low crime rate, decent people. Quiet night life but that’s ok with me. Climate is the main drawback. Hot summers, cold winters. Too many thunderstorms with global warming make my sinuses really hurt. But no place on earth would be perfect in that regard. Warm and moderately dry but not too dry, with occasional showers to freshen things up and dampen down any pollen, would be best. Honestly, I’d give life here a 7/10. It would have been higher a few years ago before our health services were gutted and our provincial bus service scrapped. As I can’t drive, that’s an important consideration.

Two lines of thought, positive first: For the most part, friendly and welcoming, with wonderful diversity. If you tend to be social by nature, a good part of the world to enjoy. Speaking mainly of Vancouver, there's always something happening. Great beaches, nice lakes wonderful hikes, so much choice, plus all the gigs down town and elsewhere else. MSP's affordable for working people. I'm surprised that the unemployed still have to pay it! The Whitecaps are heading to the top of the league, what more can you ask for? Negatives: A bit of an obviouse one, the cost of living in relation to typical salaries. The relationship becomes more tenuous every day, especially when you throw into the mix the cost of housing. For ordinary working folk the thought of owning a house has gone from dream to fantasy. Allowing foriegn buyers to buy up just so much here hasn't helped. Except for a few token taxes, the BC government's looked the other way. So without getting too political, there's the oversized bluebottle in the ointment. It sounds funny to say that other than that everything's cool, when the cost of property, rentals, and the cost of living's so significant. However, if you can navigate your way round those societal cornerstones, not a bad part of the world at all. Je ne regrettes pas

Moving to Canada is like moving to any other developed nation. Unless you have local contacts in your area of expertise, getting “local experience” will be a challenge. It is particularly difficult for professionals, architects, dentists, engineers, lawyers, medical doctors as they will need to have foreign credentials recognized and this may require taking additional courses, doing internship-type training, etc. My friends tell me that it is easier to find meaningful work in the U.S (perhaps they have better contacts there) but easier to immigrate to Canada. I am Canadian with Canadian degrees but when I came back to Canada in 1993 after working abroad for 2 years, it took me nearly two years to find meaningful employment and nearly 7 before I found work in an area connected with my area of principle study. It is not easy moving to a foreign country; on average I would say that meaningful settlement, getting a good job, learning one of our two official languages, and becoming comfortable in you new homeland, takes about 5 years. In that same time, the immigrant has also acquired Canadian citizenship and a Canadian passport That compares to decade or more, to get U.S Citizenship

Absolutely not… Moving to Canada was a great decision. But like any decision, it has to be planned. From a financial perspective, understanding the market and adapting to the new life. I did not find a job the first year, but I did find a job at the end of the year. I moved to 3 different places but each move was better than the previous one. I made friends, I created a social life, I enjoyed the country. Canada has given me what no other place has ever given me, and that is the opportunity to be equal to everyone else and compete with others in a fair way. I managed to go to school at night, taking night classes. I made an effort to blend in the new society and the country helps you in doing that every step of the way. Canada was great to me and my family and I appreciate how this country opened their arms for us when no one else did, and for that I am eternally grateful.

No, I’m happy to be here. I read the endless complaints and just think, “that’s not me.” But I also read the complaints and know exactly what they are talking about. The cost of housing is too high. The cost of everything is too high. It’s a cold country. Infrastructure has to be maintained in horrendous conditions. It costs a lot to live here. So long story short, if you can’t play in the cold, don’t come to Canada. The weather will aways be what it is. My father was born in Georgia in the U.S. I never saw him swim in a Canadian lake. My kids swam in glacial pools and kettle lakes. We swam in the north within weeks of the ice melting off the water. It’s not for everyone. But if you’re tough enough, it offers a great life.

It's depends on where you're moving from and what was your situation in your previous country of residence. Pros: Clean fresh air, water and electricityPresence of green spaceRelatively safePresence of government supportOpportunity for growthLack of political turmoil and ethnic clashesCons: WeatherSet back on your career pathBusy lifestyle and lack of social capitalFinding employment can be hardEven the cities are a bit too quite(And yes. A bit of discrimination)Canadians are generally really nice and helpfull people. Basically it all depends on the type of person you are and how you handle situations. If you already have a family over here, perfect! If you are escaping war, it's great. If you didn't have a good job where you came from and are willing to work really hard, that's awesome. It always takes a while to settle down in a new place, it might take longer depending on your personality type. But if you already had a life in your previous country and are a extroverted person who likes lively places, moving here might be a bad idea.

Yes, I am regretting it now. Moved from US with a decent pay job offer. Things are quite different here, depending on where you are migrating from: high taxes, high cost of living - basically you earn in CAD but pay US equivalent prices ( i.e things are roughly 30% more expensive), long wait for basic medical services, brutal winters, gun violence is becoming common in some cities. It is better to spend your productive part of your life in US and then retire here…

Not at all. Here in Canada, your talent doesn’t have price. It has worth. People recognize it and respect it. Culture is far more than just diverse. You can find almost all types of cuisines from around the world almost anywhere here in Canada. People are self-conscious about their health. You would find free-to-use sanitizers at public places even before COVID happened. Nobody bothers about your life and don’t come to pinch-in pinch-out once in while telling what you should do. You are on your own. You hardly know who lives in third house from yours even after years pass by. This can be a plus or minus for people but in my opinion, it’s surely plus. People do have proper driving sense. Traffic gets controlled properly and all traffic laws are followed fairly strictly. It’s very hard to find someone who would regret moving to Canada.

I don’t have a definitive answer at the moment as I myself moved in here about 2 weeks ago. Just started exploring job opportunities. I would add my experience about job market in the coming days. It is purely subjective question, answer varies person to person based on their experience vs expectations of their future home. I live in Oshawa, Ontario. I got a bit of chance to explore day to day life here which I find it good interms of quality. I had been to public parks, library and shops interacted with locals and immigrants, overall environment is good and positive around. This aspect I like it the most here. So far so good, go for it. Stay positive about the new place and not to compare with another as every place has its own pros and cons that is again based on person to person. I will add more details later.

I haven’t migrated to Canada and i’m not hoping to in the near future. But from what i’ve heard from people who have and are truthful about their experiences; some liked it and others didn’t. For those who didn’t like it, they complained about the Canada work experience that Canadian companies always ask for. But to answer that concern, I was speaking with a friend last week. He migrated with his family to Canada. I asked him this same question of Canada work experience. His answer was that people should aim first at smaller companies to help them build their work experience, before applying to large corporations. Finally, I think I’m not in the best position to answer this question, just adding my 2 cents.

Best decision I ever made. I love the USA, but Canada is the future....multiculturalism that works, space to grow, easy access to fresh clean water, stunning and diverse landscapes, growing economy, natural resources to spare, tolerance (for the most part), value placed on manners and humility, gun control, separation of church and state, good government, innovation in a variety of fields, positive focus on the future, excellent education, social safety net, separation of government and the legal system, universal health care, space for wildlife to live away from humans, the arctic, French Canada, social stability...the list goes on. The cold? I just came back from Istanbul and Delhi a few weeks ago and it was cold there too. In Canada, everyone has internal heating in all homes and buildings. Canada is not nirvana but it has a lot of great things. I am glad i am here. This country works for me, now and hopefully in the future.

These kids have no idea why Punjabis left and why you living in prosperous state or city should leave? You will find these Punjabis consultant having branch in every city to trap these innocents with rosy pics and dreams. Even if 50 percentage succed what about the rest who have left well paying jobs and work at wallmart for years struggling with frustrated life. And everybody want to be at GTA and BC. I have told Canada is not for career making for educated people . It only for them who have no future and ready to do any work . You Fucking never cooked and washed clothes in India at your parents home and here you have to get out in knee deep snow every morning and carry heavy parcel at store or warehouse for pennies or work as watchman . Even month of May is chill. Why you need to suffer ? Are you from war torn nation seeking asylum ? Absolutely no ! Guys I would advise go on a tourist visa ,explore by meeting people , listen to their struggle before taking any decision and most importantly wasting your hard earned money. Peace Canada will keep tempting you. 😄😄😄

No I don't regret moving here. I love it but if you're coming from a country like India (especially from a warmer place such as Mumbai), you'll miss quite a few things being in Canada. What I personally find difficult : The weather in winter. I love the snow but honestly the summers can be really unpredictable as well because the temperature fluctuates all the time and it also rains! So to me summer is really really fleeting.If you're working here, you're going to have to do everything at home as well including cleaning and cooking (some people of course get help over the weekend etc but that can be expensive and eating outside every now and then not only is unhealthy it can quickly add to your expenses). So there's a lot of hard work to be done here.Even if you're working you won't be able to save a lot because you pay a lot of taxes, and cost of living is quite high as well.Other than these three, it's great living in Canada.

Yes. I am British but while living abroad I acquired a cat and at that time we had six months quarantine (for rabies) for all animals entering the UK, vaccinated or not. I was fortunate enough to obtain an immigration visa for Canada, was employed within a week and have lived here ever since. Canada is a wonderful country. The people are reasonable, peaceful and friendly. It has the rich tapestry of First Nations, their unique cultures and much wisdom. I admire Canada’s achievements, not the least of which has been to refuse to be bullied by our neighbour. I am fortunate to have been able to visit the country of my birth and education and for much that my two countries share.

I don't Like cold weather and I am in the prairies east of the Rockies so it is exceedingly cold in certain months of the winter.We broke a 40 year record last February..Global Warmijg means not only warmer overall but also more erratic temperatures. Am I sorry that I moved here to Alberta or to Canada ? Never do I wish to live elsewhere actually. People here are open generous and not aggressive overall and we are a safe and inclusive society. My family feels wrapped in a society that is trying to solve its problems through discussion and a clean voting system with a number of different parties in a parliamentary government. Women have taken on a more and more significant role and gender issues are front and centre as a demand for equality economically and politically has taken root. Am I happy to have moved here? After 50 years I can say, you bet!

No. How can I regret moving to a Country where I have the opportunity to achieve my dream. As a law abiding, peaceful, focus and hardworking immigrant; I never regret my decision of starting a new life in a country that want me to discover my dream. It is a home away from home for me. Since everyone dream is to live in a place where there is security of life and property, dignity of human person, social inclusion and equality, and freedom of religion or belief—all these I found in Canada. Albeit , no country on the planet is 100% perfect in all, the government of Canada is doing her best to create an haven for minority groups in the society, while ensuring peaceful coexistence among all races in the country.

Moving Canada is a dream come true to many people. But of course, there could be some getting-used-to in the beginning as it would be with getting settled in any new place. Some may feel home-sick in the beginning, especially if they are all alone. But let me tell you it will pass off. In my personal experience, I faced a little homesickness in the beginning, but that was because I missed my country and not in any way because of the new country. If anything, Canada made me get used to its community very easily. Canadians are very friendly. Anyhow, as there are people from many parts of the world in Canada, it is not hard to find out people of your liking. You can learn so many things from being a part of a multi-cultural society. There is a reason for Canada being able to attract a huge number of foreigners every year to settle there permanently. It is the easily accepting nature of the country that makes me feel at home. So, no. I have never regretted coming to Canada once. If anything, I want to become a Canada permanent resident as soon as possible.

It's been 2 months since I moved to Canada, Nova Scotia province . Well in last 2 months I say so far so good. I am located in Halifax I got myself a job within 2 weeks of landing , although background verification took another month before I could actually join work. I found myself an apartment ( took a cheaper apartment as I was unsure of my job while landing ) I also did my landing procedures within a week of landing ( SIN, health card, bank account, sim card, driving lisence, etc) while residing in Airbnb based accommodation. what exactly is my accept this becoming a PNP ( provincial nomination prospect) I don't feel dissapointed about any of it . I have a significant job with good wage, also I would like to add my work profile is practically just like I had that in India. i will be presently positive about my future leads right here. Loving the change . Not to mention the benefits that we have actually to be a parmanent citizen of Canada we know it that's why we used

I never regretted immigrating to Canada at age 23, and am grateful the country took me. But, in reading the responses of those who had regrets, it seems satisfaction depends on where you presently live and how you like that. My advice is compare- with facts. List the criteria that are most important to you, and compare your present country with Canada. Make a data-driven decision and weight the criteria that mean most to you. Ability to work in your chosen field will be important; research where the jobs in your field are, and salary ranges. Research cost of living for our various cities; this can vary greatly. If you •must• live in Vancouver, for example, you will pay a premium. Compare personal income tax in your present country to Canada’s but also check what the taxes pay for. Our taxes are on the high side, but your health care is largely paid for. The weather? You’re not made of marshmallow, dress for it.

I absolutely love Canada from the bottom of my heart and do not regret moving here. If you evaluate your experience in Canada only from the point of view of Career success you will be bitterly disappointed. It is true that your experience and education from back home wont be given any weightage and that you will most likely have to start from scratch. However, every job here gets equal respect and you will be able to live a good life doing any job. The winters are brutal for sure but since you have decided to live in Canada, it won't hurt to spend some money and pick up an activity to do in the winter. Most immigrants do not do that. Embracing the Canadian way of life and Canadian culture is quintessential to your success as an immigrant in Canada. Having access to places like these within a 2 hours drive is the ultimate privilege of living in Canada.

Hi Nikhil, Thanks for A2A. I actually do not regret any of my life decisions. I am content with whatever I encounter in life and moving to Canada was one such encounter or if I put it in my optimistic way, an opportunity of a lifetime to come out of the shell I was always kept in and I came out with flying colours at the end. Someone has told truly that if your efforts are selfless and true, you will always achieve success one day. So, for other people moving to Canada, it would test your patience and tolerance of getting hold of Canadian way of living. If you are ready for it, make the move. Cheers!! SD!!

Yes! It has just been 2 Months Here. Trust me, All those Instagram and Facebook stories of your friends chilling out in Canada are just a face to hide the real life struggles. From Budget Constraints to Winter Depressions to Sadly watching your loved ones chilling in India , There's lot of Struggles Everyday. Fortunately, I am here just for One Year and trust me even this One Year Seems to be Eternity! If You Have a choice to stay back In your own country, Don't Put yourselves into this Difficult situation!

A lot of the comments are about people moving to Canada and not making Canadian friends.If your sole purpose is to move to Canada to make friends,then you are in the wrong “business “.You move to a new country for a better standard of living,civilization, safety ,better money etc.The problem is that the civilization is slipping away in Canada.Visit any major city there and it would be hard for you to figure out what continent you’re on. It's a zoo.Cities like Toronto are turning into mini Chicago's. Money wise,at least for an EU citizen from Eastern European ,it's just not worth it.I was making 2000$/ month back home,moved to Canada and I was indeed making more, but the prices are through the roof. Property tax on a average home in Quebec 5000$/year(I was paying 200$/ year back home).Food prices at least 30% more .Go to a Walmart and pay 10$ for a kilo of cherries. Go to any Lidl,Aldi store in Europe and pay 3 euros for the same thing.European immigration to Canada is close to zero this days, but if any European is reading this,please stay away,for your own sake.It's not worth it.Europe is way better and I know that for a fact,I had the chance to work in the USA,Canada,Western and Eastern Europe.

I don't. Opportunities took me elsewhere for now. But in Canada I spent some transformative years, started my adult life, and had my personal identity formed. My family's move to Canada has ultimately made me a stronger, more flexible person, and I don't know many places where you are afforded the peace of mind to mold your self identity (at least that's how I felt in Toronto). With that being said, I know a good number of people that ultimately moved back to where they came from see: Ron Tal's answer to What is it like moving from Israel to Canada?

Best decision I ever made in my life bar none! So I didn’t have a college degree I was just a guy tying to make a living playing music when i moved up here in the early 70’s. back then work was plentiful and while I struggled to make a living playing music, there were manual labour jobs around so I never suffered for work. Got my landed status and then later my citizenship. Started paying into the medical plan which is a good reason to live anywhere you can have one. Long story short, I’m retired, live on a smaller fixed income that is enough for me, and altho I don’t have a lot I’m amazed that I don’t have to work as an older guy. Never thought that. Always thought that the day I died I’d be late for work.

Nope. I came from Central America from a horrible country where the only prospects for young men of little means is either: be unemployed and fight for your life by running from street gangs or join a street gang and survive by stealing from and murdering innocent people. So yeah, no regrets at all. People from first world countries like Canada and the US are way too self critical sometimes and split over their political differences that they don’t stop and appreciate how, comparably, awesome their countries are (for the most part of course).

I was born and raised in Canada. I went to college in the US and then married a Canadian and lived there for about 14 years. I liked living there very much. Our circumstances changed and we moved back to Canada 37 years ago. I like living here. However, I wish circumstances were different because I enjoyed it living in the US more than living back in Canada. We had family here but now they are almost all passed away. I would like to be able to live in the US again but that option is not available to me. I will however enjoy living here. I am fortunate to live in the most beautiful part of Canada here in Victoria.

response.answer_text: This entire diatribe is sectarian and grossly unappreciative, not to mention it reeks of loose and reckless personal experiences that do not echo the sentiments of tens of millions who have migrated here for good reason. I couldn't get past the initial diarrhea that is seemingly aimed to agitate proud Canadians who know better. It’s just too painful and uncultivated/unschooled/ignorant to continue reading. Canada is a wonderful country in all facets, it’s why the UN speaks to our distinct greatness among other desirable places to live. I implore you to leave and seek the fulfillment that you feel so adamant ‘Europe’ will provide for you. Addition by subtraction.

Yes… born in Alberta… international, professional, experience … have experienced intolerance… at minimum indifference here unlike any other place… Canada is regressing on many levels… stuck in extraction economy mind set … Second World values set entrenched … to what end…? Too many qualified people who want to contribute dissuaded. No country can continue to endure the brain drain Canada has fostered for last 30 years. The AVRO Arrow mind set continues… is engraved in a insecure Canadian mindset that does not foster competition and meaningful achievement…Sa productive… positive progress. Worse than ever… failed national projects is Canada’s legacy…

I live in Canada. One suggestion I would have for people looking to move to Canada is to DO YOUR RESEARCH. There are places in Canada where if you leave the house for 5 minutes you will literally freeze. (Northwest territories). There are places who are less accomodating to immigrants and are usually more “redneck" (Alberta, Saskatchewan). And there are places that have great public transport, lots of jobs and beautiful forests (Vancouver). Canada is not perfect; like any country it has assholes, and bad places that you do not want to live in. Do your research on the jobs available, the cost of rent, the cost of groceries, the weather conditions, the insurance costs, the beliefs of the people, the cost of schooling, and insurance and more … Canada is HUGE. To day that Canada is entirely good or entirely bad is simply a poor argument. Find a place that has the characteristics that you would like to live in and I'm sure you will love your time in Canada.

Call me blunt, but when it comes to filling in Canadian jobs: Canada has an obligation to hire Canadians FIRST and foremost. Only if they can’t fill the position domestically, then they will look outwards. When we see positions being filled by migrant workers under the TFW taking jobs that Canadians can fill (and then we wonder why there’s a shortage of jobs) then we are wondering what the hell happened? Consider your position before you immigrate here. You’re NOT entitled to a job in Canada; mainly because YOU are not a Canadian citizen (yet - if that’s the plan that you’re intending). You may not like my position, but I make no apologies for it. Come to Canada but don’t think you’re entitled to Canadians making room for you so that you can behave like an entitled immigrant.

Not at all. Canada is amongst the most civilized countries on the planet. Yes, it is cold, with only 2 seasons, but it is a place that respects the rule of law - which means you can exercise your rights as a citizen. If you’re looking to line your pockets with gold, this is not the place but if you’re looking for a peaceful place to raise your children, get them a good education & be protected with decent healthcare - you’ve come to the right place!

I do not regret even tiny bit moving to Canada and making it my home country where I raised 3 wonderful children together with my wife. Canada has always been great and will remain great. What a wonderful country. Personally I am not very traditional Muslim, quite a liberated person and accepting of all others. Canada provided me with lots of national and international opportunities. I welcome anyone to Canada who truly wants to make it their home and adapt accepting of all others. You will find Canada alright!

I lived in Canada for a short time. I went there (Montreal) for 2 reasons. 1) I was mistakenly led to think that Canada was kind of a ‘lay back America of the 50s - 60s.’ It ain’t. 2) Canadians are easy going, somewhat naive fun loving people that were hardy and wholesome. They ain’t ( maybe some are…just like some Americans are). I expected Canada to be a lot like America and it is to some degree…But there’s still something different about it that I found uncomfortable. Nice place to visit…but I moved back to the USA

First of all if you are coming from the countries where the temperature is warm, you will surely feel Canada lot much colder than your home countries in winters(Temp vary -10 to -20). But this does not seems to be a considerable factor to be regretting moving to Canada. You can enjoy beautiful summers of canada from May to August, these months I’m sure you will love this country. Secondly, I was worry of the culture in this country, But I am amazed to see that how friendly people are over here. No Racism. You’ll find different cultures in Canada all enjoying there space without discord. The Government is also found very stable and stable, Justin Trudeau, the Prime minister is well known for his down to earth nature and helping nature in the time of need

Not even a little bit. I got an awesome job within 4 months of landing in Canada as a PR. The Canadian work culture is good. I finished a diploma course for which the fee is paid by the Ontario Provincial Government. You are entitled to all basic amenities as equal to a citizen. I made a ton of friends in college and the office. Went on trips to beautiful places. Unlike USA H1B VISA, I don’t have any worries when it comes to traveling abroad. Life here is safe, slow and peaceful.

I have never visited Canada or never lived there. But as some Indians who returned from Canada there were some complaints. India is definitely not a developed country with lots of trash and air pollution but still why some Indians returned from there you may ask. Even with huge amount of healthcare amount in USA Indians will still prefer USA . See we Indians are practical people, we only want money and at the end of month we only want to have a disposable income. Canada highly taxes it citizens. Prices compared to USA are not cheap. Opportunities are few since startups are few, only salary is bit good but again they go in taxes mostly. Healthcare is single payer but not efficient. I heard about huge waiting times, which would make even the hot headed Indians cuss “chutiya desh”. It's sort of radical liberal believing that supporting LGBTQ is the most important thing.

I do not regret moving away from home and experiencing a new life .it has been an experience for me so far.i came as student now a citizen.when i came i just wanted to experience north american study work experience living culture.its has made me more independent self reliant experience has been enriching .ive learnt about credit how things work here how to pay for mortgages loans cc how you go about build things from scratch .what to do now i can move to any part of the world and do it all over again i plan to go back to India in near future for my personal reasons but over all its has been an eye opener

response.answer_text: Certainly not, yesterday I was commenting my wife, that our friends and family back home, cannot imagine how happy we are, doing whatever we love, building our future, everyone of us, making our dreams and goals come out and enjoying this level of life. For most of newcomers, I know is pretty hard to settle, and most of them miss their country back home, and complain for everything, hard to find a job, winters so cold, summers so hot, bla, bla, bla, but for us is the best country to live, so far. I don’t regret it at all. I moved to Toronto earlier this year. And yes, its not a cake walk. The process of settling down, finding a home, networking, job hunt, adjusting to the weather and the new culture - NONE of it is easy! As I figure out each piece of the settling down puzzle - I’m trying to share my personal learnings and help other newcomers adjust faster/better. Making settling down a little less unsettling for newcomers.

I was actually born here, so I didn't have a choice in the issue. That said, when I was gone, I regret not staying gone. However I had no idea how bad life was going to get and the dysfunction manufactured for me the last few decades, especially the violence and Terrorism of the last 12 years. Cruel and Unusual Punishment by anyone's standards. Never ending

I was born in Canada but my parents are from Punjab, India. My mother came here with her family at a young age. So when my father and mother got married my father moved to Surrey with my mother. They had my oldest sister Arsh Sidhu in 2002. It is a real struggle. Finding a job, paying for a car, and probably the hardest feeding your family. Now I and my family are stable all thanks to my parents’ sacrifices and the courage of leaving there own home.

This anecdote is a bit cynical: after my German grandparents failed to emigrate to the US and settled for Canada my great grandfather apparently spent months sulking. Then one day after coming home from a part time job (already an old man) he received a pension cheque (or a stipend of sorts from the govt) and then proclaimed “I would chose to live nowhere else!” jokes about socialism aside I think it’s amazing that Canada will happily support a family who by all intents and purposes were enemies of the state just months before.

This question varies based on each person’s expectations. For me, I’m not satisfied because I left a comfortable life in India working as a manager in a multinational technology enterprise, and found myself in a restrictive and closed job market like Vancouver. A place where my transferable leadership skills of managing global team members in US, Europe, and India were not recognised because I did not have “Canadian experience”. After a lot of struggles, I secured a job with an American company that recognised my skills and experience.

Wayback machine didn’t have the url, but here’s ”Top 8 Reasons NOT to Immigrate to Canada” taken off that site that might give you an idea of the unhappiness…. *** Visit: www.NotCanada.com ***

It is a beautiful country.. I am so thankful to God for that..People are very polite and well mannered (Though that is slowly changing ..thanks to the newcomers, though not all of them are responsible for it). The things I do not like here is, the so called ‘Canadian experience’ and high cost of living in cities like Toronto and Vancouver. Rent, Gas, Internet and phone are main factors which increase the cost of living. Rent is ridiculously high in these cities. If you don’t have Canadian experience, you may have to go to the college at whatever age you are, and struggle to go through the stressful college education and then start from the scratch.

I have a friend. He is an engineer and he moved to canada, Toronto. When I met him a few years later, he told me of his struggles there. The chief struggle was securing a job. Canadian companies only hired canadians and only if they really couldn't did they hire a foreigner. He searched for months. He is an engineer in singapore and a top rated one and he told me he was on the verge of APPLYING AT THE NEIGHBOURHOOD 7-11 ON THE OFF CHANCE THEY HAD A COUNTER JOB before he got a job as an engineer. So u can imagine how hard his struggle was.

Yes, when it is winter and I have to deal with cold (-30 C) and snow for 5 months of the year. No when I realize that I am closer to my family. Canada has many opportunities for wealth and advancement . But in a large city like Toronto it is almost impossible to get a professional job. But you can try some business which many people succeed at. Calgary is better for new immigrants as there are less people , housing though also expensive , is less than Toronto. My experience is that for my children they have had better opportunities but there really is only your immediate family. You will miss the social and family togetherness and support and be really lonely especially as your children grow up, get married and raise their own family. It is difficult to say whether moving to Canada is best. If your situation in your home country is terrible then you have more reason to go to Canada.
